reviewText: In a world where enhanced edition" has started to be synonymous with "will run on modern hardware if you shell out $20" it's absolutely refreshing to see Larian deliver this masterpiece free of charge to owners of the original. You start out with an already fantastic game that's received numerous game of the year and editor's choice awards. Then you spend a year polishing that game
date:
and adding new features. The result is brilliant Enhanced Edtion of an already fantastic game.

New features for EE:
Fully voice acted - Every line of dialog now has voice acting. The voice acting is really good too
Dual wield - Rogues now look more iconic with the ability to dual wield
Grenades - You can craft and throw various sorts of grenades.
Tactician Mode - A new  challenging mode where encounters are redesigned to be harder by adding new spells and enemies into the mix. Classic mode still available obviously.
Split screen co-op
Controller support
Updated graphics - The UI is totally reworked

reviewText:
This game is great in many, heavy aspects, and falls short on a few light ones. The negative aspects of it are more a matter of taste rather than being poor game design. Since so many negative reviews are written by people who think the game's too slow, I'll give a fast review so that you'll have time to play it sooner.

Pros:
- Great game design.
- Beautifully crafted world with a competent graphics engine.
- Great soundtrack.
- Combat is highly tactical and multifaceted. Planning and having a variety of strategies matter. (I recommend playing on Tactician Mode)
- Profound character creation, that actually matters in gameplay.
- Dialogue choices (sometimes) matter and help build character traits.
- Humour and pop-culture references.
- Lots of secrets.

Matters of taste:
- Very unforgiving to: Inexperienced RPG-players. Unskilled tacticians. People with bad dice rolls. Those who can't properly use Google as a last life-line. People who bought a keyboard without the F5 and F9 buttons. Sufferers of amnesia.
- Slow, sometimes painfully slow. A beverage or friend to accompany you through some parts of the game is highly recommended.
- A bit too few in combat" tracks.
- Arhu is ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere.

Cons:
- Repetitive character auto-reactions to world effects. ("Feeling a bit hot under the collar!" "On the mend!" "What a deluge!" etcetera)
- Unnecessarily slow animations and queuing outside of combat.
- A little too uninformative quest log.
- Some quests/parts of quests are downright uninteresting.
- As with any game of any publisher
date: a few bugs here and there."

reviewText:
This is a review/list of a 2 player Co-op experience (not split-screen) of the Enhanced Edition (without mods) played around a month after the release without any prior experience of any Divinity game. We played the entire game with keyboard and mouse on both computers.

Character creation, roleplaying, exploration and story.+ The characters are shaped during the travels allowing you to diverge (if you want) from the class you created at the start.
+ Reading books, letters and listening to NPCs reward the players taking their time doing those kinds of things.
+ LOADS of side-quests with varying components such as VIP-escort, bosses, storylines for your mercenaries, puzzle solving and rollplaying (duh!).
+ There's voice acting for (almost) all the dialogues in the game.
+ (Co-op only) You and your Co-op friend may disagree on matters in the story and this will change your characters traits in different ways, giving you different bonuses based on what you reply.
+ (Optional) The Tactician Mode offers a fun and innovative harder playthrough where the enemies have new tricks up their sleeves.
+ (Optional) The Honour Mode = Permadeath + Tactician Mode combined. No resurrection scrolls, saves over your one and only saveslot when someone in your party dies and deletes your save if both your main characters die.
~ The Puzzle elements in the game can both be fun and frustrating at times.
~ We didn't even use half of the spells in the game, yet somehow we felt like there were spell classes not even present in the game.
- Keys/arrows/books will clutter up your inventory and it's hard to keep track on what to keep/throw so you might end up keeping them all in a bag. Maybe a keychain & a quiver would be an alternative.
- Renaming/customizing bags so that you can identify what is inside without opening it would be a nice addition.
- Got stuck HARD on one of the quests due to the way we wanted to play. Minor spoiler warning. The Councillor's Wife"-quest forces you to break in and steal things. We were trying to play without stealing/breaking in anywhere
date: but it seems to be the only way you can do it.\nCombat.+ The elemental system offers alot of options in fights
recommended:
puzzles and character development.
+ Enemy encounters feel challenging throughout the entire game.
+ A large variety of enemies to encounter. (which gets even better in Tactician Mode!!)
+ Being able to sort your spells and action items into 5 different "hot-bars" is a life saver later on.
- Selecting enemies during fights can be a pain because you might miss them due to their animations.
- From time to time the enemies and other NPCs don't know what to do during a fight so they just stand around and skip their turn after ~10 seconds.
How does it look? What does it sound like?+ The massive 7 hour soundtrack was one of the biggest surprises for us
hoursPlayed:
it is very enjoyable.
+ Refreshing environments in contrast to many games that go for the gloomy look.
+ It's easy to see what is going on when you're in combat or out adventuring.
+ A smart system that makes things see-through where your characters are.
+ Great and easy to use camera controls.
- The cinematics could use a visual overhaul.
- A few times in the game uninvolved NPCs won't shut when you are fighting.
Options and performance.+ We didn't experience a single software-crash during the entire game!
+ The option menu included everything that we wanted to change
voteText: including a sound mixer with the following sliders available: FX/Music/Ambient/Voice/Cinematics and Master.\n+ Has built-in support for mods. However
helpfulPercent: there aren't that many mods available at the time of writing.\n+ Includes a variant of borderless fullscreen called "Fake Fullscreen". Jumping in and out of the game is as fast as you'd expect from a borderless feature
votesHelpful: but it will minimize as soon as you're clicking on something outside the game.\n- The top part of the UI doesn't show the correct values such as your health
votesTotal:
the turn order and which buffs/debuffs you and your enemies have been exposed to.
- Both of us experienced sound problems in certain areas of the game: King Boreas' treasury and right outside Icara's Ice Prison.
- (Co-op only)Sometimes the game won't show (or even load) the same data for both players.
Examples: The second player won't see the correct animations

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is a roleplaying game developed by Larian Studios. The game was also partially funded through Kickstarter. This enhanced edition of the game was released in October 2015 for PC, PS4 and Xbox One. It came as a free upgrade for everyone that owned the original game which was released in June 2014.

Gameplay in Original Sin follows a very classic RPG style of play. You control two heroes, and you take part in battles which are turn-based combat.  The game play is very tactical, and some fights can last up to about forty five minutes at times. Positioning, making sure you use potions and spells at the optimal moment all play a key role to success in Original Sin. The combat system can be considered to be slow paced, but I personally enjoyed the tactical thought you have to put into every action you take. The game’s tutorial system at the start of the game is done very well, and introduces all elements of gameplay in a satisfying manner.  A lot of the game is based in dialogue as well; I will say this now, if you aren’t one for reading masses amount of text (or listening to), then you will probably want to avoid playing this game, as there is a boat load of text and dialogue to be found here. There are times when you get to make key choices in the dialogue scenes, and also offers branches to find out more information about lore and plot as well.  Overall, the gameplay is really well done, and if you want to find a game that you can absolutely get completely lost in its gameplay, then you should stop here and just pick it up.

Graphically, Original Sin looks gorgeous. The enhanced version of the game improved the graphics quite a bit over the original release, and how managed to reduce the install size. The colourful environments and lush greenery just look amazing. This is one of the best looking games I have played in a very long while. The animations of all characters is done very well too; never did I see any janky looking movements or action, which helped at keeping me fully immersed in the beautiful world.

As with all RPG games, the story is crucial to the reception it gets. Original Sin does not disappoint here either. On top of the games over arching main story line, you also have the chance to branch off into other lesser side plots which can sometimes make you forget all about the rest of the game as they are so in depth. The side quests in this game would probably be main stories in another; that is how good the plot behind Original Sin is. You will of course have to be up for reading the text if you want to get the full effect out of it though.

The majority of Original Sin is voice acted – this helps a lot given the amount of text in the game, but there are parts, which are sometimes quite randomly selected, which aren’t voice acted. This is where you will need the patience to continue reading the dialogue to fully understand what is happening in the world. The sound effects and soundtrack are really good too; nothing seemed out of place so it fits in well with the game.

I found the game to be fairly tricky, I had never played the classic RPG games, I was just too young to understand them, and so I felt as if this game took me on a crash course of learning about them. I have to admit, I did have to use wiki’s and FAQs at times to progress and work out how best to tackle a few bosses; but that should be taken as part and parcel of the gaming experience with something of this size. Researching the best action to take for me makes the game all that more fun.

The world in which this game is set in, feels so alive and active. When you are in towns you can hear plenty of market sellers in the background selling their goods, you can find countless amounts of side quests, and plenty of items to interact with and loot. If you are looking for a game with almost perfect level design, look no further.

In total, this game took me about 54 hours to complete, this was with doing as many side quests as I could find and listening/reading to all the dialogue in the game as well – that is on single player. Where Original Sin gets above other games of its type, is that you can also play the game in co-op mode as well; that alone means you can probably hit the triple figures for the amount of hours on offer in this game.  There is an absurd amount of content to see.

Since this is the enhanced edition of the game, I didn’t find any technical issues. The game runs like a dream on 4k resolutions. Loading times are almost none existent as well. Like I said above, they have somehow managed to get the install size down on the game as well, which is something of a mystery given the amount of improvements they have added/changed. .

To sum up, Divinity: Original Sin is an absolute masterpiece of a game. The gameplay whilst slow paced is so well done, it will keep you interested and wanting more after you first battle. The plot is one of the best I have ever had the pleasure of seeing in any video game, and one that I will remember for a very long time. On top of all this, you the amount of content on offer is amazing. I cannot recommend Divinity Original Sin enough, even if you aren’t a massive fan of the RPG genre, this could be the game that changes that opinion for you.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
I can not tell you properly with words how good this game is.

I will try however and I should start, as everyone, comparing it to old school RPG titles. Unlike recent RPG-called titles from this century —mostly made for the new generations of players, with little or no brains needed at all to solve quests—, Divinity: Original Sin looks like a true role playing game reminiscent of the old ages but with very cool new ideas —some of them unique— and fresh graphics.

The main characteristic, typical of Larian games, is the freedom to do almost everything you want: the game is classless, so you can choose a warrior in the beginning and later on you can change your mind and provide him with some spells or range skills, if you like it, when he level up; this way you will end up with four characters, two of them from the start and two more later on, with a combination of skills, traits and talents that fits you. You can interact with almost every item in the game: doors, chests, barrels, pictures, chairs, etc, and you can open them to look inside or destroy them if you prefer, or even take them and move them from one place to another. You can also choose if you prefer to talk to every NPC and solve quests, trade with them, or killing them if you like it, or even steal their items and loot their houses. Every action will make the villagers approach you in different ways, turning hostile to you or being polite instead. And if you don't like to trade with NPCs a lot you are able to craft your own gear and even spells if you choose to do it with the immense amount of ingredients and tools you will find everywhere.

What makes this game unique, and a gem, is a combination of the role playing part with the interaction between characters —even yours!— and its combat system. Divinity is not a combat focused game, it is more a conversational and exploration RPG title; however, combat is also very important and this is not a real time one, it is a turn-based combat system with action points mechanics that forces you to think about your resources, the enemies, and the environment; so each turn you can use your points to move, drink potions, attack or cast spells if you got enough points for them, or if you prefer you can reserve some of your remaining action points for your next turn, for example if you want to wait when the enemy is far away from you and later on you want to hit him two or three times in the same turn. The best part of the system is, no doubt, the chance —and mostly the need— of using the elements on your favour. It means you can cast a rain spell on your characters to stop them from burning; you can also cast rain on enemies, make them wet and then cast electricity spells for extra damage and stuns. You can also use ice spells if enemies are wet —state than come from your spells or from real rain itself!— to freeze them. You can shoot (after throwing it for example) an oil barrel with a fire spell to make it explode and damage the area, or just hit it with your arrows to make it pour the oil and later on cast fire on it if you wish. You can make an ice barrier to protect, wait until enemies are near it and then fire it, making it water and causing enemies to stumble, and then electrify them. You can combine elements to create clouds to avoid being a target. You can stealth and stab enemies too if you have the right character to do such a thing. You can use barrels and things of the environment to take cover, to protect you and to avoid damage. You can also try to flee if you find the situation too chaotic for your taste. You can... well, you can —and you should— do all these things if you want to survive, because combat is not always an easy task on this game.

For all these things I must say this is a heck of a game; I have not THAT fun with a videogame probably since some decades (I'm absolutely for real here). It's also true that there are some things that are not optimal and need improvement. Among the negatives, there is the camera movement, the slow pace of the game sometimes when you need to go from A to B, and the bad interfaz mechanics when you need to equip gear, change items from character to character, sell something or look at the items you got, or pick them. This is not a noob-friendly game; aside from the little dungeon tutorial at the start, you will find little or no help at all and you will find lost yourself if you are not used to RPGs games. However, asking in the forums will help you; there will be trolls, true, but overall the community will end up answering your questions and solving some of your starting problems, I'm pretty sure.

But if I take all these things together and put them all in a balance, I have to recommend this game to every player in the world. If you are an oldschool gamer you just can't pass on this. And if you are a new player and you didn't play or didn't even know any of the games other guys are mention, you have to give this one a chance and compare it yourself with the new RPGs. I promise you won't be disappointed.


PLUS you have also the Enhanced now, which add more quests, balanced skills, graphics, controller support, camera movement, subtitles in some languages, full voice actor and help with some of the issues the game got before. And even more difficult settings, with a new one with permadeath and only one savegame for massoquist tastes.

reviewText:
I have over 80 hours logged with the original version of this and it is by far one of my most favorite recent RPGS out there. They really added alot of changes. They revamped the crafting, added VO to practically ALL dialogue(and the voice acting is charming, IMO), and spruced up performance and made everything generally better.

If you played the original and loved it...this is complete fan service. Seriously. If all gaming studios treated their products with loving as Larian has done...the gaming industry would be unrecognizable.

I whole-heartedly recommend this. It makes a fantastic game even better.

++voice acting; great quailty and I am damn sure the opening into narration is the same voice actress as the female british Inquisitor from DA:I
++dual wielding!
++GRENADES!
++more crafting/craftin UI overhaul! Hell...the entire UI has been changed and overhauled and for the better!
++optimized performance!
++better graphics all around than previous version.
++tactical mode for the people out there who love surprised and even greater challenge. They designed it to counter common strategies of players of the original. Seriously. I am seeing the AI do things I havent seen before in the original. Looks like its been upgradd.
++honour mode = one save only. Think of it as Ironman Mode. You die and your save is deleted.

I honestly cannot think of any cons right now. I will update this if I do. I am liking it that much.

reviewText:
I backed this game on kickstarter and played the original  version (the one before the enhanced edition). Back then I wrote a pretty negative review her on steam. It just wasn't very enjoyable for various reasons. I actually never got through the first story quest because most of the time I didn't have any idea what to do next. The game just threw you into this world and left you all alone.
Luckily for me and everybody else Larian continued working on their game released the enhanced edition. I decided to give it one more try and totally fell in love with this beautiful game.
First an foremost, there is now more guidance at the beginning of the game. You're still pretty much free to do whatever you want, but the game mostly points you in the right direction.  At the beginning it's still a little tough to get into (since you will be doing a lot of running around, talking to people when you would like to test the awesome combat system). But follow through and you get rewarded with one of the most intricately, beautifully crafted RPGs since the Baldur's Gate series.
Every handcrafted corner of the world is dripping with the developer's love for details. If you look closely, you will find interesting/weird/scary/funny surprises behind every corner. The combat systems is one of the best I have ever seen in an RPG (the use of the elements and their combination isn't just a nice advertising gimmick) and character developement is really open and deep.
Do yourself a favor and buy this game right now.

reviewText:
Don't judge a book by its cover.

Imagine opening a tabloid newspaper for a quick read about the Kardashians and finding inside scientific journals.

From the outside this excellent RPG looks like Diablo had a threesome with Disney and Torchlight.

Inside this is a complex, funny and innovative game. There is no RPG like it.

Fire + Poison = Explosions.
100% fire resistance + immunity to burning = walking on lava.
105% fire resistance = healed by fire.
You can talk to the animals!

At the beginning of the game my mage was using Air magic in combat and shocking themselves into missing a few turns in combat. Lol - I am so lame. Don't stand in a puddle of water ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

I used a rain spell to douse a burning ship and got involved in a love human/ orc thing going on.

I investigated a murder that took me to the end of time and came across and elderly deranged elf looking for justice for his murdered family. (Very creepy voice - lovely acting).

It's all not fun and games. There is a dark side too where you come across great evil and undead. Of blood and sacrifice and the end of the world.

Combat is turn based and quite a joy. The combination of elements and battlefield layout allow almost infinite possibilities in battle.

Use telekinesis to bash enemies on the head with water barrels. Use your bow or sword. Conjure zombies and fire elementals. Throw grenades. Quaff a healing potion. The world is quite open and you will often come across battles you can't win. Either innovate or come back later.

Do it your way and have bags of fun. Recruit some companions or play through with your original two. Play through a rock, paper, scissors mini game to convince NPCs to accept your views. These are not the droids you are looking for."

Inventory and Crafting. Literally millions of things to pick up which can be crafted into millions of combinations. You uncover recipes as you read books but you can experiment too. Slipping on ice too often? Bang some nine inch nails to the bottom of your boots.

The developers have also brought a Legend of Grimrock 2 type puzzle element to the game. It's strange. Requires brain function. What? In this game. Really? I can separate my party? In fact one puzzle requires you to kill a party member and teleport to their dead body 'on the other side'. Scary. Amazing.

I really struggled to get into the final location in the game until I retrained my brain and used these teleport pyramids given to you early on. When I solved the puzzles it was like I passed my school exams again. I did me proud.

Negatives needed right?

Crafting - overwhelming at first. Confidence gained in second play through.

Mission items - they are not tagged. You can't sell them. You can't find them in your inventory. Where is that stupid
date:
STUPID reveal scroll? Have I broke the game?

Missions - you really can go round and round and round trying to progress. There is only a little hand holding.

Summary

I really
recommended: REALLY love this game. It's beautiful. Innovative. It looks like Disney but inside there is iron and steel. It will chew you up and spit you out. It will test your RPG credentials unlike Wasteland 2 or Pillars of the Eternity did.\n\nIf you are looking for a proper RPG
hoursPlayed: with C&C and complexity - take it on."

reviewText:
By far the new standard in Couch Co-op games.

No longer is  Player 2 invisibly bound to Player 1 by some kind of autoscrolling window game of running man simulator.

Quest, loot, fight, flee, craft, and create your own experinces independently, with a dynamic same/split screen interface.

Divide your party and combine again at any time through useful tools, like; Synced log/quest book, synced crafting recipies, magic pockets, send to player inventory, shared map/quest markers, and warp to player.

Use the character classes for Co-op role play, with skills like leadership for example granting bonus's to the characters when they are together.

The world of Rivellon is moulded by both of you, quest outcomes are debatable and roleplay dialogues allow you to express your opinion in game. Disagree with your flat-mate on whether or not those guards should be killed for treachery? Don't like how your girlfriends Cleric has decided to end a conflict peacefully?   Oppose them in dialogue and force the issue to the fate of virtual rock, paper, scissors.   Win and the desicion is made, lose and have comfort that your characters personality is still affected by your protest.

This game has recieved 9.0 /10 on IGN and 4.5/5 overall on Metacritic.
I persoanlly give it a 10/10 for co-op alone.  Works great on steam link/controller.

Dont have a couch mate? the original sin comes with online co-op which plays out with the same flexibility.

reviewText: If you're into games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment and Pillars of Eternity then you are going to like this game. Game starts out really slow where you just blindly rob everyone in the first town and never leave until you reach a certain level. Well you can leave but if you do so too early then you'll have a hard time outside. If you go out and stray from the main questline you're going to get destroyed cause mobs don't scale with your level so you'll have to do things a certain way. There's a few areas where the sound just dies. This happens in areas where there's a lot of windy and gust noises. Seems to be a bug that hasn't been fixed yet. The turned based combat in this game is really fun as well as you can combo elements. For example you can throw an ice shard, freeze the ground, then cast rain to melt the ice, and use lightning to create a static water field to stun enemies grouped up. I'm nearing 70 hours and I just entered the last major map of the game so there is also a lot of content here with very little loading screens. Very fun game and I am hyped for Divinity: Original Sin 2

reviewText:
I don't post much on Steam, and can't remember the last review I've written, but this game warrants one. Larian Studios has produced a masterpiece here. I love it. The co-op experience is amazing, and there are so many wonderful little quality components to this game, that I keep finding myself amazed! Just a few moments I loved:

1. The first time the buddy I am playing with interrupted my conversation and challenged the answer I gave the NPC, resulting in a rock/paper/scissors match. Very cool, and how these answers influence your tendencies, kudos!

2. The first battle I really experience environmental effects. Got frozen, then slipped on the ice, followed by 2 enemies falling beside me...

3. Learning how the crafting system actually works and then being floored by just how detailed it is. Holy crap, what a wonderful addition. Did my buddy really just break a bottle with a hammer and then put the shards of glass in an empty grenade to make an armor-piercing grenade. Cool!

4. When the enhanced edition came out and I got it for free. Thank you Larian Studios, love to see a studio that cares about the customer. Take note State of Decay. Additionally, what an improvement the enhanced edition actually is! Tactician mode is awesome.

I could go on, but I hope you get the point. If you enjoy computer RPGs, play this game. Even better if you can play with a buddy. Such an epic experience!

reviewText:
An RPG not meant for everybody
If you are looking for an easy, fast-paced RPG, Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition is not the RPG for you.

This is a challenging game with heavy dialogue and slow-paced combat system.

If your party is not prepared for combat, they will easily get wiped out.  The combat is difficult because your party is out numbered and out levelled in most situations.  There are only a finite numbers of enemies on the map so you cannot “grind” to level your party up or get better loot.  The game is laid out in a linear way which forces your party to outsmart your enemies by using the proper spells and environment surroundings.

I can appreciate the work done by this indie game developer, but I find this game is little too hardcore for my taste.

Due to the rating system, I can’t give this game a mixed review.

If you like challenge and exploration based RPGs, you might want to try out Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition.

If you are a beginner to RPGs, I suggest skipping this game.

At the end of the day, I have to ask myself Did I have fun with this game?"  Sadly
date: I have to answer  no.  Getting into the game combat system
recommended: puzzles and exploration was a chore for me."

reviewText:
Best RPG on PC. It's not even close. Do NOT waste time reading the things I am about to say about this game. There's no need for that. It's a must buy.

Positives:

- Split screen on PC! (player 2 can join and leave seamlessly while player 1 is playing, just pick up the controller man!).
- Supports controllers. Because that's how they roll.
- Both online and offline multiplayer.
- Over 100 hours worth of content with multiple difficulty levels. And no, the difficulty levels aren't just jacking up the health points and damage. Enemies gain new skills, strategies. Oh, and there's more of them. There's also permadeath mode for you nutjobs. Thought Diablo 3 was hard on hardcore? Think again.
- Great art style and visuals.
- So. Many. Damn. Spells. So many.
- Characters are highly customizable.
- Awesome loot is highly rewarding. Trust me, good gear in this game makes a huge difference. But not quite as much as a good strategy and smart...
- Manipulation of elements! You can create water puddles which you then can electrify. Or freeze to create an icy platform to trip your foes.. Or allies. Yes, there is friendly fire and yes it is absolutely glorious.
- Very difficult fights. There's also puzzles.. Don't worry.. There are guides in YouTube for you slackers too..
- Dialogue between your characters (or your and your friend's characters!). And yes, you have a choice in, well.. Making choices. And yes, you can disagree.
- Easy to understand crafting system that was improved in this version. It's very straight forward.
- You can murder everything in your sight. Even your quest givers. Say goodbye to your possible rewards though.. Or just kill them after the quest.. Not like I have any experience doing that of course.. Also, you can steal (I HIGHLY recommend doing that. God the amount of gold......)

Negatives:
- Nothing really worth mentioning. I guess if you dislike turn based combat that requires lots of thinking could be considered one if you are more into your average hack 'n slash rpg's". But no
date:
there's nothing worth even mentioning.

Verdict: You really think it's even necessary to rate this game?

reviewText:
An incredibly enjoyable RPG experience that you can share with friends.
It isn't without flaws despite what some people say for some reason, but it is irrefuteably a fantastic old school style game that will remind you of games like Baulders Gate.

The game has plenty of voiced dialogue, a deep immersive world, and solid well built tactical gameplay that keeps you pushing forward. It gives you a plethora of weapons, and an okay amount of spells to experience; however the armor and gear in the game has almost no real customization and there is not much effort put into letting you have any type of unique appearance.

The game has quite a few bugs and oversights unfortunately, from incorrect textures, to health bars in multiplayer not synching up properly (I healed myself too many times when I was already full health because of that problem).
Rain doesn't put out fires, but if you cast rain it does, initial character creation in multiplayer a bit tricky, due to how the multiplayer system works, and misclicking will happen a LOT especially with the auto pathing issues.
Another small issue is that all females have high heels as a mandatory thing, regardless of if traveling frozen tundra or volcanic ruins, their class or anything else...

There is nothing too game breaking however, and most of it is fairly easily dismissed or dealt with.

All in all it's a great game, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the older slower paced tactical RPGs from when they were younger.

reviewText:
Let me tell you a story of how a daring, kind adventurer who set out save the land, fell from grace in an instant.

Finished quest. No money, but I've got a full inventory.
Better start clearing through this stuff for what to keep and what to sell.
Scrolling through inventory.
There's a massive ornate chest in there.
Must've picked it up on that quest.
Dump it in the middle of town and try to open it.
Lockpicking level too low.
Doesn't matter, mages can break open chests with magic.
Might as well farted on it for all the damage it does.
One of the stall vendors near by sees me attacking this chest.
Clearly I am a murderer and out to kill everyone.
Vendor freaks out and calls the gaurds.
Try to load previous save.
Haven't saved in over an hour.
sigh


And that's how the entire population of Cyseal halfed instantly, as they tried to defend the innocent chest from the evil Source Hunters who saved them earlier that day.

Doesn't matter, got tons of loot... the other half of the city doesn't even care.

Chest is still locked

11/10

reviewText:
Somehow the developers made something well designed and extremely fun, even better then it was before. Divinity is already a game that speaks for itself in most aspects. The graphics, the combat, the story, and customization and options were all top notch and exceeded most peoples expectations. Truly it's a Kickstarter story success. Bringing all the elements of CRPG titles that you know and love, and giving each feature an awesome modern twist. From Co-op/Multiplayer to amazing quests. The Enhanced edition brings more in the form of sharpened graphics, voice acting, controller support, and making the game much more friendly to new players. At the same time they have added new challenges to keep fans of the original title salivating and challenging their tactics and parties to the limit. Being a new player to Divinity, I instantly fell in love with this title and I don't want to look back. This game brings everything I loved about D&D, Ultima, and does things in its own unique style. Giving you the freedom to choose your own party, your own adventure, and have an amazing time while exploring the vast world and lore of Divinity. If you are a fan of CRPG's, there is no reason you shouldn't own this title. Which brings me again back to how amazing it is that they made a great game an even better game. That is a fine line to walk and Larian Studios did it, and did it well.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/2OnfJMVxqA0
I hope you enjoy!

reviewText: Engrossing RPG with many elements from older top-down, turn-based, games. Does not go easy on the player and the mechanics need to be discovered, but once they are you get a valid sense of achievement when you complete puzzles and defeat challenging bosses.  Inventory is bit of a pain as nearly everything is craftable into something else, so you don't want to get rid of much and the interface doesn't give you a search option (just sort by, which can be helpful).  I recommend long time TBRPG players to play the Tactician mode as it makes combat difficult (and sometimes frustrating), but it really makes you play the game.  I've enjoyed many hours so far exploring, trying to work out crafting, completing as many quests as I can, and doing a lot of saving and reloading--especially the saving and reloading.  ;)

reviewText:
This is cRPG with good story, great dialogs, big dose of humour, difficult tactical fight and many skills, spells and items.
Does good RPG game need more to be good? Probably not, but this is not a good game, this is great game, so it offers all of it and a lot more! Let's mention also great sound and graphics, smart AI, crafting and full voice acting. I mean FULL, so in this game rats can talk and even bull can be fortune-teller!
But it's still not the end, I haven't mentioned two biggest features.
First is that in this game you control two main heroes, instead of one as usual. They may have totally different opinions and argue with each other during making decisions. How it affects on the game? Character you don't agree with, may win an argument and make decision you didn't want to make! Almost like in real tabletop RPG games with real players. Brilliant!
Second thing is fight. You may interact with environment and use the elements in many combinations, so you can bring the rain, freeze it to slipped enemies, turn the ice back to water and then into steam which may be electrified by lightning and shock lying enemies. But make sure that your characters are far enough during all of that. This is complete change of rules!
So on the one hand we've got difficult old-school RPG with tons of dialogs, but on the other, this game offers more than just evolution to the genre.
I do not hestiate to say that this game is more revolution than evolution!

VERDICT
MUST HAVE for every RPG fan!
But if you're modern action player, I need to warn you. This is difficult game with lot of dialogs, so it may be boring for some people.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've got to play. I was catious getting into it as I didnt get into Pillars of Eterinity, its market competition, but my fears were unfounded. The world is rich and well crafted, with memorable characters and long hours of gameplay. As of writing the review with 66 hours in I'm only about 70% done in the main quest. Totally worth it!

Also, really recommend taking the Pet Pal with one of your characters to enhance your experience with a bit more quests and interactions. Also Timfred the badass buck. Word!

Pros:
Long rich questline and side quests.
Big zones to explore.
Good loot system and distribution.
Complex fights and pretty good AI ability casting (they have a problem with user placed obsticles though).
Gorgeous environments and creature designs.
Amazing soundtrack, really, it works so well to give atmosphere and enhance fights
All narrated charcters, even the mute ones (through a narrator).
Funny jokes and easter eggs all over, which don't interfere with the overall feel of the game.


Cons:
This game doesnt make it clear where you should go next, even if you want to know. The logs are detailed in case you want to remember details, but I always found myself going into the wrong places and dealing with higher than my level mobs, to later to go to the correct" place and fight redundant fights for worthless loot. Some places were not in the quest line at all but gave important story info.
This game's puzzles are sometimes bad hidden object games
date: and sometimes "find the combnation" through trial and error. Dont expect to get clues as to what to do on about half of them.\nSteam has a syncing issue with the game where it takes quite some time to sync to the servers after you quit. I have no idea why it happens but it takes me 5-10 mins to sync the data
recommended: so no immediate switching to other games.\nA few misplaced noises in the soundtrack make you wonder if you activated a trap or your attempted action was denied or some other bad accidental event. I'm talking about you
hoursPlayed: clunky-clunk and droppy-drop!\nSpammy-helpless-characters-with-one-line-to-say make some rescue fights annoying."

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the original Divine Divinity, I really wasn't happy when I saw that Original Sin had turn-based combat. I always preferred action RPGs and quick paced fights over sluggish moves and waiting on your opponent's turn. However, Original sin has a great way of combining a HUGE amount of cross-class combos with tons of environment effects like explosions, poisons, ice you can slip on, mud that slows you down, oil you can set fire to… which actually makes no fight like the previous, and your options endless.

Pair that with an amazing story, very funny – yet witty dialogues, insanely huge locations to explore, and you have yourself one of the best RPGs ever made - if not the best RPG to date.

The graphics are gorgeous, bursting with details on par with the golden days of 2D RPGs, and yet again, as in the original Divinity – you can pick up and move pretty much anything in the game which can result in very useful player-made covers during combat, or just plain silly outfits like using a water bucket for your helmet (because - why not?)!

I really won't go into any detail here because no quick Steam review can do this game any justice. The game runs perfectly smooth, no hiccups, no bugs (although you might get into a situation where your other hero doesn't agree with you and overrides some of your decisions which might lead to a specific quest not being able to finish – but that's the only isolated issue I've found in 60+h of gameplay).

TL;DR - It's not a game, it's not a RPG – it's a piece of art.

10/10 – Would pet Arhu again.
voteText: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
My trouble with Divinity: Original Sin began at the character creation screen.

You have to pick two characters with no explanation as to why. I set about designing a fearsome, burnished bronze-skinned, flame-haired vixen, and I named her Mavis, because old names are brilliant and if I ever get a dog I’ll probably call it Wilf. Mavis looked like she could turn her steely gaze on a field of enemy orcs and they’d burn through fear alone. The other character had hair like Marouane Fellaini, and I called him Barry. This was a mistake.

After the brief introduction from a pirate with a voice like John Lennon about some sauce someone had spilt in Rivellon (I wasn’t sure about that bit if I’m honest), you’re thrown pretty much into the deep end. There’s no type of tutorial beyond a training dungeon of sorts, but the UI is quite straightforward and there’s nothing to frighten anyone who managed to get their head around the countless RPGs of old this game resembles, Point-and-click to move, “I” for inventory, you know the drill.

Immediately the game screams I AM RPG at you, with scrolls and mysterious tales and a corpse on the beach. Your two characters interact with everything in sight, from crates that are invariably empty to NPCs who have a series of odd tales to tell; as you reach land you find the journal of a man joyful at how he can fly who then climbs a nearby cliff and discovers that he really can’t, like those pillocks who hurl themselves off Worthing Pier with experimental wings on their back every year.

You can talk to just about every character in the game, though non-named NPCs have little to say and often ramble over the top of each other like teenagers at a weed-free party. Your adventuring pair even talk to each other in a manner affected by how you’ve chosen their “AI Personality” at the start. I knew no better and chose “random” for both, which turned out to mean “schizophrenic”, as one minute Mavis was complimenting Barry’s grave-robbing skills and the next she was calling him a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for breaking their only lockpick.

In opening zone Cyseal you’ll eventually unearth two additional characters you can co-opt to form a merry band of travellers. And travel they will around this massive world, which seems to stretch out endlessly in every direction with additional zones to teleport to when you’ve accidentally worked out how. Fans of exploration will certainly have a wondrous time in this game.

Unfortunately, it was a desire to see the world that first led to the realisation that Barry was a useless fool, much like the real Marouane Fellaini. Of course I was happy to blame myself for Barry’s first electrocution, wandering as he was through a puddle at least six inches deep. Dangerous business, puddles. There must have been a warning I missed, I think.

But absolutely everywhere poor Barry went, trouble found him. Hordes of zombies would home in on him as the weakest link and he would invariably die after a single round of turn-based combat. His mighty weaponry could only have been rendered even more deadly by the addition of a feather duster to his non-sword hand.

At one point the hapless Barry watched as all three of his colleagues fled a hopeless battle in turn only to realise he was too close to the enemy to get away. Over the course of nine combat turns he tried to use his “action points” to run away, and seemed about to make it to safety when he was ended in a horrifying ball of flame that appeared from Christ alone knows where. As usual, Mavis had to find his sticky pile to resurrect him and escort him back to Cyseal, tail between legs.

At least part of Barry’s problem was that while exploring the world outside the town, you’re given no warning that you’re about to be attacked by a group of six or seven undead or wolves or similar that are of a far higher level than you could hope to cope with. Retreat becomes depressingly useful, though there seems to be little penalty for it (and once you’ve retreated, have fun working out how to re-link your characters so they’re not wandering about alone – it took me about 20 minutes and you’re on your own).

Even Cyseal held terror after terror for our witless hero. The group would find a book with the solid RPG title of Secrets of the Scroll Volume II, and what self-respecting adventurer wouldn’t want a read of that? So Barry picks it up to flick through, but the game mechanics dictate that he’s actually stealing the book and its nearby owner suddenly goes berserk and starts hacking at him with some sort of axe until he is yet again a tragic red mess the book’s owner now has to clean up.

Theft is everywhere, and if you’ve a moral problem with larceny you’ll get nowhere with this game. When no-one’s looking you can trouser whatever’s on offer in someone’s house to sell to any vendor. If the lady of the house pops to the toilet it’s your duty as saviour of the world to have away with that portrait of her husband while her back is turned.

Some aspects of the game are handled a little ham-fistedly, mostly notably the system for convincing NPCs to let you do what you want. I wanted to get through a door; the guard, of a friendly faction I should add, said “No”. I chose the option to try to “reason with him”. This led to an inexplicable game of rock, paper, scissors, which I lost, at which point the guard decided I was a simpleton and started attacking me. “Chip my rock with your scissors will you? Come here!”

The game is about depth, exploration, a very pleasing crafting system, and not graphics. Visually it’s no more than fine, though the magic effects when you’re hurling combinations of the four elements at doomed enemies are quite enjoyable. That said, strangely often I found myself entering a building with windows that was lit (poorly) by torches despite the bright sunlight outside.

Another thing the game is not about, though, is hand-holding. If your favourite flavour of RPG involves a linear story, signposted waypoints and a clear route from start to end via an engaging story, Divinity: Original Sin will not make your 2014. Too often you are left wondering which NPC you haven’t spoken to yet to push things on, trying each one in turn until you’re finally given a clue to one of the (well-written) storylines. It can be quite frustrating if you’re not interested in gradually levelling up and heading off out into the wilds, because without levelling up you will soon find out which of your group is Barry.

Ultimately the key to this game is its freedom. If you’re happy to explore an open world, crafting, looting and delving into the often-excellent game mechanics, this game will delight you. If you’re looking for a serious, story-driven RPG, the narrative of Divinity: Original Sin is unlikely to hold your attention for long enough to justify the purchase. It almost seems to want to be a solo (and co-op) MMO, with its depth and flexibility but without the never-ending concern of “other people”.

Divinity: Original Sin belongs in that curious time between Baldur’s Gate and World of Warcraft, having vastly improved on the former but been, in some senses, neutered by the latter and the genre it helped popularise. As a single-player game, Divinity: Original Sin is almost certainly better than most WoW-type fantasy games, but without a coherent, easy-to-follow storyline it straddles the divide a little unsuccessfully.

VERDICT: Granted, even among its many improvements, Divinity: Original Sin Enhanced Edition is not a perfect experience, but it sure is unique. It’s a grand adventure that rewards those who are patient enough to wade through some of the less polished aspects with incredibly rich dialogue, a huge world to affect and explore and much more besides.

My Rating: 8.9/10

reviewText: Don't let Divinity: Original Sin's grim title and poster fool you -- this is a charming CRPG that is absolutely bursting with personality. The dialog and situations are often hilarious, and the turnbased combat -- while challenging -- is ridiculously fun. Your choices matter and the game frequently encourages you to really think about consequences and how to solve problems, whether it be a troublesome NPC that you'd prefer not to murder or a pesky foe that just won't go down.\n\nRegarding the new Enhanced Edition -- I'm still fairly early into it, but it already feels like a major improvement over the original release. Between the extra polishing, performance improvements, and new features, the game feels much more finished". In particular

reviewText:
One of the very few games that I couldn't tear myself away from, and immediately as I finished the first playthrough began and finished a second playthrough.  I normally don't even play games like this, but it was awesome.  This is a must buy for anyone who plays videogames.

You like Civ type games? Great, it's turn based/tactical
You like action RPGS? Great, even though it's turn based it's very smooth and the action animations are awesome.  Also, spell combos (exploding fire+poison for example) are super cool.
You like story-based RPGs?  Archetypal, yet still great story.  Individual character stories really good as well.
You like FPS?  Well, at least you can kill stuff and blow stuff up.
You a loot ♥♥♥♥♥? love crafting?  I played twice and still havent even scratched the surface.
You like controller based games? Awesome/native controller support.  I frequently switched between the 2.

Buy it!!

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin (Enhanced Edition) is essentially, a revised version of Divinity: Original Sin (Classic). The game's interface has been simplified, the gameplay has subtly been altered and the game input has been optimized for use with a controller. In addition, new game difficulty settings have been added. Those are some key changes to the game. While those may not seem like a big deal, it drastically changes the feeling of the game. Realistically, by playing this version you're getting the console port version of the game but with pc's strong visual options.

What is Divinity: Original Sin? Divinity: Original Sin is a beautiful role playing game featuring strategic turned based party combat in an imaginative medieval setting, all while introducing you to a unique dual-dialouge system between 2 heroes you create at the beginning of the game and play through the game with.

What is a Dual-Dialogue" System? Imagine playing the game as 2 characters
date: you prioritize one character as your main character
recommended: so you think for him/her and make decisions for them on their behalf but there is what makes it different from other role playing games - your secondary character has a say in your choices
hoursPlayed: they can agree with you or disagree with you and if they disagree with you
voteText:
then that choice can change the out come of the quest or the storyline as a whole. You cannot control them but they may change the mind of an npc for example which may make you angry. So think of it as simulating playing co-op with a real human and being able to communicate with them on making choices throughout the game's timeline. Similar to old school dungeons and dragons pen and paper games in that respect.

I feel that is one of the game's main selling features as it makes the game very unique.

The graphics of Divinity: Original Sin are beautiful
helpfulPercent: it's a modern looking rpg with an old soul and it reflects on the art style it possesses. I love Larian for this.\n\nA stealth element. The game features alot of sneaking
votesHelpful: lock-picking and diversions. I found it very entertaining to find I could enter a shop with one character
votesTotal: start a conversation with the shop owner and while in mid-conversation
votesFunny:
switch to the other character and sneak in to steal weapons and other items because the shop owner was distracted.  Small things like this make me really enjoy this game.

The combat is difficult but fair. You must think about your moves ahead of time of you want to survive. Know when to preserve energy or run.

The storyline doesn't take itself to seriously
commentsCount: there are animals to talk to and alot of moments that might make you laugh out loud. There is alot of depth here though.\n\nThis game features crafting. You can craft items such as different kinds of arrows. So if you are a lovecraftian
column16: you will feel at home here. But don't worry you don't HAVE to craft there is tons of items already in the game as well.\n\nTo close this review before I keep talking about how great this game is all morning long
column17: this game has everything you might want from a western rpg
column18: mixing modern gameplay aesthetics wiith old-school traits of the genre as well. It's a great game I think any rpg fan will enjoy!\n\nThis review was based on the current build of Divinity: Original Sin (Enhanced Edition). I got this edition as a free upgrade from my purchase of Divinity: Original Sin (Classic) - before the enhanced edition released. So I have this edition installed on my Alienware Alpha and the Classic version installed on my Primary Desktop PC."

reviewText:
So, I'm the kind of gamer that jumps around from game to game struggling to settle on one title for very long. Divinity: Original Sin has captivated my heart. I spent four hours last night wandering through the first town talking to the town's people listening to their stories, helping where I could.

The combat is significantly more tactical than I would have expected and is surprisingly fun (I usually play fast paced games).

This game has opened up a new genre to me, and I'm loving it.

I created my main characters in the likeness of my wife and myself, which is pretty awesome itself, and it adds a sense of ownership.

My favorite moment up until now has been arguing with my in-game" wife about the life of a chicken and losing.

10/10- would lose argument to "real" as well as "in-game" wife again."

reviewText:
Pros:
- Great game design.
- Beautifully crafted world with a competent graphics engine.
- Great soundtrack.
- Combat is highly tactical and multifaceted. Planning and having a variety of strategies matter. (I recommend playing on Tactician Mode)
- Profound character creation, that actually matters in gameplay.
- Dialogue choices (sometimes) matter and help build character traits.
- Humour and pop-culture references.
- Lots of secrets.

Matters of taste:
- Very unforgiving to: Inexperienced RPG-players. Unskilled tacticians. People with bad dice rolls. Those who can't properly use Google as a last life-line. People who bought a keyboard without the F5 and F9 buttons. Sufferers of amnesia.
- Slow, sometimes painfully slow. A beverage or friend to accompany you through some parts of the game is highly recommended.
- A bit too few in combat" tracks.
- Arhu is ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere.

Cons:
- Repetitive character auto-reactions to world effects. ("Feeling a bit hot under the collar!" "On the mend!" "What a deluge!" etcetera)
- Unnecessarily slow animations and queuing outside of combat.
- A little too uninformative quest log.
- Some quests/parts of quests are downright uninteresting.
- As with any game of any publisher
date: a few bugs here and there."

reviewText:
I've played through this game twice so far, once when it came out and again in Enhanced Edition, both times in 100% co-op.

I have to say that the second playthrough was pretty fun. Knowing how to game the system, craft really powerful items and create a well balanced party that can smash through obstacles is pretty fun. The last boss just completely folded like a wet noodle in just over one turn of combat (it would've been less than a turn, but alas we cast some buffs that we didn't need). I had a particular amount of fun carrying a stack of oil and poison barrels in my characters inventory and throwing them out at bosses before/at the start of fights so that my ally could blow them up with meteors. KABOOM.

The 'Enhanced Edition' doesn't change much for most of the game, but does spruce up the ending quite a bit. And it's free anyhow, so what are you even complaining about? Unfortunately however, the game's approach to making puzzles is not enhanced. It's still 'go find this stupid switch that we hid between six levers' or whatever. Ugh. No thanks.

In any case, I'm quite looking forward to the sequel with it's competitive questing business. That will take a bit stronger storytelling than what they've been doing though. The story is already hard to follow with two people plugging along at different rates. I can't imagine how confusing it'd get when everyone's trying to kill each other or what have you.

But well, that's something for the future.  For now, this is a good game that people should play.

reviewText:
Great game. The story is ok. The combat system and character progression are very satisfying.

Main downside i experienced is enemy AI (or rather the lack thereof). It makes no sense that an enemy archer would cc 1 of my summons and then attack another summon in the same turn, while a way more dangerous character of mine is standing right next to it. Things like this really reduce difficulty a lot even on tactician and honour mode. Also a lot of non-combat skills are completely pointless, lockpicking or telekenesis for example.

However these were but minor grievances in a thoroughly enjoyable experience. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's.

8.5/10

reviewText: I didn't realize it from the reviews, but this game is pretty much the closest you'll get to D&D: The Videogame while still having nice visuals and production value. It gives you so many options for everything because everything has interactions with everything else. You can light oil on fire, carry an entire loot-filled chest in your inventory until you can find lockpicks, spend hours talking to NPCs in town, or kill literally everyone you see. It's also one of the few turn-based games in which multiplayer is actually enjoyable. If you like having a lot of freedom, give this game a look.

reviewText:
7 out of 10, but moments of brilliance too.

Epic Pro: It is the first game to truly feel like a 2016 modern version of Baldur's Gate 2, which is awsome.

Huge Con:  The combat is easy once you figure it out.  Spells dominate to a fault. Combat looks more complicated than it is, sorry to say it. In Divine" it is all about elemental resistences and that's basically it.

Notable Con:  Oh my god the crafting is a nuisancce.  You often get minor enhancement for too much trouble.    Everything about the crafting system needs the heave-ho.

Con:  Pickpocketing and stealing is tedious and often pointless.  Needs the heave-ho or a drastic change."

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition is one of the best RPGs you can get.

POSITIVE:
- Complex (but not complicated) skill system.
- Handcrafted, detailed world with many dungeons and different locations.
- Well written quests.
- Quests are actually FUN to do. (No boring fetch quests)
- Characters are interesting, talk a lot.
- Chalenging turn-based combat.
- Nice story.
- Loads of jokes and interesting dialogues.
- Clases do not matter, you can create any hybrid-build you like.
- No DLCs milking you for more cash.
- Very useful journal that will point you to right direction. It is your best friend.
- Books are enjoyable and sometimes needed to read.
- Interesting elements mechanics (fire, water, poison, etc..)
- Nice graphics, well optimalised engine.
- Creators DO actually listen to their fans.
- No quest arrow.
- Crafting system is very nice.
- Game is very long and well worth your money.

Negative:
- Game is not very noob-friendly, it is a bit overwhelming at the start.
- You will need to read a few Beginners guide" or "tips and tricks" before you can really enjoy this game.

Other than that

reviewText:
What a fun game! My and friend and I got this game to have a nice long co-op adventure. We play together online, and it has been a blast. The online co-op system works great, and it's easy to invite using steam. We each were in the same character creator when we started the game, and its been a bro force adventure ever since.

Its easy to loose hours and hours of time in this game, and it feel like a very rewarding expirence. It's great to find a game like this that isn't an MMO, and where your decisions matter.

Gameplay is solid, and there is loads of story in a deep, mostly open world to explore. Progress in this game is slow but well done. There is no grinding to level up, or fighting respawning enemies. Each battle is new and different, and you gradually level up as you progress.

Its create to watch your characters become stronger and more powerful than you ever planned. You can start choosing a path for your characters (you have more than one to play around with) and spec for some amazing builds, or respec mid way as the nature of your battles is changing.

I couldn't understate this game. If you are looking for a great RPG with solo and co-op potential, and you want some classic genre jokes, try this game out.

reviewText: This game is worth every penny. The devs are setting a great example of how to support a game well after its release. This new Enhanced Edition is fantastic, and all the little imperfections are quickly being patched out. The graphics are top notch, the gameplay is fun like Baldur's Gate, and the setting is very intriguing. Some classic RPG themes and humor make the whole thing quite appealing. My only real gripe is the sound. Devs, you spent all this time giving me this nice, crisp ambient sound, and fantastic musical score, why do you then have to jar me with this sudden change to harsh scary music as soon as a battle begins? Please, PLEASE can you make it so there is an option to disable battle music" ?"

reviewText:
Beautiful Game // Amazing RPG Experience
+ Interesting characters with well-thought out and meaningful dialogue, of which there is plenty
+ Overall fantastic voice acting and outstanding soundtrack
+ Beautiful graphics all around, in addition to running very well (at least on my machine)
+ Thoughtful and engaging questing with often interesting and unique mechanics
+ While visually unimpressive, the game's character customization offers an immense variety of completely different character paths and abilities
+ Well-designed and graspable loot and gear system
+ Character decisions affect the game world in a profound way, altering the environment and NPC interactions in a meaningful and game-changing way
+ While not anything to write home about, the story is fairly engaging, and the lore behind the world is certainly interesting
+ Authentic and classical turn-based combat system, incorporating both battlefield environments and NPC statuses into a complex but easily learnable strategic system that is challenging and rewarding all the same
+ Difficulty levels are sound throughout the game, offering a true challenge, and making even the most seemingly regular of encounters possibly dangerous fights (and it's adjustable, too)
+ Intercharacter interaction adds to the overall roleplaying qualities of the game, and the wide variety of skills and gear choices allows your characters to assume true and unique identities
+ Co-op is very well executed and a blast to play
+ Plenty of easter eggs and references to be found throughout the game
+ Enhanced Edition offers clear and logical improvements and alterations to core mechanics, story quirks, and bugs that only enchance the experience

- Although having no quest markers is, in my opinion, a good mechanic, the game is often too cryptic both with its dialogue and journal system, and very rarely quite frustrating
- Repetitive character reactions to the environment, meaning your characters will be saying the same things in the same situations quite a bit
- Bartering, crafting, and gear management are a bit clunky
- The complex systems of dialogue, character progression, and battle mechanics could be better explained, and the tsunami of information presented to the new user might seem overwhelming
- Story and game progression (levelling) feel very slow at times
- Some animations are far too slow
- No end game content, as the story finishes and the game is over

Overall, Divinity: Original Sin Enchanced Edition is an amazing experience, and a fitting homage to the classics of the genre. The game is fantastic in almost all of its executions, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a great game, even at full price.

reviewText:
Imagine Origin Systems circa 1992 just after the release of Ultima 7. It's a magical game and every day after school, you rush through your homework before sitting down in front of the computer screen and losing yourself in the world of Brittania. Continue to let your mind dream, and picture a world where Origin didn't fritter it away - all that tremendous creative energy, soul, and beauty. That imaginary company would have eventually created a game like Divinity Original Sin.

It is a very long game that manages the rare accomplishment of being fun the entire way through, even for veterens who often get that been-there-seen-that feeling.

If you like fantasy RPGs, or tactical combat, or co-op, or any combination of those three genres in the slightest, you should get this.

reviewText:
So I just finished playing through Divinty:OS EE, and my final thoughts upon finishing this game are Thank god it's over". But I can explain how I got to this stage of complete agony when trying to finish the game. Divinity utterly fails at making the UI a pleasant experience at playing the game. Furthermore the game makes astounding choices that make you question if anyone in the development process asked WHY ARE WE DOING THIS.
So to start things off I'll say some things that Divinity does that makes zero sense to me.

-There's no quick trading
If you have a ton of ingredients or items to trade to your OTHER character you have to move them ONE ITEM AT A TIME.
This is completely ridiculous to say the least
date:
BUT the more astounding thing is that the game actually has a system in place to automatically move quest items from one characters inventory to the character that needs it. In other words? There is absolutely NO reason to ever have two seperate inventories like they've done in the game. Inventories should be "magically linked" 24/7 and capacity combined from the characters.

-Healing after combat
This is one that I think gets ruined for me after playing The Last Remnant. See the concept is that in TLR you fight every battle like it's your last battle so you are FULL HEALED after every combat. Divinity decided that you should be forced to heal yourself after every fight
recommended:
which makes sense IF there was a system that worked around this. The problem is kinda covered w/NO MANA so skills can be used freely outside of combat to heal. However this takes hours because of the cooldowns. There's food that can be used as well which has no cooldown and can heal decently. But THE BEST HEALING can be done FOR FREE in a bed next to most Waypoints. So let me just ask if it makes more sense to either
A) Fully Heal the Party after every Fight
or
B) TP to a Waypoint and go lay down in beds to fully heal which takes a grand total of 2 minutes every time
When they both achieve the same objective which is HAVING A HEALED PARTY. Neither of them cost anything except for the second option which is a COMPLETE WASTE OF TIME.
PLEASE DEVS DONT DO THIS AGAIN FOR THE SEQUEL.
Either make Inns and Spells cost mana (which means healing COSTS something forcing the player into making choices about when to go back) or completely heal the party after combat
hoursPlayed:
there's no inbetween.

-No Mana
Kind of covered previously but skills cost no mana in the game. Everything runs off AP in combat so outside of combat everything can be used freely as long as it's off cooldown. This seems like a good idea
voteText: and quite frankly I enjoy the thought of it. But to be quite frank
helpfulPercent: it made more problems than it fixed. Mage characters in the game easily benefit over this kind of stuff where spells could be used right before the fight breaks out at no negative to the player since nothing was wasted. The spell was cast and the player has no mana or ap loss since it was considered to be cast 'outside of combat'.\nThere is synergy that exists in this game which is beyond cool
votesHelpful: but the problem is that the pay off for these synergies is waaaaay too much. These synergies (mostly the poison cloud explosion) do FAR too much damage and can be done even with grenades. I was able to kill most large mobs in a single turn with this combination
votesTotal: and it just felt cheap. Master level mage classes can do large AoE spells like Earthquake
votesFunny: Hailstorm
commentsCount:
etc which also do copious amounts of damage. I get that mages would probably be weaker towards the late game but that's why spells should more heavily weigh off of the Int. level of the character.

-Invisibility and How it ruins the Game
You can go invisible and steal anything just sitting around without worry. A max leveled pickpocket can go to town with invisibility and bleed everyone dry. I was sitting on 200k gold when I finished my playthrough. There was literally nothing I could have bought to spend this money.

-Leandra
I don't know if this was the enhanced edition only or what
column16: but the fight begins with Leandra surrounded by 4 Void Knights and Three demons. The fight begins by the three demons casting THREE INVULNERABILITY AURAS one of which goes to Leandra. I immediately off one of the demons and two rounds later (when the invulnerability wears off)
column17:
the remaining two demons PLACE THE INVULNERABILITY AGAIN. I kill the next demon and yet again the process continues. Finally all of the demons are dead and I can go for the boss! NOPE. Physical Immunity aura and eventually places an elemental immunity aura as well. Now the problem with this fight was that it was entirely wasting your time. For 8 turns you have to sit there with characters being COMPLETELY INVULNERABLE. Now this makes no sense to me because the Void Aura is supposed to be able to get hit through as long as the character has a tenebrium weapon. WHICH DIDNT WORK. I had a weapon that required Tenebrium skill lvl 2 which APPARENTLY doesn't count as Tenebrium. Irremovable invulnerability is never a fun option to a fight. Especially not when this is one of three fights IN A ROW that you have to do at the end of the game.

-Crafting System and Blacksmithing
The crafting system at times makes absolutely no sense and Blacksmithing is simply worthless because you'll never make an item that's halfway decent. Seriously go look up the crafting recipes online
column18: google Divinity crafting for a .pdf file that will be the first option. You can make fish pies

column21: and cheese bread from dough but CANNOT make a pumpkin pie. At first I was willing to go along with it until I realized how asinine the recipes were. A jar of mud combined with a fiery heart makes the most OP weapon in the game
column22:
a sword of planes. Take THAT blacksmithing.

-Identifying and Repairing
Merchants/Player don't have a Repair All or Identify All button. I don't know why.

-Perception
There is no reason this game should rely so heavily on this. It just feels cheap. If you don't level it you'll get stuck with no answers until you read online that your perception should be 10. You buff it to 10 and proceed on. There's only negatives to keeping this around.

-Puzzles
The puzzles were mostly for children which was the the practice of put the cylinder through the cylinder hole concept. When the game didn't rely on this
column23:
it instead quickly shifted to tiny buttons that are hard to see or find in large rooms. Tiny buttons are not puzzles.

-Teleport Pyramids
While I thought initially they were a neat idea
column24:
I quickly realized that it was a cheap fix or free puzzle item for the devs.  When in doubt get the puzzle to somehow incorporate leaving one character behind and having to use the pyramid to bring them back. Also I thought I would be fancy and leave a pyramid in an area I wanted to quickly return to. But apparently the devs think I'm stupid so the pyramid would get teleported into my inventory if I left it (Waypoint travel). This makes no sense to me BECAUSE as long as you have one of the pyramids it's absolutely impossible to lose the other one. I thought that was the point of the pyramids but I GUESS NOT.

-The First Town
Too close to the start
column25:
players enter and are given too much to do in the town which results in not leaving for a few hours.

Bugs
-Enemies just stare in combat and waste your time (The Fix? Combat skip to YOUR turn.)
-Icara (An essential NPC) died during one of the final bouts
column26: her dead corpse kept teleporting to me but I had no way to revive her. I easily killed the boss in two rounds without this NPC
column27: but it also affected the Ending where I was unable to ask Zandalor what happened to the Sisters
column28:
BECAUSE she was dead and I was never given an option to fix the Soul Forge.

I had more to say but WORD LIMIT
tl;dr It's okay but not a 9/10 game. Expect a 6/10 at best.
In 2-4 hours I was impressed
column29: after 20-30 hours I was annoyed.\nRecent games must be awful for this to be amazing."

reviewText: Fantastic game! A great throwback to old school RPG pc. This Game does NOT hold your hand... You need to read everything incase you miss something important, and check all the corners. I lost count of how many times i was well and truly stumped at what to do next.. Until i spoke to a damn rat that gave me a clue or something like that. It reminded me of being a kid again really enjoying games because of this reason (thankfully we have the internet for help now when desperate).\nThe gameplay is fun, you have so many ways to go about doing anything that even the most simple of solutions seem sometimes way too obvious to do.\nSlow turnbased combat isn't for everyone, So if you don't like it don't bother getting this game.  Every single person/creature is brilliantly voice acted too, it really draws you in and is very addicting... Only downside is i wish there was a way to cause a delay on the background chatter.. It's nonstop repetition with no wait time (Highly annoying!)

reviewText:
If you've played the first Original Sin, there are things are most welcome and some that may put you off at first.

First off, they've updated inventory management and that gold is shared between the party. This was a huge pain the the Original Sin since each character basically had their own gold purse. Furthermore, the interface for crafting has been overhauled as well, leaning more on drag 'n drop for convenience.

New is also game modes, which replaces the regular mode in Original Sin with something they call  Classic Mode. If you want harder difficulties, Honour mode is what you're after. There's also tactician mode and some others. There are more quests to dive into as well, along with some new abilities and the like.

Enhanced edition also bring full voice acting to the table, which is for the most part great. However, my only gripe with this game is that the enhanced edition has replaced some of the iconic voices of the first Original Sin with new voice actors that don't suit the tone of the game too well. The cheese vendor for instance, one of the NPC dudes you'll hear the most, has been switched out from the Original Sin. The excuses for switching him out, has more holes in it than a slice of a fine gorgombert.

Don't like cheese? That excuse has more holes than this fine slice of Gorgombert!"

"
