reviewText:
There's been a steady trickle of CRPGs into my library since I discovered the wonders of fair, honest download services like GoG and Steam and a litany of beloved JRPGs from designers learnéd in the hows and whys of CRPG possibility to their own heritage before that (tri-Ace, Ikahara, Megaten, Lord Miyazaki, Lord Matsuno), but this year that rivulet turned into a deluge and riding along with this wave of gaming goodness is the CRPG talk of 2014:

Divinity: Original Sin.

Larian's infamous forced march into gamestyles they had no business dabbling with and away from their strengths are gone here; the AP-utilizing combat is sublime, a beautiful toolbox of ♥♥♥♥ to play with, and constantly throws you nasty new curveballs to force your mastery of said toolbox. Excellent quest design that has you thinkin' and searchin' instead of the Honey Do list grind that most RPGs got fascinated in. Fun loot system that ain't afraid to toss you powerful but narrowing playthings to build a character towards. A classy, table-top looking art direction that is stylish and distinct, a magnificent dreamlike and daring OST by one Kirill Pokrovsky, and alot of neat dialogue between the two Guardians and major NPCs that doesn't get enough love due to its cheeky nature. Co-op play in a narrative-heavy game that pulls it off! There is so much STUFF in this game to do and earn.

There are a few problems with this gem, befitting a talented developer just now getting to stretch their legs; outside of that conversation listed above, some of it is drab and mechanical, almost as if the character themselves weren't speaking, but the writer themselves dropping that information (if that makes any sense). There are bugs that crash to desktop months in. You can also tell the KS cash didn't go far enough and got stretched thin (noticable but not necessarily bad since it means more of that sweet sweet fightin').

reviewText:
I don't review games, I usually read reviews. Only have 2 hours put into this game, can safely tell you that I'm going to beat the crap out of this more than a few times. Should the slightest boredom come around, I will attempt muitiplayer which I heard is a beast on its own.

This game took the life force out of so many other great games, and made itself an abnomination, a true work of art! It took me 2 hours to examine the beginning of the game! Just to pick up shells on the beach and look through a tomb evil doers came out of! Not because I suck at games, heck no, but when I find a game I want to truely digest, I SCAN every square inch!!! IF you are a player like me that likes to examine carefully and enjoy a true tactical adventure, then buy this game, its probably one of the best $40 you threw at steam. Well, considering you are a RPG fan.

Playing this game I felt the prescence of many other games. Clearly, one of the developers paid attention to all the GOODS of games that were already made! I felt like I was playing Diablos, older Fallouts, Dungeon Dragons Baldurs gate or similar, XCOM, Dungeon Siege, Torchlights, heck the dialoge systems is richer than Mass effect. The point is, it took the souls that made these other games what they are, and made itself what it is. It gives no quarter for your complaints.

This is the kind of game that made me wish I was 13 again, no responsibilities, no work, barely any home work. I would play the crap out of this. $40 aint nothing in a life time! So please, instead of listening to someone like me, who don't write reviews, ramble like crazy, buy it!!

reviewText: I wanted to buy this game earlier, but decided to wait because I was intrigued by the Enhanced Edition and all the overhauling they have done. This game is not really a regular enhanced edition or remaster, it is a massively overhauled version of the award-winning 2014 RPG and Gamespot's PC Game of the Year 2014. What I loved about this is the fact that it's a publicly funded game by an indie dev, which means that it literally has no limits in terms of content. No crappy publisher-restrictions are there to hold them back like EA, Ubisoft or other Triple A devs/publishers. This reminds me of what CD Projekt did. Keep it up guys, looking forward to DOS 2.

reviewText:
Holy crap what can we say about this marvelous adventure and effort to bring it to consoles/additional content/controller support?!

One of the first things you'll notice, is that EVERY npc interaction is now fully voiced whereas beforehand only major characters were voiced (leaving the game feeling rather empty perhaps though it was supported by excellant writing).  All of that is now still there and it's certainly nice even interacting with a fish vendor or other minor entity that it has it's own voice.  Fantastic!  That alone would be worth buying the enhanced addition.

Quests have been reworked so they are more streamlined and additional quests have been added.  I was playing along the first major quest noticing a quest item had been moved here or there but it was essentially the same storyline.  Happy to report that keyboard and mouse working just fine - and PC demands were performing better with no visual hitching or bugs that I noticed.  I am not running the game on a 'state of the art machine' 12GB of DDR3 Ram, Quad Core Processor and only 1 GTX 680 (the other one died haven't bothered to replace it); so overall performance is optimized pretty damn well.

Next, after 2/3 of the way through the main first storyline (Mysterious Murdur) I plugged my controller in - a 360 controller and was immediately detected with a tutorial starting up as things came up to show how to interact with the world using it.  I found the transition seemless.  The radial menus are easy to navigate, and became intuitive after an hour or so.  Navigating inventory, a somewhat annoying task with mouse/keyboard I found to be a bit easier though you can certainly flip from mouse/keyboard and back to controller easily enough (ingame keybind) so choose which way you want to play.  Personally I found that sitting back and moving my team around using a controller much easier as I've often lately grown tired of clicking around etc so its nice to sit back on my couch thus using my 360 Controller.

Is this game worth a buy then?  It was with the unenhanced version and well, it certainly is now.  So what are you wating for?  I would buy this if you like RPGs, its a fantastic game with hours and hours of gameplay.  The added voice content and controller support offering more ways to play a great game.

reviewText: Enhanced Edition as a title fails for what Larian did this to game. These aren't just new textures, or models. It plays like a whole new game. I think that Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition should be an example of how other RPG games should work. If you are looking for a fun co-op game to play online, or in your living room look no further. Co-op gameplay is seamless and fun. They have really built co-op into the story mechanics, as much as they have the gameplay. If you are looking for a long game, this is supposedly 100 hours of content. I don't believe that, because I've spent almost 50 hours and I am not even halfway. (No, I haven't been dying constantly.) Between the sidequests, puzzles, combat, the main story, and the crafting you will spend well over 100 hours on this game. I commend Larian studios for their incredible attention to detail, and their love for the game is shown in the work they put into it. Looking forward to Divinity 2.

reviewText:
Turn-based RPG games have had a terrific revival this last year, not least spearheaded by this marvellous title from Larian. I played Divinity II a few years ago, which was a small budget but fairly decent title also from Larian, so it really is no surprise that they managed something quite remarkable with a stronger, crowd-funded budget. I hope they keep this level for the next release as well!

The game revolves around dual protagonists with one optional companion each, so a group of 2 - 4. The RPG system is kinda new but easily recognizable by seasoned veterans of the genre. There's a lot of fun to be had with the way elements interact and a lot of interesting choices to be made in the levelling system. Mastering the game takes thought and experience but playing the game is easy and intuitive in itself.

The story is fun, nothing THAT special narratively, but the true quality is in the telling. Humorous, colourful, varied and sometimes outright dark, it comes together nicely in the end. Lots of little details to explore and combat is very rarely repetitive. It revolves a lot around the four elements and how they interact mixed with some crowd-controlling abilities, buffs and debuffs from other lines (do NOT ignore these if you play on a difficult setting!). The only problem I encountered was that I often mess around with different classes and ideas on a difficult setting while I learn the game mechanics well enough to create my exact party concept. In this game, there is a bit of a lull early on in the game with a lot of story-driven gameplay which can be a bit tedious to replay seven times before you get the party balance right. Apart from that, this game is just quite simply excellent. If you're into RPG games at all, you should definitely check out this title.

reviewText:
Awesome game with a great number of tactical choices, using the environment and mixing right elements to aid you in battle. The two new difficulty settings seems like a great addition, going through tactician mode now. Enemies actually seems to work more with logic, using things better to their advantage.

There is some puzzles here and there also, some of them not so straightforward and requires some thinking. Dialogues are all spoken, even the animals.

Crafting is also quite good, with it you can experiment different combinations and might just craft someting nice. Skillbooks and scrolls are also craftable if you find them blank. There are also recipes that you learn from books.

If you like turnbased combat, saving throws, rpg's then this game is absolutely worth looking into.

reviewText:
Played this on local co-op all the way through, it was brilliant. It's got some of my favourite aspects of an RPG:

- Total customisation: custom classes, freedom to use any skill, build any build, can equip anything you want as long as you have the stats. Completely original.
- Strategic turn-based battle: it almost plays like D&D -- you plan out what you want to do, you communicate with your co-op partner, plus a bit of randomness like a die roll as you confirm and see what happens. Sometimes hilarious.
- Quest decisions: multiple ways to finish quests, your characters gain traits and bonuses depending on your roleplaying actions throughout the game.
- Fun stealth aspect. Not essential but it was fun sneaking around, pickpocketing, lockpicking.
- Great writing, voice acting and art. It's got a sense of humour and quirky writing. The in-game graphics IMO much better than that ugly anime-ish cover/splash page. Literally every NPC line is voice-acted, and done well. The amount of voice acting is on the level of Oblivion or Skyrim.

The main storyline is a very slow burn. Even at about 20 hours in, you're still kind of not sure what's going on, but it's simply so fun exploring, collecting loot, selling loot, levelling, that you don't even care.

This game really surprised me by how fun it was and how much depth there is. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good RPG, especially fans of old-school D&D-style RPGs.

Play it with a mate or a bae :)

reviewText:
One of the best cRPG of all time.

But wait I'm not even finished with the above statement, mot only this is one of the best cRPG of all time, this game can also be clasified as one of the best turn based game of all time when you entered the combat part of this game.

Wait there is more, after playing this game, I can't help playing other western medieval fantasy game without thinking why can't I simply cast a poison spell on my enemies and then explode them with fire combo? Or make them slip on their feet while trying to chase me across an ice surface I laid down before them on the battlefield? Those environmental/elemental effects during battle in this game is nothing short of revolutionary especially in cRPG and TBS genre and should make us wonder why something like that hasn't been done before?

Aside from that the RPG mechanics on this game is quite simple and addicting, things like leveling, crafting or quests are good enough although not stellar

2 main downsides are the lack of in depth guidance in this game regarding those mechanics and the quests; number two is that the writing and story telling are just mediocre

reviewText:
This game is one of the better RPGs I've played in a long time. I give it a 7/10; this number would be even higher if it were not for the one flaw I find with the game - too many puzzles. Now that the one and only con has been stated (which can be mitigated should you decide to use walkthroughs), here is a list of a bunch of pros:

--Combat 10/10: One of the best turn based combat systems yet. It mixes an old familiar feel from early RPGs like Fall Out and Arcanum (using turn points) with an original take on using attributes to effect your turn points. Of course the usual things like constitution still gives hit points and things like that, but I feel the entire stat system as it pertains to combat is perfectly balanced.

--Story 6/10: Ok so the story isn't the best, but it isn't bad either. It certainly keeps you involved. It has two draw backs - its slow to start, and the other I won't say for minor spoiler sake.

--Graphics 8/10: I mean, its a turn based rpg.... so don't expect anything like skyrim. But compared to everything else in its game-group, its at least as good.

Overall, its well polished and worth playing. Would teleport a rabit into a lava pit again.

reviewText:
The game opens with the Larian studios logo, an image of a  stern looking warrior who is playfully popped in the head with a sucker arrow (is that what they are called?). This is a perfect analogy for divine divinity original sin. At base, its a really strong RPG with great combat mechanics and multi-layered story line involving the very destruction of time and space.

Despite this, the game manages a blanket of humour that's just enough to stop the game taking itself too seriously and subtle enough not to undermine the core game. Visuals, voice acting and game stability are all first rate and the developers continue to give up dates well after the games initial release date. Original sin is a obvious labour of love and all that time and attention shows. My personal complaints about the game are small and could even be seen as nitpicking but i wanted to share all my thoughts. Crafting feels unsatisfying and unnecessary, i wanted to explore this aspect of the game but was continually turned off after a minute or so of trying to involved. Loot, there is way too much loot. After every fight and even chest discovery i found myself constantly comparing my new find to the gear i have on. It seems every 5 mins of gameplay brings the potential of an upgrade. I didn't like this for two reasons, it breaks the immersion of the world and compelling story line i am engaged in and two, legendary items don't feel legendary, the feel common place. Lore master is also a little immersion breaking. Everything you get an item you need to find it in your backpack, right click to identify item then begin the comparison to your current gear i previously mentioned, it would be much more efficient if it just proc'ed naturally.

Despite these minor flaws  divinity is one of the greatest story driven RPG's of all time. Even the companions have compelling stories that reveal themselves over time and time in well with the main plot. The isometric RPG could be seen as played out but Larian have breathed enough fresh ideas into it that it feels like an advanced step in the games style rather than a mere throwback. The duel main character aspect was particularly refreshing. If you are sitting on the fence then i urge you to give this game a try. There is plenty bang for your buck and virtually none of it feels like filler. 9/10

reviewText:
This is easily one of the best games I have ever played.  Let's go over pro's and cons

1. Co-op. As a man that searches for games to play with his wife I love this idea. Couch co-op or online. It's seemless at sharing the same screen as well for great splitscreen gameplay. It also makes it easy to share dialogue options with two players and to quest together. We had so much fun together.
2. Visually beautiful. This game has a wonderfully colorful pallette.
3. Amount of gameplay time. The amount of content makes this game easily worth $100 and yet it goes for something like $40. A great value.
4. Storyline- Wow. Just wow. A multiply layered story with many stories interweaving in one another. Fantastic.
5. Voice Acting and Music- Beautiful music and great voice overs.
6. Combat- fun turn based combat that uses the elements well.
7. Beautiful and varied enviroments.
8. Great controller support

Cons
1. The monster designs wtih a few exceptions (Bracchus Rex, Trife, the undeead mini bosses), were uninspired trope fantasy stock.
2. Puzzles- Some of them I just hated. I had to actually find a stupid switch I missed.
3. Broken quest system- It's easy to miss a switch, accidently drop or lose an item, etc. Be careful not to sell or drop an item, key, or book unless you know for sure you don't need it.
4. The Mapping system makes orienting and finding your position difficult for the direction challenged such as myself.  There is no waypoint systems and the way the map movies makes finding east, west, north, south tricky. It could have been done better.

All that said. This game is so much fun, and playing hours upon hours with my wife was a great experience we both loved. I waited for the steam sale, but when they release a sequel we don't plan on waiting this time!

reviewText:
It's D&D in every way. And D&D has always been a fun and immersive experience for me.
If you've always wanted to try D&D, buy this game and play it with your friend.
You pretty much get the entire experience, from the combat to the clashing dialogue between party members.

Mages bombing party members because woops AOE.
Rogue's spending eternities setting up a backstab.
Knights and Warriors charging away from their party and dive head first into a trap.
Archers whining about their arrows running out.
Party members whining that the rogue is stealing from everyone.
Party members whining that the knight is being a no fun allowed prude in general.
Party members whining about the mage making combat insufferable.
Mage whining about not being able to do anything without killing a party member whilst the entire orc horde is foaming in the mouth over them.
Clerics being god's gift to a party.
Someone tell the rogue to stop stealing or I'm pawning off this greatsword and becoming a fisherman.

Yep, that's D&D.
Fell in love with this game.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin was incredible, and as a backer I went through my share of ups and downs.
But the Enhanced Edition? Almost perfection in game form. Welcome back, Classic RPGs!

Play-time isn't necessarily a selling factor for RPGs,
as you'd expect them to last 100+hrs, possibly double or triple that.
Something to bear in mind, however, is that I played 50hrs of
the 'Classic' Original Sin while it was still in production.
I've now played 40hrs of the Enhanced Edition, using my knowledge of
where to find the side-quests, rare items etc...

I HAVEN'T LEFT THE FIRST HUB AREA YET. Here are a few reasons why:

- As a mage & thief combo for my Main Characters, we steal, manipulate and scheme to progress.
Locks get widely ignored as we distract the guards with dialogue from one character
while the other pickpockets them, stealing the keys and infiltrating silently.
That room/treasury/armoury you're not allowed into until later? We've emptied it.

- My mage can talk to animals, which means I spend twice as much time
laughing my ♥♥♥ off at the fantastic humour, as well as getting extra quests.

- The first Hub area, Cyseal, is ENORMOUS. Overlapping quests, hidden areas,
a plethora of side-quests, distractions etc.

- The fantastic combat system keeps me entertained even in areas FAR above my level,
as I combine different elements to bully superior opponents into submission via crafted arrows, grenades, spells, ambushes and full-frontal assaults.

Tl;Dr:
Buy it.
Enjoy the hell out of it.
Worship Larian Studios as your new RPG Development Gods.
Wait for Original Sin 2.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was a kickstarter project!? It is no surprise that the Kickstarter for Original Sin 2 met its goals five times over within 12 hours.

AAA+++ production, major updates to the game on re-release and provided FREE to original owners (other developers take notes!!!)

Not only is this one of the best RPGs I have ever played but I fully support Larian Studios in their future endevaors. They listen to their community, they provide updates to year old games without trying to bilk their customers for more money, and they have made one heck of an amazing game!

PROS:
-Incredible game engine
-Excellent combat mechanics
-NON LINEAR questlines. You can complete most quests via several different methods.
-Almost ALL characters can be attacked/stolen from/killed. This can lead to a variety of methods for completing quests (although on rare occasion you might render a side quest incompletable if you kill everyone involved but this will not hinder your progress in the main story).
-LOTS of content! (My one playthrough, skipping all dialogues, was just over 80 hours).
-Solid graphics
-Solid voice acting

NEUTRALS:
-There seems to be a rich backstory, but I play mainly for the mechanics and not for the plot so I skipped all the dialogue/etc (and still spent around 80 hours for a single playthrough).

-Skill/stat distribution is in need of a complete overhaul (the EE changes did not help much):
--Primary stats are virtually useless (esp past 10 points at which point you can use all related gear).  The only worthwhile stat otherwise is Constitution for HP (or Perception for archers). Mages don't need perception since wands always have 100% hit chance.
--Skills are oddly distributed and severely lacking. Most builds will require 2 or maybe 3 skills total; you will have far more than enough skill points for this leaving a lot of leftover points with no real skills to take. FOR EXAMPLE: An archer build needs 5 bow (or xbow) and 5 marksman.....thats it. No other skill will improve the archers dps, and if you choose to take a school of magic then you are no longer shooting your bow... the only other thing is to take Lucky Charm, but even then it just gives you offense rating which only equates to CHANCE to hit (not a dps buff).
--The stat/skill/talent system is inherently fine; the problem is with the current layout of abilities and stats. The talents also need a serious overhaul, with particular focus on talents gained at skill levels 3 and 5 to promote more build variety.

***These are issues that would be a major deal in competitive multiplayer, but since D:OS 1 is a single player/coop game these issues are VERY MINOR and will hopefully be fixed for D:OS 2's competitive multiplayer component.


CONS:
-A variety of skills are far too similar, with certain classes simply being better. FOR EXAMPLE: Freezing Touch and Petrifying touch are identical skills, except Frozen" provides an addition +10 armor to the target which Petrify does not. This means petrify is better in almost all instances over frozen as a status modifier.

Instead
date: the different schools should be functionally opposites. This is well executed with Cold and Fire magic:  Frozen (unable to act
hoursPlayed: +10% fire resist) -> Chilled (same buffs as frozen) -> normal (no buffs) -> Warmed (-10% fire resist
voteText: +10 cold resist) -> Burning (DoT
helpfulPercent: -10% fire resist
votesHelpful: +10% cold resist).  The function of fire magic and cold magic is distinctly different
votesTotal: and one can negate frozen by intentionally firing/heating up the target and vice versa.\n\nUnfortunately
votesFunny:
not all schools of magic operate on this principle and consistency would go a long way (especially for competitive mp coming in the sequel).

-Blacksmithing is almost worthless.
-Crafting is boring although it does provide minor stat buffs."

reviewText:
Simply put, Extremely Satisfying!

First off the game offers so much to do and many ways to built and play your characters, Sometimes you may get lost chillin' in the city for a few hours talking to Npc's about quests and such and other times you'll be on an adventure outside the castle walls, every second fearing for your life. (Save often peoples...) The game introduces a very fun and unique conversation system, that especially shines when your playing with a friend or family member, Allowing you and your Co-op partner to make decisions on how you feel and want to do in the game world. (Even if your Co-Op partner is settled on always trolling and disagreeing with you just to start an arguement)

The combat is engaging and difficult, But not too much so. Although I will say it does matter what type of party you have set up, For instance, My party I have for my Solo playthrough is 3 different type of melee characters (One who can heal of course.) And a archer... Now, while its still fun, such a team is much harder to playthrough the game with then, I dont know, a team with only one melee character and 2 mages instead. But regardless it doesnt take away from the fun of the game.

Now for a few cons about the game... Personally I feel the game offers little in the way of actual character appearance options. You make two characters, But without being able to change your characters build what-so-ever if you make two of the same gender characters they tend to look a bit similar. Not to mention there is only 3 voices per gender and about 10 or hair style's and faces. Im not saying this is a big deal by any means, You can still make characters you'll enjoy playing, and I know alot of people would like to argue about how much your characters appearance matters in a game like this, But I honestly think the closer you can get the character to how you imagine your adventuring crew helps with immersion and feeling your characters more. Who knows, I might just be weird or something... Heh.

As for the other beef I have with this game is *Sigh* it kinda feels like your always pushed to do stuff in a certain order, No matter how much bragging goes on about the tabletop-like freedoms of the game, Simply put you will have to explore the world in somewhat" a set order. The main reason for this is because levels on this game are a big deal at times. So say you set off for a quest that seems interesting at the time to find out that the enemys are 2 or 3 levels higher
date: Well your better off just walking away and doing a different quest or finding a way to earn some experience points before going back. And honestly
recommended: even when you do complete stuff 1 or 2 higher levels than you (Which isnt easy at all) That means you 'prolly just overleveled yourself for a different quest
hoursPlayed: Taking away from the difficulty of that quest. It isnt a huge problem honestly
voteText: because you still have some choices on what to do and when

No matter how much I said about the cons the game is still overwhelmingly good. The endless ways to build your team is wonderful

votesFunny: fire magic archers or even traditional type builds like pure mages or sword and shield... Basically anything you can think of! (Just make sure you spend your attribute and skill points wisely!) The endless ways of building your team helps keep the game fresh through multiple replays

reviewText: I bought Divinity Original Sin quite awhile back on an impulse and I am incredibly glad I did. The enhanced edition only adds that much more polish to an already awesome game. In my view the best thing about this game is the combat, If your looking for RPG combat with a tactical but still modern feel look no further.\n\nWhen I originally bought Divinity OS I  had been looking for a game with turn based combat that wasen't just the same old side-view battle screen thing since I have never found that very appealing. Divinity OS provided turn-based tactical combat in a 3d world where the elements interact dynamically with each other. Want to get rid of a poison cloud? hit it with a fireball and make it explode. Enemy not flammable enough for you? douse him in a puddle of oil and light it on fire. And heaven forbid you accidentally light yourself on fire, you can have someone cast a rain spell to put you ( and everything else in a large radius) out. Simply put, It's just a tremendous amount of fun. For me it was the first RPG in decades that actually recaptured that stay-up-all-night gaming thrill I found when I was a kid, and for that I can't thank larian enough. The terrific co-op just adds that much more value to an already exceptional game. The story is interesting, even if parts of it are a little cliche, the characters are memorable, the soundtrack is, well let's say divine"
recommended: and its all pulled together by the best turn based combat experience I have ever had. Possibly the only area of the game that could have used more work is the somewhat clunky crafting system
hoursPlayed: but even that is workable.\n\nNow as far as what the Enhanced Edition brings to the table

reviewText:
Been a fan of a lot of great RPG series such as DA, PoE, etc. Bought this game on sale very recently, and decided to give it a try. Overall a very great and unique RPG game, and I don't know why I didn't give a thought earlier on.

WARNING! Contains some spoilers:
Within the first one or two hours of gameplay, I managed to complete the tutorial dungeon and the surrounding area. Had a mini boss-fight within the dungeon. Gangbanged a soldier behind one of my characters, and then froze and teleported the mini-boss skyhigh and back onto the ground 15m away from the origin. Received an arrow shot from another soldier in the next turn but he got frozen quickly afterwards and then shattered by a knight ram-kill. Only the boss left and he had decided to stand up and come for us. Within close range (when it's my turn), he was frozen and gangbanged. And he turned into ghost form. I just simply ignored the spells and skill sets and just finished him off as usual. RIP...

reviewText:
Wow. I'm not a massive turn-based RPG fan but this game really did deliver in every way.

It is difficult at the start (for a short while) if you are a bit of a noob like me but only because I didn't realise quite how tactical you need to be! Once you discover that you'll need to think about using the environment, sight lines and structures to aid you against difficult enemies, it suddenly clicks! The game is very well balanced (in normal mode - which is all I've played), and each fight could go either way if you recklessly run into a situation. It is very enjoyable and the world, characters and quests are all expertly constructed.

What I very much appreciate also is that it isn't pandering to the direction of most mainstream titles by making the combat etc a bit of a chore, rather than a challenge (e.g. Diablo 3, which did not do Diablo 2 justice in my opinion). It also actually requires you to think a bit in the puzzles and quests and gives you mutltiple options.

Divinity - Awesome game!

reviewText:
This is easily one of the best games i have played of all time.  It's been on my wishlist since before it's release and I was always hesitant about getting it.  However, after i bought it, I realized what I'd been missing the entire time.  The gameplay is reminiscent of Dark Alliance, Baulders Gate, it handles smoothly, and really brings alot of options to the table.  To tie it all together, the game has a nice atmosphere, good soundtrack, and campy humor, which really brings out the best in the gaming experience.

Pros: smooth gameplay, entertaining and challenging quests, good story, enjoyable dialogue, and visualy appealing.

Cons: Lack of inital character customization.  Every male is burly and shaped the same, and every woman is thin and attractive.  Its not a huge complaint, but when i make a rouge character i prefer a slim, more elusive frame vs the burly knight type character.

reviewText: This game is totally engrossing.  It is consuming my every waking thought.  Usually in these types of games I don't care what every NPC has to say, but in Divinity, I'm curious as to what is going to happen next.  The environment is beautiful, the story is witty and fun.  The combat is entertaining.\n\nI wouldn't consider myself a hardcore gamer and I have racked up over 50 hours in this game in just over a week.  That's insane. The only issues I have are minor, like quest direction can be somewhat vague at times and targeting in combat can sometimes change when the target moves right when you click making you move to the target instead of attacking, thereby losing your AP.  Inventory management could be a little bit better laid out, but these are all minor and don't take away from the overall experience.  Definately worth the money!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
More than a year after originally purchasing the classic edition, I got around to playing through the game on the enhanced edition. Clocking in at ~60 hours for that run, I have to say that, barring some poor design choices, this is an RPG of a quality I don't see often, high as it is.
Where it counts: in making decisions that define your character(s), in the engrossing combat mechanics and the outstanding world design, Divinity: Original Sin shines as a unique example of an RPG done right.
That said, the Diablo leanings the game has, in the inventory system most particularly, detract from what could've been an even more interesting experience. Fiddling with a massive inventory that keeps overflowing with prefixed and suffixed items, many of which aren't that good, was tedious.
Another minor bad point is the practical punishment for preparing for tough battles. The system doesn't let you down potions in advance, nor apply buffs. They don't last long enough if you initiate combat willingly. Food, it appears, under this, is useless.
But with all that said, I still enjoyed the game a whole bunch and can recommend it greatly.

reviewText:
This was a kickstarter project!? It is no surprise that the Kickstarter for Original Sin 2 met its goals five times over within 12 hours.

AAA+++ production, major updates to the game on re-release and provided FREE to original owners (other developers take notes!!!)

Not only is this one of the best RPGs I have ever played but I fully support Larian Studios in their future endevaors. They listen to their community, they provide updates to year old games without trying to bilk their customers for more money, and they have made one heck of an amazing game!

PROS:
-Incredible game engine
-Excellent combat mechanics
-NON LINEAR questlines. You can complete most quests via several different methods.
-Almost ALL characters can be attacked/stolen from/killed. This can lead to a variety of methods for completing quests (although on rare occasion you might render a side quest incompletable if you kill everyone involved but this will not hinder your progress in the main story).
-LOTS of content! (My one playthrough, skipping all dialogues, was just over 80 hours).
-Solid graphics
-Solid voice acting

NEUTRALS:
-There seems to be a rich backstory, but I play mainly for the mechanics and not for the plot so I skipped all the dialogue/etc (and still spent around 80 hours for a single playthrough).

-Skill/stat distribution is in need of a complete overhaul (the EE changes did not help much):
--Primary stats are virtually useless (esp past 10 points at which point you can use all related gear).  The only worthwhile stat otherwise is Constitution for HP (or Perception for archers). Mages don't need perception since wands always have 100% hit chance.
--Skills are oddly distributed and severely lacking. Most builds will require 2 or maybe 3 skills total; you will have far more than enough skill points for this leaving a lot of leftover points with no real skills to take. FOR EXAMPLE: An archer build needs 5 bow (or xbow) and 5 marksman.....thats it. No other skill will improve the archers dps, and if you choose to take a school of magic then you are no longer shooting your bow... the only other thing is to take Lucky Charm, but even then it just gives you offense rating which only equates to CHANCE to hit (not a dps buff).
--The stat/skill/talent system is inherently fine; the problem is with the current layout of abilities and stats. The talents also need a serious overhaul, with particular focus on talents gained at skill levels 3 and 5 to promote more build variety.

***These are issues that would be a major deal in competitive multiplayer, but since D:OS 1 is a single player/coop game these issues are VERY MINOR and will hopefully be fixed for D:OS 2's competitive multiplayer component.


CONS:
-A variety of skills are far too similar, with certain classes simply being better. FOR EXAMPLE: Freezing Touch and Petrifying touch are identical skills, except Frozen" provides an addition +10 armor to the target which Petrify does not. This means petrify is better in almost all instances over frozen as a status modifier.

Instead
date: the different schools should be functionally opposites. This is well executed with Cold and Fire magic:  Frozen (unable to act
hoursPlayed: +10% fire resist) -> Chilled (same buffs as frozen) -> normal (no buffs) -> Warmed (-10% fire resist
voteText: +10 cold resist) -> Burning (DoT
helpfulPercent: -10% fire resist
votesHelpful: +10% cold resist).  The function of fire magic and cold magic is distinctly different
votesTotal: and one can negate frozen by intentionally firing/heating up the target and vice versa.\n\nUnfortunately
votesFunny:
not all schools of magic operate on this principle and consistency would go a long way (especially for competitive mp coming in the sequel).

-Blacksmithing is almost worthless.
-Crafting is boring although it does provide minor stat buffs."

reviewText:
To put it simply I found this game to be thoroughly enjoyable in almost every single way.

What I loved:
The humor and story of the game kept me entertained throughout my play through.
The environments looked fantastic and varied.
Exploring and talking to NPCs (even the animals!) was often rewarded with a fun conversation or quest.
The combat felt great and tactician mode provided a good level of challenge for me.
Combining the elements makes combat feel dynamic.
The rpg elements are really open and allow you to diverge from your original class or mix and match any set of skills.
The puzzles were mostly interesting although I admit a few got frustrating.

What I didn't love as much:
I experienced some sound issues a few times where music or sound effects would just disappear. Reloading my save always fixed it though.
Sometimes the AI wouldn't know what to do in battle and stand there for about 10 seconds before ending their turn.
Sometimes I had some trouble selecting enemies during combat due to their idle animations.

Overall I would give it a solid 9/10 with only some minor annoyances here and there.

reviewText:
It's D&D in every way. And D&D has always been a fun and immersive experience for me.
If you've always wanted to try D&D, buy this game and play it with your friend.
You pretty much get the entire experience, from the combat to the clashing dialogue between party members.

Mages bombing party members because woops AOE.
Rogue's spending eternities setting up a backstab.
Knights and Warriors charging away from their party and dive head first into a trap.
Archers whining about their arrows running out.
Party members whining that the rogue is stealing from everyone.
Party members whining that the knight is being a no fun allowed prude in general.
Party members whining about the mage making combat insufferable.
Mage whining about not being able to do anything without killing a party member whilst the entire orc horde is foaming in the mouth over them.
Clerics being god's gift to a party.
Someone tell the rogue to stop stealing or I'm pawning off this greatsword and becoming a fisherman.

Yep, that's D&D.
Fell in love with this game.

reviewText:
Simply put, Extremely Satisfying!

First off the game offers so much to do and many ways to built and play your characters, Sometimes you may get lost chillin' in the city for a few hours talking to Npc's about quests and such and other times you'll be on an adventure outside the castle walls, every second fearing for your life. (Save often peoples...) The game introduces a very fun and unique conversation system, that especially shines when your playing with a friend or family member, Allowing you and your Co-op partner to make decisions on how you feel and want to do in the game world. (Even if your Co-Op partner is settled on always trolling and disagreeing with you just to start an arguement)

The combat is engaging and difficult, But not too much so. Although I will say it does matter what type of party you have set up, For instance, My party I have for my Solo playthrough is 3 different type of melee characters (One who can heal of course.) And a archer... Now, while its still fun, such a team is much harder to playthrough the game with then, I dont know, a team with only one melee character and 2 mages instead. But regardless it doesnt take away from the fun of the game.

Now for a few cons about the game... Personally I feel the game offers little in the way of actual character appearance options. You make two characters, But without being able to change your characters build what-so-ever if you make two of the same gender characters they tend to look a bit similar. Not to mention there is only 3 voices per gender and about 10 or hair style's and faces. Im not saying this is a big deal by any means, You can still make characters you'll enjoy playing, and I know alot of people would like to argue about how much your characters appearance matters in a game like this, But I honestly think the closer you can get the character to how you imagine your adventuring crew helps with immersion and feeling your characters more. Who knows, I might just be weird or something... Heh.

As for the other beef I have with this game is *Sigh* it kinda feels like your always pushed to do stuff in a certain order, No matter how much bragging goes on about the tabletop-like freedoms of the game, Simply put you will have to explore the world in somewhat" a set order. The main reason for this is because levels on this game are a big deal at times. So say you set off for a quest that seems interesting at the time to find out that the enemys are 2 or 3 levels higher
date: Well your better off just walking away and doing a different quest or finding a way to earn some experience points before going back. And honestly
recommended: even when you do complete stuff 1 or 2 higher levels than you (Which isnt easy at all) That means you 'prolly just overleveled yourself for a different quest
hoursPlayed: Taking away from the difficulty of that quest. It isnt a huge problem honestly
voteText: because you still have some choices on what to do and when
helpfulPercent: but it feels bad when alot of things around you are too high of a level and you know theres only two or three quests you can do.\n\nOverall I find the game EXTREMELY SATISFYING! No matter how much I said about the cons the game is still overwhelmingly good. The endless ways to build your team is wonderful
votesHelpful: Tank healers
votesTotal: Two-handed sword mages
votesFunny: fire magic archers or even traditional type builds like pure mages or sword and shield... Basically anything you can think of! (Just make sure you spend your attribute and skill points wisely!) The endless ways of building your team helps keep the game fresh through multiple replays

reviewText:
I finally got my girlfriend into video games because of this!

Pros:  It's  a fantastic game with lovely top-down visuals and in-depth story.  The characters are rich, including your own.  The best part is, you can shape your character's personality and traits the way YOU want!  Combat is very challenging, but it makes you think and plan ahead.  Use the environment to your advantage, and you will succeed.  Co-op is remarkably fun and highly encouraged! Don't play this game by yourself!!! The more, the merrier!

Cons:  I run into random frame freezing and stuttering from time-to-time.  But that may have something to do with my PC in general.  There are ways to jump right into a fight without going through a lecture with the enemy NPC right before, but you run the risk of breaking the game.

Verdict:  This is a fun game, with hidden jokes and excellent gameplay.  I highly recommend it!

A sexy 9/10

reviewText: I bought Divinity Original Sin quite awhile back on an impulse and I am incredibly glad I did. The enhanced edition only adds that much more polish to an already awesome game. In my view the best thing about this game is the combat, If your looking for RPG combat with a tactical but still modern feel look no further.\n\nWhen I originally bought Divinity OS I  had been looking for a game with turn based combat that wasen't just the same old side-view battle screen thing since I have never found that very appealing. Divinity OS provided turn-based tactical combat in a 3d world where the elements interact dynamically with each other. Want to get rid of a poison cloud? hit it with a fireball and make it explode. Enemy not flammable enough for you? douse him in a puddle of oil and light it on fire. And heaven forbid you accidentally light yourself on fire, you can have someone cast a rain spell to put you ( and everything else in a large radius) out. Simply put, It's just a tremendous amount of fun. For me it was the first RPG in decades that actually recaptured that stay-up-all-night gaming thrill I found when I was a kid, and for that I can't thank larian enough. The terrific co-op just adds that much more value to an already exceptional game. The story is interesting, even if parts of it are a little cliche, the characters are memorable, the soundtrack is, well let's say divine"
recommended: and its all pulled together by the best turn based combat experience I have ever had. Possibly the only area of the game that could have used more work is the somewhat clunky crafting system
hoursPlayed: but even that is workable.\n\nNow as far as what the Enhanced Edition brings to the table
voteText: it's quite a bit actually. It adds full voice-acting along with controller support
helpfulPercent: which was needed because of the addition of local co-op and the port to various consoles ( I still prefer the mouse and keyboard
votesHelpful: but the controller setup is pretty well thought out). Skills have been changed
votesTotal: added and generally polished. Two new weapon types
votesFunny: grenades and wands
commentsCount: are now available ( both are quite a bit of fun)...I'm sure there are plenty of other improvements that I just can't think of at the moment
column16: but suffice to say it's well worth buying.\n\nOn a side note
column17: kudos to Larian for giving those of us who owned the original version when the enhanced edition came out a free copy of it. They really didn't have to do that
column18: and I think that is evidence they are a company worth supporting
column19: which among other reasons is why I backed the kickstarter for DOS 2.\n\nIn summary
column20:
the things I liked and didn't-

Divinity Original Sin EE:

reviewText: This game is one of the best rpg games out there. The story is rich and interesting. The mix of turn based combat and world exploration is perfect. The voice acting is great and the dialogue is funny. The local coop is well executed (a plus for me); the game seamlesly switches from one camera when players are close to a verticle split screen when walking away from each other. The skills are fun to play with and the various perks allow for different fighting styles and strategies as you build your character. As a fellow game developper, I tip my hat to the team at Larian Studios. These guys made a gem and I just can't wait for the sequel!

reviewText: An excellent rpg, it is old school though. It has very good tactical combat that feels rewarding when you beat a difficult segment, and excellent single player and co-op experience (with in split-screen!), pretty good writing and voice acting.\nAlso, the developers seem to really care about delivering a great product above anything else.

reviewText:
This is easily one of the best games i have played of all time.  It's been on my wishlist since before it's release and I was always hesitant about getting it.  However, after i bought it, I realized what I'd been missing the entire time.  The gameplay is reminiscent of Dark Alliance, Baulders Gate, it handles smoothly, and really brings alot of options to the table.  To tie it all together, the game has a nice atmosphere, good soundtrack, and campy humor, which really brings out the best in the gaming experience.

Pros: smooth gameplay, entertaining and challenging quests, good story, enjoyable dialogue, and visualy appealing.

Cons: Lack of inital character customization.  Every male is burly and shaped the same, and every woman is thin and attractive.  Its not a huge complaint, but when i make a rouge character i prefer a slim, more elusive frame vs the burly knight type character.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
More than a year after originally purchasing the classic edition, I got around to playing through the game on the enhanced edition. Clocking in at ~60 hours for that run, I have to say that, barring some poor design choices, this is an RPG of a quality I don't see often, high as it is.
Where it counts: in making decisions that define your character(s), in the engrossing combat mechanics and the outstanding world design, Divinity: Original Sin shines as a unique example of an RPG done right.
That said, the Diablo leanings the game has, in the inventory system most particularly, detract from what could've been an even more interesting experience. Fiddling with a massive inventory that keeps overflowing with prefixed and suffixed items, many of which aren't that good, was tedious.
Another minor bad point is the practical punishment for preparing for tough battles. The system doesn't let you down potions in advance, nor apply buffs. They don't last long enough if you initiate combat willingly. Food, it appears, under this, is useless.
But with all that said, I still enjoyed the game a whole bunch and can recommend it greatly.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Being skeptical of the relatively high price, I was lucky enough to get it on sale during Christmas, and after playing briefly I would recommend it at full price too!  Divinity pulls you into its world right from the beginning!\n\nI am ony a few hours into the game and already in love with it! Attention is paid to every detail from the contents of crates and barrels to crafting and character elements.  Additionally, the immersion level is amazing due to good voice acting, events, dialouge, buildings, and much more.  Camera control and zoom is great as well, and with these types of games I have found this to be quite lacking sometimes, yet Divinity fluidly pulls it off.  If you like games such as Baldurs Gate and Wasteland 2 you will DEFINITELY get your money's worth!

reviewText: Mixed View:  I really enjoyed the game until  3/4 through the 2nd map when I realized how level 10 was well below my enemies and once I reached the blood stone and could not destroy it.....  because I did not buy the right weapon on another quest, which is in an area I can't get to unless I do another quest, which ... etc. etc.  So you start finding out later in game you might have to go back and replay 1/3 the game because somewhere you forgot to pick up part of a spell, a critical key, talk to someone, etc.  And if you can't destroy the blood stone then good luck killing demons who have infinite strength.   So at that point I had to say ... it was fun up till now... time to quit.... when the frustration factor/ Fun factor is like 3 vs. a good game that is .1, time to move on.  I hope with Divinity 2 they do a better job.  I read the same frustration with many playing the game .  However, I do see the real value in the game if you are one that does every quest and loves that kind of thing.  I did like the option to grow your character and use strategy when fighting your enemies (that was real plus).  I would give the game a 5/10 overall, since I will never play more than 40% of the total game now.

reviewText:
TLDR at bottom...

I've played through this game as well as the unenhanced edition with my friend several times. We've had the original since it was in alpha and ironically mistook the nature of the game for something else (we thought itd be like skyrim lol). However, it still became one of our favourite games to play together. We're always looking for good co op games to play and I heartily recommend this game if you enjoy strategic co op rpg's.

This game was a wonderful bonding tool, and what made it so great for me was being able to play it with my best friend. The game is increasingly more fun if you play with someone else. I have many fond memories I can share with them and I don't think any game made me laugh so hard I cried actual tears like this one. Anyway we had fun playing through the still developing game several times over, and I'm happy with how the final game ended up.

There's alot of aspects to love, if you like crafting, this game has a nice and interesting system. The traits system was also original and interesting if sometimes a bit tedious, with me (the group crafter) having to look up wiki's on crafting and blacksmithing recipies.

The co op aspects are wonderful, there's a plethora of ways for you to intereact not only with your partner (should you have one) but also with the several characters you can get as followers. I found the combat to be spectacular, the different strategies you can choose from, different class routes you can choose lead to many possible combinations which give it good replay value. The turn based combat sets the pace at a very controlled rate, which is nice if you have other things going on, like texting a friend or if you need to take a snack/bathroom break. The game isn't demanding or needy like many other online games are.

The story is also very interesting and complex and has many twists and turns. The mysteries throughout it are captivating and kept me and my friend guessing for most of the game. The characters throughout the story are interesting and even though you influence your followers they have their own stories that unravel as you play. Your characters respectively become who you make them to be, and this affects how your followers behave and what kind of people they end up being.

Point is, this is a well developed game i've seen from the early alpha to the enhanced edition, and im very happy with how it turned out and how fun and original this great co op game is; one of the best co op games ive ever had the pleasure to playthrough.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Dungeons and Dragons meets Fire Emblem in an adventure mode gameplay. This game is really intuitive, has funny self-aware moments, and a really well thought-out classing, character build system. The fights are interesting and challenging if you pick the right difficulty. Even the dungeon crawling, looting, and trap/secret detection is all very fun and rewarding.

Downsides: Seems to crash a lot in multiplayer and have funny bugs. There's very little concise and definite information out there regarding crafting, skills, character builds, so you kind of just have to feel it out as you go. Some skills are clearly more useful than others and synergize with other multi-classes, but you don't really find out how and why until after you have your character leveled up.

Gameplay far outweighs the downsides.

reviewText:
I got this game because it has all the ingredient and flavoring vibes that says Torchlight 2 or Diablo Series in it.
To play this game via LAN, you will only need to purchase once. 2P can join in a hosted game by 1P in offline mode.

I could talk about the pros or the cons about the game, but I'll leave those to the experts. So far, game works fine even
without Mods for me.

One thing I would like to point out is, the game has dual dialogues events in which 1P and 2P will be engaging with.
The dual dialogues will let you choose/decide the outcome for that certain events.
Any disagreement with how both players wants the outcome to be, will lead to a mini game of Rock-Paper-Scissors.
Winners gets to get the outcome they wanted, and I always win. LOL.
I find that fun to do especially when my Gf likes to plays the good role while I do my evil role.
The dual dialogue+Rock-Paper-Scissors thing is fun but only when you do it with another player. Not so amusing with an AI unfortunately.

reviewText:
First id like to say......WOW this game brings it.

For rpg they kinda all follow a build for characters but this game puts character build and flushing a story to a whole new level. You make a basic character and the great aspect is throughout the game you are building who your character is as a person using conversation which can assist with traits and abilities for the character. Its not your normal look i leveled let me add some things, its more then that because you converse with your party members while they talk to NPC or after decisions they make. you can make your party think the same or go against each ideology which is fascinating and there is mechanics built in for resolving conflict.

There is a challenge in fighting as when using magic or fighting enemies you really need to check your surroundings and know your elements. As combing spells or things around in the area can make a HUGE difference in combat. At the same time the AI is great they to will use what is around to really knock it to the players and combine spells as well or control the enviroment. Its all one can one in an RPG and more. I am glad after playing this that i did back them for their kickstarter cause i cannot wait for what this company has to bring this game is already great.

i give this a 10 out of 10

reviewText:
This is a top-tier RPG for the RPG enthusianst.  The added controller support is excellent and extremely intuitive, and the split-screen/local co-op is aboslutely fantastic.  I know this had online co-op support in the original version, but I cannot think of another game that really plays off the co-op elements as well as Divinity does.  Quests can be tackeld in numerous ways depending on your build or affinity.  The fact that there are two heroes can be EXTREMELY entertaining when playing with a friend with a different attitude or moral outlook than yours.

The battle mechanics work well.  It's turn based, so it may be a turn off for some, but I found the combat very entertaining and satisfying.  Very, very deep skill system with your comman stats like STR, DEX, INT, etc., but also borrow a bit from fallout as you can gain Talents" every few levels that are very similar to Fallout's Perk system.

Graphics and sounds are top notch.  Fun factor is off the charts for any classic RPG lover.  Story is goofy
hoursPlayed: and serious all at once.  It strikes a really great balance between all those tones.\n\nCouldn't recommend the game more.  As you can see by my hours clocked I've spent a lot of time with it.  Must buy for any RPG fine IMO."

reviewText: I'm sure you can find a lot of reviews explaining just how good Divinity Original Sin Enhanched Edition is. But let me highlight what I think make this game so enjoyable for me: exceptional degree of freedom + tactical turn based battle Use your skill almost everywhere, everytime, manipulate the environment, kill almost every NPC, multiple ways to solve the quest, split your party to solve puzzle out of the box. While there are other games that offers similar degree of freedom, Divinity: OS EE battle mechanics goes along very well with it giving you almost unlimited array of tactical options. I look forward for mod support to be implemented in the enhanched edition.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A very fun game in addition to the previous game.

I didn't finish the previous game, but having the whole game voice acted makes me wish I waited to play this version, and I hope the next DS has fully voice acted.

The degree of freedom is almost unparrallel to what you can do.

The real fun the of the game is the challanging fights.  Since the game is turned based, combat is slow, but challanging.

Enemies often start first, and are sometimes invulerable unelss you have a magic spell to unturn them.

EE has a few more perks, a very clean and satsifying ending.

Don't underestimate perception, it can help show many things you missed as there are TONS of easter eggs in the game (something I regret since I was combat focused).  I don't know how anyone could play this game on heroic mode unless they knew 1000% what they were doing.  One thing that is annoying is the game should be almost renamed quicksave, as there are TONS of things (simple opening a door, digging up a whole) can lead to a massive explosion and a whole party wipe.  So you quicksave and load often to reset fights/encounters/conversations often limiting the challange of the game.

Since dialogue paths are often linear, there is not a problem to just quickload.

Puzzles and quests can be overly complex, and since there is NO HAND HOLDING in the game, it is made for pretty smart players imo.  Often you need the IGN walkthrough guide to help you out.  Even near the end where the stuff is new, you have to solve the puzzle by moving the statues on the 3 stone tabs and flipping the switch to reveal a mirror to flip a switch to a door (a puzzle in a puzzle in puzzle) lol.

Yes you might rage out a few times on tactician for those die hard for a challange, but the ending, and winning is more satsifying.

I personally played this game for the immense challange of the combat it offers, and the bauldur's gate, pillars of eternity, D&D feel.  I still like Dragon Age Orgins more, but this is more of an indie route, and is reflected as such in the price.

Looking forward to a sequel.  Game takes about 40-80 hours to complete, so well worth the price point if party strategy and extreme problem solving are your thing.

What are you waiting for?  :)

9 orc axes out of 10.

reviewText:
This isn't a game for everyone.  If you dislike poking through crates, tracking down obscure information, revisiting areas in town multiple times then you might want to pass this game up.  If you liked games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, or other similar turn based ROLE-PLAYING adventures, this is for you.

The adventure so far has been entertaining and intriguing.  There are great references to literature sprinkled througout, so if you like the classics, you will get some of the jokes.

My current disappointment is that there is no editor for enhanced edition that I can find.  I would like to write my own adventures and look forward to that tool becoming available again.

reviewText:
I've always been an extreme enthusiast of the old BioWare top-down rpg Baldur's Gate, and any of those close to me know this. Once upon a time my friend started playing this game and heard it was similar to Baldur's Gate, and knowing me he immediately bought me a copy of Divinity Original Sin.

One of the best gifts I have ever received. I never thought a top-down rpg could be considered next-gen in 2014 but just about every feature in this game is astounding. spectacular graphics, although the models are a bit cartoony.

The Turn based combat was the only part of the game that qualifies as dissappointing, but it was very well done, and very tactical and dynamic, and I enjoyed it.

The story is incredible, it's pretty lengthy so you get to enjoy it for a while, and it's very suspenseful and mysterious, with some great, creative and unexpected twists. A very interesting feature is how you role-play as two characters, which adds fun to multiplayer if you decide to co-op the game. Your two main characters are often confronted with difficult decisions and they debate about them and the way they interact with eachother impacts the game moving forward. And the overall theme of the story is very creative, and is definitely superior to the average RPG story theme of the bad guy wants to watch the world burn and you are going to stop him."

Gameplay is very

votesFunny: and extensive crafting system as well

column18: forest

reviewText:
Can't add much to what thousands of people have already said. DOS has the best combat system I've seen in a turn based rpg to date and will probably only be topped by DOS2 in the near future.

The way the environment, objects, characters and elements interract creates chaotic and fun but also deep gameplay that rewards creativity and allows for a multitude of approaches. If there was a Nobel prize for achievement in game design whoever created DOS' combat system would deserve it imo.

There's loads more that could be said and praised about DOS but I'll leave that to other reviewers.

reviewText: Divinity: Original Sin is basically two things. First and foremost, it is a huge beautiful game that combines charm and depth in a way that most other role-playing only dream about. After creating your own characters, take control of its two main characters and one or two companions that are either mages, assassins, archers, knights, healers, mercenaries or other fantasy cliché encountered in its path.\n\nOne is unleashed in a world where every square meter is packed with neat design and good atmosphere. The music sets a great atmosphere through the whole experience, and jokes, obscure pop culture references and the ability to talk to animals gives the game quite a frivolous tone that only stops at the right times.

reviewText:
After digging up a grave a skeleton spawned... wiped my whole team.

My 2 handed warrior with lone wolf after skipping his turn got charmed... wiped my whole team.

A chest to loot behind pool of lava? GET IT!... wiped my whole team.

But jokes aside.

Divinity Original Sin Enhanced Edition delivers on pretty much all the aspects (story could be a bit more interesting).
- Graphics are gorgeus.
- No more arrow or point on your map to finish a quest, you actually have to use your brain to figure out what to do next!
- Combat is complex and interesting. Losing a battle? Suddenly you remember that if you hit that water puddle with lighting all enemies will have a chance to get stunned and switch favour of the battle.
- RPG element is great, decisions you make will have influence on overall world.
- NPCs are very interesting and voice acting helps in this aspect as well.
- Your characters and team can be build in vareity of ways, which means lots of replayability.

If you haven't tried DivinityOriginal Sin like myself, get this game as soon as you will have the cash, trust me you won't regret doing so!

10/10

reviewText:
I wrote a review for this game a long time ago when it first came out. They replaced the original game with the Enhanced Edition, so I felt the need to come back and rewrite my review. The original game was an absolute masterpiece on so many levels, and I was shocked that the Enhanced Edition could take the game even further. The game now has so many new features, a revised crafting system, a revised story, and is now fully voiced.

An absolutely beautifully crafted world that allows players to play how they want. There are multiple ways to complete most quests, whether it be through brute force, conversation, stealing, or whatever you can think of. The options are only limited by the very generous game mechanics. The depth of this game is absolutely mind blowing. I'm on my third playthrough and I still find new things I hadn't discovered before and new ways of doing things. The story doesn't feel forced either, it just glides along as you explore the world.

The turn-based combat system is wonderfully designed and allows you to win your battles using any means at your disposal. Go in head first, build a barricade out of objects you find around you, set a fiery trap for your foes... whatever it takes. Combine abilities to create battle changing opportunities, like slowing your enemies with an oil slick then lighting them on fire or electrifying a pool of water, stunning those that come in contact with it. Choose your tactics based on the character classes you choose for your party, of which there are many to choose from.

On top of all that, the co-op play is awesome. This game is a lot of fun on its own, but even better when playing with a friend. Work together and plan your attacks, solve puzzles, figure out quests... two heads are definitely better than one.

Fans of games like Neverwinter Nights, Dragon Age, Baldur's Gate, and Icewind Dale will love this game and should definitely check it out. Well worth its full price, and an absolute steal if purchased on sale.

I cannot recommend this Enhanced Edition enough! They added optional gamepad controls, better inventory, smoother gameplay and they managed to make a great game even greater.

Just buy it!

reviewText:
Yet again, the best cRPG of all time.

Seriously, the fact that the developers made such huge enhancements to the game and released it for free should say enough about how much I respect their work.

This game has simply the best combat mechanics out of any turn based game I have ever played, period, and I have played a *lot* of videogames.

Now, with the enhanced edition, so many things that annoyed me (slightly) in the original are all fixed.

Every line is fully voiced now, instead of only important lines. Did I mention they did this for free?

The cooperative play is so amazingly well done and it is for sure the best co-op game I think I have ever played.

This is simply a masterpiece and I am not sure what else to write. I seriously cannot think of a single thing I dislike about this game. It is that good.

Larian Studios is my favorite developer because of this game.

reviewText:
The good:
Excellent, strategic combat system utilizing elemental and environmental effects to their max. How you use the environment (or how enemies use it against you) can easily turn the tide of a battle.
Detailed artwork and a well-crafted world.
Plentiful waypoints for fast travel between locations.
It seems that almost every line of dialogue is voiced, and most of it is very well done.
The music is well-done, and will at times get stuck in your head.
50+ hours of entertainment (if you take your time).

The bad:
Uneven pacing. Ending felt disjointed, rushed, and underwhelming.
A few buggy quests requiring quicksave/quickload to allow dialogue options to continue.
Inventory management is a chore.
Be prepared to abuse quickload to win games of RPS. You can be the most charming person in the world against somebody with the charisma of an ugly bridge troll and still lose RPS.

The ugly:
I killed the final boss in 1 turn using only half my party. Decidely anti-climactic.
Spells and arrows often get blocked by objects and topographical features of terrain. Very annoying.
Enhanced Edition version of the puzzle" to enter the Source Temple was a royal pain. As was the "puzzle" in the temple itself.

Story ✩✩✩✩
Gameplay ✩✩✩✩
Sound ✩✩✩✩✩
Graphics ✩✩✩✩✩

Bottom line:
Buy if you enjoy CRPGs. I got 60+ hours of entertainment.

P.S. I played this both on a gaming rig with a Radeon 290 @ 1440p and on a laptop with a i5-5200U + Intel integrated graphics @ 1366x768. Game ran acceptably on both. As always be prepared to make compromises if your hardware is outdated."

reviewText:
This is quite possibly the best Turn-Based RPG I have ever played and the best game to have ever come out of a Kickstarter campaign. Many games, mostly AAA console-focus titles, advertise player choice as a selling point, but few get it right or even live up to it. You can finish almost every quest in any which way you want in any order. An NPC will only give you an item to progress further by completing a quest you dont care to do? Just pickpocket it off of him/her with the necessary skill level. An NPC have something with awesome stats in their inventory? Sneak around and rip if off them or from their house. Be a good person, bad person, or something in between.

The various elements that can be wielded in this game was a splendidly refreshing new mechanic to play with. Poison, earth, fire, air, water, etc can be utilized and combined to give you very interesting strategies to give yourself an upperhand in combat, especially when fighting more enemies than you can handle or enemies several levels above you. Lay down poison or a poison cloud for either damage or area denial and once youve maximized its use light it on fire to blow up anyone inside it thus converting poison to now buning damage. Lay down fire to burn enemies and extend its coverage to throwing more oil around the area and if you want to change that then put some water down and itll create a smokescreen blocking all line-of-sight. Much more can be done, but Ill keep this short.

I never thought this game would have lasted me over 80hrs. Outside of combat there was plenty to do through big and small side-quests. And they had substance whereas many games by shallow devs/pubs add boring, trivial quests to pad game length. Also, puzzles and traps were everywhere. Either through riddles, hidden switches, hidden hatches, etc. I am psyched for Divinity: Original Sin 2

reviewText: I've been playing this game for about a week now and the game is fairly entertaining. It does have some frustrating aspects however. reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game, and for while I was certain I was, but now the honeymoon's over.

The game makes a great first impression, boosted by the fact that I love party-based RPGs. Shiny graphics, crisp sound, 2 customizable avatars. But then the ugliness arrives.

The biggest part of the game is designing the right party setup. Do you want a balanced group, a melee-heavy group, a caster group, or rogues and archers? The game is highly difficult, even on normal, and you need your party members to do precisely what you want, in order to get anywhere. But the game immediately pours ice water on you by not allowing you to customize your two additional companions. So if you have the perfect setup in mind, you now have to work around the garbage skills your 2 companions bring. (Lone Wolf is a joke btw.)

You venture forth with your less-than-ideal group of 4 adventurers. You try to (as much as possible) avoid the uninspiring and unfocused story (from a murder investigation to saving the world from an existential threat -- really?), instead opting to focus on combat and skill development. You stave off nausea and turn off the voice so you don't have listen to the ungodly blend of Southern / Scottish / Irish / British accents in the awful voice acting.

You quickly realize that even though the game is supposed to be open-world, it really isn't. There are many choke points blocked by creatures too high-level for you, so you have to double back and look for something you can defeat. No such luck. So now you go back to the story. You spend hours trying to find that next scripted event that will move the story forward. Except it's nowhere to be found and you're forced to google it, realizing it was some tiny detail you missed, whose connection to the story makes no logical sense whatsoever. You will be constantly stuck" on certain quests you didn't realize you have to put on hold until a much later point.

The game touts the flexibilty of the classless system and your ability to be whatever you want. Except you must live with (and regret) your skill investment decisions every step of the way. The game uses diminishing returns to essentially force you to make balanced characters (i.e. spreading your points across several skills / stats rather than focusing on a few)
date: but balanced characters are actually horrible (attacks miss all the time
hoursPlayed: longer cooldown
voteText: can't equip items
helpfulPercent: etc etc). In the end
votesHelpful: after restarting the game dozens of times
votesTotal: you realize you had to specialize after all.\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: an aesthetically pleasing game (sans the voice acting)
commentsCount: with questionable design choices."

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is simply one of the best games ever made. I could go into a multi-page rant about why this game is so great, but I will not be able to stop so I will keep it brief.
The entire game is just fantastic - the combat is exciting and varied, the story is interesting (and often funny), and the aesthetic is great. For anyone interested in strategy games, this is a must have. I have only just began a new game since getting the Enhanced Edition but I have finished every mission/side quest in the classic version. Although I have barely played any of the Enhanced version, it inspired me to write a review and help boost the overall steam rating of this game because Larian simply deserve it for being such a great company and making what is a genuine masterpiece.

Like the sound of a tactical, story-rich RPG full of character, cool spells and weird encounters?

Buy it. Trust me, you will really enjoy it.
