reviewText:
Ok, this is honestly the best game I've played since Dishonoured. However, it is the sort of game that you will only like if you are a specific sort of person. Yes, it plays well as a standard tactical rpg game that allows for an awful lot of linear thinking in how you combat scenarios, but in reality, it feels a lot like a pen and paper rpg that has been streamlined so that combat doesn't feel so clunky. Of course, there are some limitations due to the medium, but this is probably the best game I've found so far for giving a feel of freedom in how you go about things and what sort of character you're playing.

You will enjoy this game if:
You enjoy highly challenging tactical rpgs
You enjoy storywriting/pen and paper rpgs and are prepared to make a character (or two) and then have them interact with a highly dynamic world
You enjoy dishonoured/deus ex like freedom/do it your way style games. Seriously, there have only been one or two occasions where I felt like I wanted to do something that the game didn't permit (one of them was jailing somebody that the game only allowed me to kill or allow free).

You will not enjoy this game if:
You do not enjoy the pace of the game slowing down for several hours at a time as you talk to NPCs, investigate murders, interact with the rest of your party, etc.
You like fast paced games and games with twitch combat (combat is turn based, top down, but movement of characters and interaction with the environment is almost totally free).

Key features of the game:
Pen and paper like freedom, or at least, the best game for that sort of thing I've ever seen
Highly challenging strategic combat with an awful lot of linear thinking (for example: a friend and I spent a while trying to get past a handful of quite challenging orcs... after a while, I teleported an oil barrel onto them, then he ignited it with a fireball. Similarly, teleporting the flaming zombie into the river proved quite effective, and a burning boat was saved by using a rain scroll).
Slow paced gameplay at times
Dynamic NPCs, ala Skyrim
Skills that practically scream 'use me in or out of combat'
Engrosing storyline
Interesting interactions between protagonists

reviewText:
While although a strong single player game, I wouldn't recommend getting it for yourself unless you're such a top down enthusiest that you have several hundred hours solo in other similar titles.
HOWEVER
This game takes on a whole new light when played with a friend. Not only is the writing hilarious and the mechanics solid, but the memories you'll take away playing away with friends is the real gem. We still laugh to this day about the time I tried hiring a hooker and ended up getting a bed time story, and of my jealous friend who hired his own hooker who ended up being an assassin.
Seriously, even if this isn't your normal style, if a friend asks if you want to get it with him and give it a whirl, dive head first into it. Do be warned though, this game might last you about 40-50 hours for one play through then its pretty exhausted unless you end up playing it with another friend.
Please excuse my very minimal hours in this game, for as like many others, my review pertains to the original edition that came out. The enhanced edition is definitely very optimized though, so if you've been hesitant in trying this out now is the best time to do it.

reviewText:
++FIRST IMPRESSIONS--SIX HOURS OF GAMEPLAY++
- Find out an NPC took a bribe that led to a Bad Thing happening
- Tell him he should turn the money in
- He beats me at paper scissors rock and refuses
- Try to pick the money from his pocket and turn it in myself
- He catches me and attacks me
- Knock him on his ♥♥♥
- Beat him to within an inch of his life
- Flee the battle
- Go tell the Legion Captain about the bribe
- He gets arrested
- Ransack his shop while he's in prison

Pros
- Almost every little decision you make has some kind of impact. Even minor dialogue choices affect your characters through putting tallies on certain personality traits that affect in-game bonuses. You're presented with a number of challenges that you can solve creatively, and the method you choose actually has some bearing on what kind of people your main characters become.
- Combat requires you to think and manage resources, unlike many modern games that hand out health potions like candy and make it easy to get by without them to boot. The element system is a cool way of encouraging players to alternate their spells, using combos such as drenching the enemy with rain to set them up for a lightning attack. This aspect also gives wizards something to do in battle besides blast enemies, as their area spells are sometimes needed to clear up hazardous conditions so the party can advance or create hazardous conditions to deny routes to the enemy.

Cons
- When I came into town, I met a cat wizard who likes turning into a cat and making cat puns. I figured he was the comic relief character. I now realize that they are all the comic relief character. Goofy characters and goofy writing constantly undercut the game's efforts to get you invested in the story. The setting actually looks pretty interesting (other than the hilariously-named Sourcerers" and "Source Hunters")
date: but I can't bring myself to care. This is a particularly major flaw in a game that's supposed to be an old-school-style RPG.\n- There are some quirks in the combat interface that take some getting used to
recommended: and the one-click command system combined with the delay time after some combat animations makes it a little too easy to accidentally commit a character to burning all of his or her action points walking across the screen to a useless position or firing an attack spell off at a corpse or barrel. Despite being almost insultingly hand-holding at times
hoursPlayed: the tutorial doesn't talk much about the UI."

reviewText:
Ok, this is honestly the best game I've played since Dishonoured. However, it is the sort of game that you will only like if you are a specific sort of person. Yes, it plays well as a standard tactical rpg game that allows for an awful lot of linear thinking in how you combat scenarios, but in reality, it feels a lot like a pen and paper rpg that has been streamlined so that combat doesn't feel so clunky. Of course, there are some limitations due to the medium, but this is probably the best game I've found so far for giving a feel of freedom in how you go about things and what sort of character you're playing.

You will enjoy this game if:
You enjoy highly challenging tactical rpgs
You enjoy storywriting/pen and paper rpgs and are prepared to make a character (or two) and then have them interact with a highly dynamic world
You enjoy dishonoured/deus ex like freedom/do it your way style games. Seriously, there have only been one or two occasions where I felt like I wanted to do something that the game didn't permit (one of them was jailing somebody that the game only allowed me to kill or allow free).

You will not enjoy this game if:
You do not enjoy the pace of the game slowing down for several hours at a time as you talk to NPCs, investigate murders, interact with the rest of your party, etc.
You like fast paced games and games with twitch combat (combat is turn based, top down, but movement of characters and interaction with the environment is almost totally free).

Key features of the game:
Pen and paper like freedom, or at least, the best game for that sort of thing I've ever seen
Highly challenging strategic combat with an awful lot of linear thinking (for example: a friend and I spent a while trying to get past a handful of quite challenging orcs... after a while, I teleported an oil barrel onto them, then he ignited it with a fireball. Similarly, teleporting the flaming zombie into the river proved quite effective, and a burning boat was saved by using a rain scroll).
Slow paced gameplay at times
Dynamic NPCs, ala Skyrim
Skills that practically scream 'use me in or out of combat'
Engrosing storyline
Interesting interactions between protagonists

reviewText:
While although a strong single player game, I wouldn't recommend getting it for yourself unless you're such a top down enthusiest that you have several hundred hours solo in other similar titles.
HOWEVER
This game takes on a whole new light when played with a friend. Not only is the writing hilarious and the mechanics solid, but the memories you'll take away playing away with friends is the real gem. We still laugh to this day about the time I tried hiring a hooker and ended up getting a bed time story, and of my jealous friend who hired his own hooker who ended up being an assassin.
Seriously, even if this isn't your normal style, if a friend asks if you want to get it with him and give it a whirl, dive head first into it. Do be warned though, this game might last you about 40-50 hours for one play through then its pretty exhausted unless you end up playing it with another friend.
Please excuse my very minimal hours in this game, for as like many others, my review pertains to the original edition that came out. The enhanced edition is definitely very optimized though, so if you've been hesitant in trying this out now is the best time to do it.

reviewText:
The game is amazing. Story is interesting so far, the tactical combat is even better than back in BG2, there's lots of humor in the game and the co-op feature is really well designed, allowing me to share the experience with my GF as one of our favorite co-op experiences of all time.

When I still can't recommend this amazing game, it's because the co-op has some of the most critical bugs I've ever seen, even 6+ months after the release of the enhanced edition:

The minor" nuisances is that hp bars and initiative order in combat is consistently wrong on the client. We've gotten used to both looking on the host's monitor to see what the real health values are
date: and when each character acts in combat
recommended: but I imagine this will be quite the deal-breaker if you're not sitting next to your partner.\n\nThe true critical issue for us has been that the co-op saves break
hoursPlayed: making it impossible to continue. We're not talking the occasional game crashes (which are reasonably rare) but that we reach a state where the client will consistently freeze up upon joining the game. We were initially able to suppress the issue a bit with help from Larian support and then bypass it for a while by switching the save to the other computer - yet the bug has returned every time. We are now 35 hours into the game and unable to continue. Larian support was initially quick and helpful
voteText: but it's now been 2 weeks since we sent them crash reports and we still cannot continue the game.\n\nWe've been loving the game
helpfulPercent: and I'd change my review to recommended in a heartbeat if it wasn't broken for us to the point of not being playable at all."

reviewText:
If you've haven't played this yet you're some crazy fool, if you have there seems to be more than enough here to play again. The pad input is some of the best I've seen in a CRPG mouse game since FFIV A Realm Reborn.

Inventory seems to be easier to manage which was a annoyance for me previously and everything else is good or better at the least.

The only thing they didn't fix or add a option for is the constantly repeating dialogue banter NPCs can churn through over and over again while you're in menus buying items or simply exploring an area in their vicinity, I don't know, perhaps there's a mod for that.

9-10 out of 10 (the minus 1 variable is for when the repeating grating dialogue gets under the skin).

reviewText: Free cheese it seems doesnt only come in a mousetrap, thanks to LS for whatever it was: a genius marketing move or a sudden stroke of charity. Because I am in a mood for cheese.\n\nI didnt love the original game as much, as I thought I would. Early acess looked very promising, but final release seemed to carry over most of its flaws: ragged storytelling, quite a few bugs, broken game mechanics (where basically combat turned into contest of cheese, rather than tactics). It did offer a lot, of course: open world, lots of freedom, charismatic characters (Talking to some of them, I almost felt back at Planescape: torment), original story, interesting combat mechanics and incredible campaign length. It was probably just me, but cons quickly outweighted pros, and I stopped playing 60 hrs into the game(which is still way more than I dedicate to other games and I hardly did 1/3 or the story) , thinking not bad
date: but not polished enough to become classic"\n\nYear later Larian did just what it needed to turn DOS into possibly best RPG ever made (Personally I'd still go with Baldurs Gate 2). But is it just "polishing"? Well. No. It is a massive upgrade in every possible way
recommended: to a point where mainstory is changed (for the better)

voteText: balance overhauled

votesTotal: you must have read all this in "features" section of steam store. However the scope of this
votesFunny: given how big this game already was
commentsCount: is nothing short of incredible.\n\nIn the end only problem I have with this game is that I cant pay larian for the second time. Because I would."

reviewText:
In this review I will compare DOS EE and DOS classic.

I was happy that most of skills was modified and that applying some of skills was modified. Story was modified only in final and it was ambiguous change. Of Course, was add some dialog and quests.

Adding recipes in craft system did game more comfortable. In game was added grenade and wand, it were very helpful.
Now you can't change the difficult of combat in any time game, it will constant when you choose difficulty in start game. Honour mode give you only one slot for save, it's mean that if you died your game is over.
And, I don't shure, but hero move slower than in DOS Classic...

Conclusion, if you play DOS Classic you will not see something new, only small enjoyable and comfortable change, but if you didn't play to DOS Classic, I recommend you to play in DOS EE.

reviewText: Divinity: Original Sin is like being cornered by the really boring boss at work who proceeds to talk at you for the next four hours. Anything you say doesn't really seem to matter, because this is about them. You wish you could get back to work, you'd even welcome it, but they won't let you. This is just part of a really long and boring job. You can't simply avoid it, because they're your boss; a lot of people admire Divinity, who you can only assume are just as boring. You're stuck thinking to yourself  If I wasn't obligated to work
date: I wouldn't." This is when I quit Divinity.\n\nThe game starts promising enough

reviewText: Game was amazingly fun, still is. It's probably one of the only true RPG games still out there today, and it demolishes the competition at what it tries to do. reviewText:
I really REALLY wanted to play this game.  However, there are two annoying aspects of the game that basically destroy it for me.

1) Every conversation will be riddled with arguments (between your own party members if not others), and all conflicts are settled with an annoying rock-paper-scissors game.  A game which you can't even pretend to be skilled at since your opponent HAS no psychology, and it doesn't even pretend to not be playing RPS for real (i.e. you never pick the same thing, so I guess it just decides who's going to win, and your choices are meaningless).

2) Every time you accidentally click on something red, everyone immediately hates you.  Who decided on that?  Sometimes, they'll give you warning before they really REALLY hate you, but I hope you save often.  If you anger someone by atempting to go through a door, good luck not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ them off, as when you turn around the other way, your party members will stream out behind you... and into the area you were just warned away from.

Basically, unless you're the kind of person who sets out to be a giant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you're going to become intimate friends with the quick load/save functions.

reviewText:
This game is no longer wretchedly awful as it was at release about a year or so ago. Even if the legion of fanboi's who supported its development at the time, swore up and down, violently confronting anyone who didn't join their blind, fantatical praises that it was the best thing since sliced bread. It no longer feels like a half baked, rushed tech demo developed by Iceland's CCP with a hacked on multiplayer element.

It feels more like the Divinity RPG games that came before it. Years before it. The reason? It finally -knows what it is- and functions well enough. The initial amateur hour rushed development elements seem mostly tended to. There are issues and echoes of old school gaming, and not the good variety. To list them all out would be hair splitting however. A tiny UI issue here, a mild graphical glitch there and so on.

If this game is missing one critical thing it is a true character level view point that can be played from full time, be it 1st person or 3rd person. See KOTOR's camera view options for reference. Yet critically, i suppose that's personal taste and not an outright fault of the game.

In closure before buying this game, be extremely sure you know what you're buying into. Personally i still loathe this game. If i could have a steam refund tomorrow i'd take it in a heartbeat. But it's not a bad game any longer. If you understand what the game is, buy it, play it with a friend and enjoy. It's finally worth a look.

----- Comments reply:
@Slimebeast :

When purchasing the game originally, and even now, many of the advertised still image pictures feature a very close-in image of the characters you play. I got the impression one could play and view the characters like that 24/7. But the camera frustratingly does not make that possible while keeping the game playable. It's just a nice, partial zoom-in view mode. You don't even have a fully free-camera from that perspective.

You can not play the game from a more typical perspective as in games like KOTOR. Please do note too, that i don't mind turn based combat. I don't generally enjoy FPS RPG's that lack turn based play. I don't even mind occasionally zooming out for a more isometric, distant view point / range.

Yet when wandering around? Exploring the setting, interacting with AI npc's? The game plays better from a distance. The zoom in mode is useless, and leaves a distasteful sense of the game being a tease as regards the player's immersion. It's as if it teases a semi-1st person mode and then pulls it away once you're there. Which is a thoroughy terrible UI experience.

That is why i loathe this game. I could complain about tiny things like inventory management too. But those are minor. Perhaps even 'genre authentic'.

However, as long as a person's expectations are acutely prepared / aware of just how this game will play, how the camera does actually work...All other early release bugs, annoyances and so on of the non-enhanced version seem to taken care of. Grade A dev work!

Those early issues dealt with, the game is fine, i'm happy reccomend it. Really. It's just not truly for me. If i could get a refund i'd take it. I'd even give my license for it to a friend if i could, if i knew the friend would like the game. I personally, just dislike the bait and switch sensation of the camera UI.

reviewText:
Problematic on Linux
If you intend to run this game on Linux, beware!

The game has about a 50% chance of crashing upon  attempt to save.  This is the case no matter whether it is a manual save, autosave, or quicksave.  If you experience this, don't wait and hope it gets better -- return the game.  Steam refused refund (and appeal) for me since I tried to tough it out for 7 hours of game play.  They say the max they allow before refund is 2 hours.

For the curious, this review was based on experience with Linux Mint 17.3 64-bit.

The combat is fantastic.

reviewText:
49.6 hours in to the game and I feel too bored to continue. The story is not interesting for me, some how it feels too childish and not deep enough to keep my interest. I could maybe live with that but also the combat is too easy for me, except in one boss fight where my team gets hit right from the start before it was my turn with a  huge scripted aoe fireball which killed on several tries usually half of my team leaving other with very low hp, had to reload from save and start the dialogue with only one character and leaving other characters out of reach of the fireball. If you are experienced with RPG's I recommend you to play on tactician level because the Classic mode is way too easy with all the cc available.

Otherwise the combat is pretty enjoyable and there are interesting combinations with the skills that you can play with.

Then there is the crafting which is annoying because the inventory is so cluttered and your resources are scattered between many chars and you have to move them between the characters and I just hate all that kind of inventory management in solo RPGs which just takes a lot of time and gives very little back. Also you get so much loot from the world and you will be swimming on money so you can usually get good gear from your explorations and from merchants.

Also at some places the NPC chattering is very annoying, they keep repeating their dialogue non-stop which becomes very irritating quickly and makes you want to mute the sounds. So if you are going to do some inventory management, find some peaceful spot without annoying npcs talking all the time.

reviewText:
I find that this game, while certainly not bad, is overrated. I've played all of the Divinity games, but I'd rate this the lowest alongside Beyond Divinity.

The game has decent combat, audio and graphics, but is, in my opinion, lacking in most other aspects.

My main interests in RPGs are mainly story, interesting character/locales, dialogue and optimizing builds/stats. The game doesn't satisfy on any of these areas. The story is a generic and farily lackluster fantasy tale that doesn't serve to invest you into the game. The characters, with a few exceptions like Arhu and Jahan, are forgettable. The locales are standard fantasy fare without anything standing out. There's also a lack of a world map to put the areas of the game into any sort of geographical context which is really hurting immersion into the gameworld.

The writing is mostly decent, but with an unfortunate focus on funny" dialogue. I know that Larian loves to put humour into their games
date: but I feel this game is too far over the edge. The character generation and leveling process is nothing special
recommended:
certainly not particularly unique in the RPG genre.

Another thing about the game that has puzzled me is the reference to the game being "old school". There is nothing old school about the game apart from the turn based combat.

I'd suggest Pillars of Eternity for a much more satisfying
hoursPlayed: deep and old school experience."

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did, but in the end, it's just too poorly balanced.

Pros:
+ Nice graphics
+ The voice acting is amazing
+ Quests can be quite interesting

Cons:
- The camera will randomly stop following your character
- You have to un-link a party member to heal out of combat
- The camera will move on it's own when not expected, causing misclicks
- Far too often, enemies are difficult to select, resulting in your character walking next to them, rather than attacking
- Encounters are far too unbalanced to the point where many at-level battles are impossible due to gimmicky mechanics (ex:  Enemies auto-freeze you on contact, meaning you only get a single hit in before they kill your helpless party)

Overall, I wish I could like this game, but in the end, it just relies far too much on gimmics and status ailments.  While the quests are entertaining, the combat is far too frustrating for me to recommend this game to anyone other than the die-hard masochists.
voteText: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I just want it to be good...I really want to like this game... but I just can't. I'm now at the final stage and the only reason why I keep playing it is the couch co op feature (there simply aren't many story driven couch co op rpgs out there). But let's just list all the things I liked and disliked about Divinity Original Sin:

Pros: - Nice story at the start, the first map is beautiful
- Character creation
- Character classes and skills felt really good when I was low lvl
- The game doesn't hold your hand and feels like an oldschool rpg
- THE COUCH CO OP FEATURE, i wish more cRPGs would adobt this

Cons:- The story gets boring after the first map, I felt invested in the world maybe for the first few hours
- The game tries to be funny and witty at times, but mostly fails at that and just breaks immersion
- The character developement in terms of skills and gear gets boring after the first few hours - no new skills after a certain point (not even close to the ending), weapons are just the same few models with different effects, armor has a laughable amount of tiers and there is absolutely no variety in the look of different armor sets (1 lvl plate armor - just a simple breastplate, 15 lvl plate armor - the same breastplate as lvl 1, only this time with an oversized shoulder piece
- Enviroment effects are a nice mechanic in combat, but in reality they are more frustrating than fun - the fields are imprecise at best. For example when your character just slightly touches a firefield with the tip of his foot for a split second - that's it, you are on fire now.
- The combat was fun at first, but when you have to battle 10 guys - good luck waiting for your turn.
- The AI is quite stupid - for expample when I manipulate an oponent to fight on my side, they often just stan around doing nothing.
- The level design is aesthetically pleasing, but the hitboxes are plain lazy. Try shooting a fireball next to flag post or over a little stone structure - it'll get stuck on an invisible concrete wall 1 meter above the mesh
- The quest log is a f***ing mess - you'll never find out if you've finished a quest or if you have to do anything. It's more like a diary, in which your character writes every stupid thing he encounters.
- I've found the player home completely meaningless - I only returned there when the story forced me to.


Final verdict: mediocreAll in all this isn't a bad game - it was fun to play in local co op. I would give it a 5/10 with a slight tilt towards a final negative score. if it wasn't for the fact that I can play this with my gf on one monitor I would've stopped playing 70hours ago and never touched this game again - especially when there are way better old school RPGs out now.

reviewText:
A mix of good and bad.  Do I recommend this game?  I don't know.

The character creation is a bit bare bones.  Class customization is somewhat interesting, but you cannot customize starting gear.  You get what the base class has, and you don't know exactly what that is until you start the game (you can get a vague idea by looking at the character).

For a tactical turn based game, where precision is very important, the user interface is terrible.  Occasionally, clicking on a skill will not activate it, leading your next click to send your character astray.  The Esc key does not let you exit dialogue, meaning you cannot quickly exit dialogue in panic mode when your characters are rapidly dying (out of combat) and instead of healing your partner, you start talking to them, because when you clicked on heal, it did not activate.  If you do activate an ability, and then change your mind about using it, and click End Turn, instead of ending that character's turn, the character uses the ability at the area underneath the end turn button; very aggrivating.  Worse still, if you are attempting to melee attack, or ranged attack an enemy, you absolutely must hold down control and then click.  If you don't you run the risk of the enemy shifting around in place, causing your character to run up to or around it instead of attack.  I've had numerous occasions where my archer wasted his entire turn running to an enemy I was going to shoot because for a split second the attack indicator became a move indicator without me moving the mouse at all (especially noticable on the half eaten zombies).  On other occasions, I will click to melee attack only to have my character take a slow walk around the enemy, usually through fire taking ridiculous amounts of damage (as it ticks approximately 4 times).

The failure to activate a skill when clicking on it happens with characters as well, such as when I need to quickly change the character I am focused on, and nothing happens while I frantically click the character icon.  Sometimes I think I have clicked on a particular character, and then tell them to move, only to have the wrong character move - often walking them right through deadly traps, hazardous terrain, or right into a group of enemies I am trying to tactially position myself around.

When trying to move a character around a tight spot, such as to avoid a known trap pressure plate, navigate around hazardous terrain, or avoid stepping into a vision cone area, the character often randomly diverts from the given path running directly onto pressure plates, through large swathes of hazardous terrain, or directly into line of sight.  Other times, pressure plates are triggered without the character actually touching them, by oversized phantom hitboxes.  When playing this game, I am often shouting either in my head or out loud at my characters WHAT THE HELL ARE YOU DOING?!"  Beyond that
date: party formation sometimes randomly changes.  For instance
recommended: in a recent battle I specifically selected a spellcasting character to move
hoursPlayed: put everyone in sneak mode
voteText: and put him in front
helpfulPercent: then cast the firefly spell
votesHelpful: and when it actually cast

votesFunny: cast it from the back
commentsCount: and set my party on fire.  Which reminds me

or when you are currently under a poison gas cloud (and the top down view is so awful I never want to use it).  Also the default run speed puts me to sleep.

So that's all of my griping about control precision.  Now for difficulty curve.

reviewText:
I cannot believe how many fundamental issues this game has that are blocking its actual content.

-Clickbox for enemies is FAR too narrowly defined, meaning instead of attacking your character will walk around them like a ♥♥♥♥♥. On hard mode, this often means you'll have to redo an entire fight as every action matters
-Fire and poison. Where do I even start on this? Not only do both do an absolutely ABSURD amount of damage, but walking even one or two steps through a fire/poisonous area will both afflict them AND do additonal immediate damage for traversing the area.
-Utterly baffling mechanics. Zombies become poisoned when I attack them? This corpse randomly blows up for 85% of my health when I walk over it? This trap instantly vaporizes my guy, with no way to disable it or get around it? This person is healed by magic?
-Horrible skill system. Combat skills mixed with magic skills mixed with crafting skills, with at least half of them being useless. The same can be said for the talents".
-Utterly pointless "sheath/unsheath" player states which exist for NO reason other than to punish the player. Accidentally have your weapons drawn and activate a dialogue option with an NPC
date: and then misclick the dialogue option? Hurray
hoursPlayed:
and unless you can reload you can kiss any sidequests they are involved in goodbye. What awesome immersion.


The pacing is slow

reviewText:
+

* Love the graphics & world design.
* Some dialogues can be fun, especially when communicating with animals. Moo!
* Enjoyable battle skills for various classes.

-

* Too much time running about. Which will happen a lot, since there is no obvious direction where to go next. Now I could be forgiving about this. I don't mind sinking my teeth into some exploring or investigating. Yet with this little (on-level) combat encounters on the go, the running around gets tedious and frustrating for me.

* I normally enjoy turn-based combat. It generally means you need to be strategic about your battles. But in D:OS EE the battles make me want to pull my hair out at times: especially with bigger amounts of foes, all their turns can take up so long I grab food, cuddle my cat & return later to see if I'm finally up (sometimes to find out I have to wait more). And if I died in the waiting process, I reload and play the waiting game again. Had I some battle strategy in mind to begin with, it now most definitely got lost somewhere... Luckily not all encounters have many foes, I did enjoy some fights.

Furthermore I concur with several things posted before me. About the puzzles not really being puzzles, emptying bags nuisance, enemy clickbox nuisance, ambient voices repeating themselves, I can go on. Those for me are minor nuisances though, and would've gladly forgotten them, if I could find some kind of pace in the game.... in story progression or battles.

reviewText: Its an OK game but I am just not sure where the GREATEST RPG since Baldurs Gate 2 is coming from. Baldurs Gate is vastly superior in terms of roleplaying, NPCs, story, Epic loot, and pretty much everything else but the nifty crafting and the environmental interactivity of Divinity. My biggest gripes are the childish writing and characters, the horrendously slow movement speed of the characters, the painful inventory management and the sluggish feel of the UI and game in general. I hope they fix at least some of these in Divinity Original Sin 2.

reviewText:
This game is an incredibly buggy mess. There's a great game underneath the tangle of bugs that are never really attended to in any sort of satisfactory way, incredibly ugly WWE/WoW-style aesthetics, and derivative storyline. As it stands, I wouldn't buy this unless it were on sale for ~90% off. Seriously.

Just a few of the awful bugs STILL plaguing the game:
-broken teller of secrets (a woman who gives your party much-needed stat points doesn't hand them out, meaning your party is essentially under-leveled)
-broken music (want music in your game? don't get this one; the music just randomly stops)
-broken quests all over the place
-and many more!

If you like Blizzard's cartoony art style and the Muscle Man character avatars (why is everyone either a hulking behemoth or a barely-dressed waif in heels?) you'll love this. If, however, you're an adult who isn't really into the whole muppet babies on steroids look this is something you'll just have to suffer through.

The devs got numerous complaints about the voice acting in the original game, so what did they do? They replaced all of the annoying dialogs with worse voice acting. It was the writing that was annoying, not the voice actors, whose voices actually had character. The game feels much blander now but it has the same cringey dialog.

tl;dr wait for a huge sale. I'm talking like around 90% off.

reviewText:
The mechanic is very good. Great fun for the first 50 hours. I applaud their thorough afford at voice acting.

However, the rest of the game I just wanted to rush to the finish line because the plot and the writing is so hard to swallow. Dialogue lack style and are extremely redundance and painful to read/listen. Art style is terrible. Item/crafting system is overwhelmingly boring. Characters completely flat.

if you combine this game's mechanic with art and story from bioware or blizzard, this would be a super phenomenol rpg of our time. a pity it suffer a severe lack of taste and style.

Have great potential as an rpg. Overall felt like a beta version of something bigger. I have high hope for the sequel.

Would you commit 80-120 hours to terrible writing but awesome fighting? Make your own choice.

reviewText:
Starts off fun. Great game. Probably the most enjoyable RPG since Ultima7.
The downside to this game is that the puzzles and requirements to overcome certain obstacles often involve trivial details that can be overlooked easily. The only person that might find this fun is someone with an obssession for detail - but then again - opinions vary for what details are important.

The game seems like it has freedom but I no longer believe this. I believe the game shapes the player into a linear gameplay style which requires someone whom spends time collecting trivial objects to overcome tedious puzzles.

Rather than reward players for skill, the gameplay designers seem unable to let go of their taste for  tediousness.

Started fun but lost interest as the game progressed. Focused less on strategy and more on running around looking for items that I never knew existed and yet turned out to be crucial to the story progression.

Combat = freedom to overcome combat any way you want.
Quests = linear chain that hinders progression unless you use a walkthrough. Feels like you are fixing someone's broken code.

I can't recommend the game because as the game progresses, I regret buying a game that I have to invest ridiculous amounts of time into just to get it to progress. Using walkthroughs seems the only way to get my money's worth and that's no fun because it makes the game feel like work.

Quest difficulty is waaaaay too hard for me and combat is too easy.

reviewText:
Without spoiling anything this game is a great example of what happens when you do really well at one thing and half ♥♥♥ everything else.

The Good sides!

The characters and the leveling system are well done, the skills are useful and varied and each type of abilities feel fleshed out and useful. Intelligence based characters have way more options than strength or dex characters as one skill is tied to strength, two to dex, and a whopping five to intelligence for some odd reason. The levels are fleshed out well, they look great, the enemies are challenging and the boss fights are interesting.

The Bad sides!

TRAPS

The game is completely littered with traps, literal traps, that will kill you and your entire group in maybe two hits if you are lucky. Half the time there is no way to avoid these traps, and there is no way to disarm them (save expensive single use items and they don't do much when there are six traps in one hallway). You just trigger them and then very slowly walk around them trying not to die and having to heal yourself over and over again while your tankiest dude takes all the explosions. The amount of traps is just insane and it doesn't add to the gameplay it really just slows it down to a crawl. Some of these situations you will find yourself in will make you scream in rage at the sheer unfairness of the situations the game forces you into, like spawning a giant minefield all around you for pushing a button you have no choice but to push for example.

The crafting system...

It makes no sense whatsoever. You need blacksmithing to make armor and weapons out of metal, crafting for everything else. You can't even improve armor without the crafting skill, which makes no sense seeing as how you make it with blacksmithing. Crafting does literally everything else in the game that involves making things. Downsides you cant find resources after you go through an area once, so there are a finite amount of things you can find. Add a system that gives  you stats randomly on items you make and you have a session of crafting and reloading again and again to try and get decent gear. By the way you have no choice in this since crafting makes better gear than you will ever manage to find since random drops are horrid most of the time. I found a legendary weapon with 1 durability point and couldn't be repaired... why even have it?

The story

It's pretty bland, magic using bad guys are bad, you kill bad guys. Nothing really standing out here,

The biggest problem with the game by far, the most unforgiveable thing they did that makes the game damn near laughable..... NO TIMED AUTOSAVES!!!!

Read that again NO TIMED AUTOSAVES.

You think its not a big deal till you lose yourself in a string of fights, get insta murdered when a ♥♥♥♥♥ character walks into lava for no reason, and then realize that because you havn't gone somewhere new in the past hour you never had a single autosave. It's downright insane that an open RPG in this day and age doesn't have timed autosaves. That's pretty much standard nowadays and the lack of one here is a real pain since you have to constantly remind yourself that you need to save. Add in the BS trap-a-palooza of instant death and you have a good recipe for frustration and rage.

The enemy spawning

Something else the game loves to do to you is spawn enemies seemingly at random. Go open a treasure chest? enemies magically appear, kill a specific enemy, more enemies magically appear, and the best part is when this happens, they tend to be suicidal enemies that explode for massive damage... No way to prevent it other than to already know when its going to happen.

The game is decent as rpg's go, and the closest thing to an updated dungeons and dragons game I've seen in awhile, but the flaws the game has just make it not fun to play. Save yourself the trouble and find something else.

reviewText:
Got through 80% of the game on tactician which is my very first play through.

Must say, the most annoying game i have played in a while. Frustrating to say the least when trying to complete quests. Some side quests started never finish until later on in the game with no real guide... also the game does not give enough hints in exactly what you have to do next... i found myself at times just wandering around just completing quests unintetionally and some quests i have had since the beginning with no real direction or subtle hints as to how to complete it.

The battle mechanics are a great concept. As always i love turnbased games.. annoying how in nearly every fight however i am always the second one to move... allowing all of the enemies to attack, freeze, poison, do a decent amount of damage before i am allowed to play making the iniative portion of a game broken in any respect. In tactician mode there were many times i had to save/load... if that it how the game is meant to work i find my best weapon against any enemy is to save\load and wait for a good roll in some batles.

A very dark story for matire audiences but a choice to have a cartoonish childish artistic desgin??

I will finish the game eventually but the only way to actually complete everything is to either playthrough a couple of times or simply do what everyone else does and wiki everything... the game is poor when providing direction on where to go next... and considering the level of some enemies and areas.. would have been helpful no?? I honestly tried to do my best in completing all of the quests without having to wiki but i dont have all day to play it.

The worst gripe i have is the inventory ui... absolutely dreadful... most of my time spend is cleaning up everyones items...

other than that... the only thing i do like is the storyline and the battle mechanics... i would rate this a solid 6/10

I turned the music off. And played some of my own collection in the back.

I hope the sequal is better...

reviewText:
Pro:
+ interactive map: Boxes can be moved and searched. Hidden passageways behind stuff, explosive barrels, etc.
+ alot of humor
+ turn based: Can be relaxing after a long day to play turn based.

Con:
- Invisible walls: They belong in 1995. Why do developers not get this :( ?
- 3 second sound loops: They drive me insane in this game. Why does the town guard say the same thing fifty times in a minute ? Why ?
- Quicksave spam game
- Inventory puzzle: Managing the inventory is half the game.
- impossible game: Started out with a mage and a  cleric. 4 hours in it became apparant that it was impossible to win a fight with this team so I had to start over. Choose to go fighter & mage. First few battles were a lot better. But then you move to the next map and you have fights of 2 level 2's versus 6 level 3's. Well maybe i was in the wrong map ? Moved north and ran into 5 level 5's instead. Ok that was no good, Went south-west and ran into 6 level 7's.

Can't enjoy a game which requires every battle to be fought 7 different ways before getting past it.

reviewText: The developers clearly knew what they were doing when they created the gameplay for Divinity Original Sin.  However, they failed to build the game well.  Their alleged release of DOS on Linux, Mac, and SeamOS is a complete failure.  The game requires OpenGL 4.2 or above, even though it says 4.x in the system requirements, 4.0 and 4.1 do not work.  Also, at least 90% of standard-issue computers that run linux can handle a maximum of OpenGL 3.3, which doesn't even get close to the requirement set by the idiots here at Lairan Studios.  They failed to notice this fact, and released the game in a way that prevents most Linux users from being able to play the game until newer hardware is available.  And by the time that newer hardware is available, this game will be boring and obsolete.  So in essence, Lairan Studios are liars, and Divinity Original Sin is a stupid game.

reviewText: Coming from pen and paper gaming, and based on all the reviews calling this a classic-style RPG, I had some pretty specific expectations. After 30 minutes I knew this game was not for me. It has an overall childish cartoonish aesthetic, reflected in the grotesque physiques of the player characters, the intentionally corny voice acting, the easy difficulty, etc. If you're looking for the next Baldur's Gate, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
With all the hype and raving reviews this got I'm just finding myself disappointed. There game is huge and there are some good ideas buried in it so but a lot of it it just doesn't work for me, some of the reasons below:

-no quest markers and an unhelpful quest log, this seems to be by design as you are supposed to actually listen to what NPCs are saying, which would be alright expect that...
-annoying voice acting and bad writing, everyone is too verbose and tries too hard to be funny, the story is also slow to get going and when it does it's just a bunch of cliches
-a few too many quests which rely on pixel hunting for tiny switches
-crafting system is random and often nonsensical due to trying to be funny (lock picks = key and soap?), though you'll find a few recipes most you'll have to figure out by combining junk at random, which is made harder by...
-inventory is a mess, can't even craft with another character's things, also there is way too much junk to pick up without knowing what's going to be useful
-most loot seems to be of the Diablo style random variety, with only a handful of unique items

On a more positive note (though far from perfect):
-the combat system is dynamic and reacts to the environment quite a bit, this is probably the game's strongest point but I found this to be a hindrance just as often with terrain features getting in the way of my ranged attacks or blocking my sight, and then having to slide the mouse around inch by inch to find the one spot where my shot or fireball would not get blocked
-the combo system is also cool, though once you get down to it there aren't all that many useful combinations and it's hard to get different characters to synergyze (air mage wants things wet for the stun, but that puts out the enemies you set on fire earlier, and there's friendly fire so your figher gets hit too) and just as above you'll end up hindering yourself just as often (for example oil and fire creates an explosion and a fire field, but also smoke which stops you from targeting things in it on the next turn)
-the character system gives you a lot of options and you can mix skills and abilities freely, though some combos are definitely better than others and there are quite a few trap choices

Above annoyances aside combat still manages to be the best aspect of this game, the spells and abilities look nice and do have some interesting and varied effects, and I can't say anything bad about the graphics and area design either. The game does look gorgeous overall and it is obvious a lot of work went into it, which has me conclude that even with the above faults this isn't some half ♥♥♥♥♥ indie effort, a few years ago I might even consider this a masterpiece, nowadays I expect more polish and quality of life features though.

Overall this seems like a deliberate attempt to go old school, without understanding that those beloved classics games were great despite their faults, not because of them.

reviewText:
I was super excited to see a classic isometric RPG (Baldur's Gate) with depth (alternate paths to quest completion), but it turns out this is a heaping pile of garbage not worth your time or money and let me explain why -

Poisoned undead will heal each turn.
No big deal, right? Just don't use the core skill for one of the default characters that summons a poison creature and you're early enough in the game to have no other options. Also, too bad for you ending up with a sword with a poison chance-on-hit.
Oh, did I mention this was on the easiest difficulty? Did it never occur to anyone to limit hostile healing as a difficulty modifier?

... this is my third save game to re-start because I've ended up making sub-optimal choices and a complete re-start was the best path... that's after reading guides online to not-ruin my characters at creation.

Save your money, go buy a deck of cards, and pick one card out. If it's the ace of spaces, congrats! You win! Imagine you just played through some heroic fantasy story. If it's any other card, go bang your head into a wall for your choice of 2 to 15 hours before shuffling the cards and trying again. There you go. That's the game for you.

reviewText:
I hate it.

1. The combat is clunky and boring. It's turn based, but like every turn based RPG ever, it really isn't. Enemies just take turns whenever they feel like it, sometimes acting twice before you get to go once. You spend most of the time watching enemies move and attack while you do nothing. Every minor fight takes at least 10 minutes, often longer. There is a bar at the top that shows what order turns will be taken in, but its accuracy is laughable. You'll look at it, plan out the entire turn, and then watch as enemies take extra turns and yours probably gets skipped.

2. There are too many enemies that heal and revive each other, with no warning that they can do so. Expect to spend 30 minutes mopping up enemies only to find out that the last guy left has the ability to revive every single one of them in one turn. Hope you had a quicksave before the fight started.

3. Everything from the battle system to elemental interactions to crafting, trading, repairing, and identifying items has a complex system behind it that isn't like any other game. Sound cool? Maybe it is, but good luck figuring it out because the game doesn't tell you how anything works. This has to be the most user-unfriendly game I have ever played.

4. There are quests that you can miss forever if you do the wrong thing.

5. You have choices" in quests
date: except you'll often be harshly punished for choosing wrong.\n\n6. There are a ton of side quests. Again

reviewText: The Enhanced Edition may have a few extra things in it in terms of gameplay, but I think I'd rather actually play the regular edition.  There is more voice acting now, but they sacrificed quality for quantity, so I'd rather not have it than have to listen to these people talk.  The voice acting now sounds like the voice actors are making fun of the game.  Also, the random chatter loops that went off every 30 seconds before?  You thought those were annoying?  Some of them don't even have delays anymore.  They not only didn't fix the most annoying thing about the game, but made it even more annoying.  Some of the writing for the dialogue is worse, too.  It's like someone was trying to sabotage the game.\n\nUnless you have to play the game with a gamepad, I would stick to the regular edition.  The enhanced edition just seems to have enhanced how annoying things are.  D:OS is a great game, but the EE is the opposite of an improvement.

reviewText: This is literally one of the worst games I have ever played, and that includes some truly awful early access garbage. It lures you in with the promise of epic party-based adventure, but delives an experience like slogging through sewage. There are no quest markers or pointers at all, so 75% of the time you will be wandering around doing absolutely nothing because you have no idea what you're supposed to be doing or where you need to go to advance the story. That doesn't even cover combat, where everything you face is much stronger than you. This wouldn't be a problem if there were only a few mobs attacking at once, but they will swarm your party, outnumbering you 3 to 1 at least. You can't grind to get over that level disparity either, so good luck getting anywhere in the story. I have to say, I was really hopeful for this game. The story and the world seems great, but this game is unplayable at best. At worst, it feels like a scam. DO NOT play this game. What a waste of $40.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Nice graphics except character models
- Good mini map

Cons:
- Insultingly bad story probably intended for 5 year old children
- Dumb and dumber characters
- Idiotic dialogs
- Boring world without any atmosphere
- Ugly character models
- No true classes, they just define the starting skills - characters are just walking skill bags
- Inquisitor class with skills like a professional witch
- Obsession with element combinations screwed up class balance and made melee fighters useless
- Spell combos get old pretty fast
- Combat lacks auto battle for weak encounters
- Doesn't deserve to be called an RPG - should have been called Divinity Tactics instead
- Combat easily topped by most strategy games with tactical combat on the market like AOW3, King's Bounty, HoMM, etc.
- Clunky camera and controls

reviewText:
The game is unplayable without following a walkthrough.

The choice is to either walk around while touching, talking to, and trying everything, or consulting the walkthrough. If taking the time to talk to everyone, touch everything, and try all approaches appeals to you then go ahead and buy this game. If you want to stand even a remote chance of getting it right without help then look elsewhere.

Main quest? Forget about it. You have to do all this quest-meandering in order to get to the main one, and you can't even come close to completing it if you try to skip or delay something. You can't just walk around and level up until things become easier. That's mainly because the starting town is surrounded by certain death on all sides. Players are forced to complete things in a very specific order to progress in the game and there's no rhyme or reason to the order so players are forced into time consuming trial and error.

Imagine being stuck in a large trap and being given a choice of doors and behind the doors is another set of choices. You have to go to door three, then door one, then go back to start and choose door one, then door five. It just keeps going that way. You can't just figure out a way.

You have to play rock, paper, scissors with psychic NPCs to win some arguments and it's totally lame.

Things like crazy design and dialogue decisions(really, Scarlett? Can you please be more consistent? Are you naughty or nice?!), nearly impossible difficulty, and completely nonsensical chronology with regards to the quests make me not recommend this game at all. It's such a shame, too! It's like a modern Baldurs Gate that is a massive pain in the butt to play. I really want to like it but I literally have to either walk around until I figure out what I'm supposed to do(not going to happen) or consult the walkthrough(not fun at all).

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but there’s no way around it. This game is bad.

I’ll start with the gameplay, which for me is the most important aspect of any game above all. I’d like to preface this part by saying that I enjoy difficult games. I liked the original XCOM and the new (in which I gave up classic ironman mode after 30 attempted playthroughs due to frustrating bugs), Master of Orion 2, Dark Souls, Ninja Gaiden, and the Megaman series. With most RPGs such as Dragon Age and Shining Force 2, I usually start with turning up the difficulty to hard. I’m not even saying that I’m particularly good at these games, merely that I enjoy playing games at this difficulty level. So please believe me when I say that even at normal difficulty, 90% of the combat encounters in D:OS are unfairly balanced and unsatisfying.

The enemies almost always go first, so most of the pacing of the game is dictated by the AI. When you do wipe and have to reload (for the first 8 character levels, for me, it was probably an average of 1-3 times per fight), it’s usually due to not knowing some gimmick or some powerful ability, or because of the sheer amount of damage the enemies put out. It’s not unusual to have to reload a fight because you didn’t have the right resistance potions or buffs pre-loaded, so you wind up with your knight dead in the second round, or your entire party AoE’d down to 33% in the first round, or half your party disabled for two rounds. Therefore, success relies mainly on making preparations based on the party wipe you just reloaded from—it’s unlikely that you will be able to adapt to the nonsense thrown at you in the very first encounter.

An example of a fight that’s impossible to adapt to the first time around is a fight with a wizard called Raddagoth. He goes first and immediately summons about 6 strong golems (which can cast spells and shoot disabling elemental arrows) and in the same turn goes invisible. I figure I just have to AoE where he went invisible, but no dice (it turns out he also has time to run away to a specific spot on the map in the same turn). The golems deal out mad damage, with the bigger one taking out half my characters’ HP pools a pop, but I barely manage to kill them without a death. Raddagoth reappears and fights us mano e mano. He casts 4 disables a round, but I manage to get him down to 66% before he successfully saves on five of my own disables in a row before summoning another 6 golems and going invisible again. They appear randomly, so the melee golems appear directly in the midst of my squishy ranged characters, and since they act immediately upon appearing, they take out half my party in that one turn. Time to reload.

In addition to the reasons given above, you will find yourself reloading more often in this game than in some others of its type (like Dragon Age) simply because they made resurrecting party members a chore in which you’re forced to continually hunt for limited and elusive resurrection scrolls. Also, be prepared to often take trips back to town and have your party members take 10-second naps on a random bed to heal up, since there’s no ability to rest on the fly.
I’ve read that the game is easier after level 10, and indeed the game is feeling easier as my own characters are approaching that level, but that first 8-12 hours or so was pretty excruciating.

I also have a long list of minor yet frustrating gripes. The character progression is boring and the skill book purchase system is boring. The mouse pointer will sometimes miss a moving enemy collision box and make your character move instead of attack, often forcing a game reload due to loss of position. The game forces your spell reticles to snap-to enemy targets, making it difficult to target empty terrain for AoE purposes. It’s sometimes difficult to distinguish when your characters are in contact with an environmental effect, causing your party members to be electrocuted, poisoned, etc. unnecessarily. Your character screams “RARE FIND!” or some other quip no matter how mundane the item is that you’re picking up. The rock-paper-scissors argument resolution game is annoying.  Respecing is an unrealistic option, since it forces you to re-buy all of the expensive skill books that you had (why someone thought this restriction was necessary is beyond me).

For those who are more interested in the story, there’s nothing to write home about there.The object is to gather the dragonballs to prevent the end of the world and also to prevent the resurrection of the ultimate bad guy. I haven’t completed the game at this point but I’m going to hazard a guess and say that you’re going to attempt to prevent his resurrection but then end up fighting him anyway. I’m impressed by the laziness of the cliché, but I’m even more impressed that they actually combined two big cliches to make it even worse.

The setting? You’re fighting your way through an unremarkable land plagued by…you guessed it, orcs and undead. Yawn. To top it off, the NPCs, especially the shopkeepers, have the most annoying accents and dialogues ever conceived.

They way the game throws the plot at the player is abrupt and jarring. For the first fifteen minutes you think you’re investigating an ordinary murder when suddenly one of the dragonballs teleports you to the Arcane Sanctuary from Diablo II. After seeing a space dragon through a giant telescope, you’re told you’re charged with stopping the onset of the end of time. In your journal this quest is labeled “A Source Hunter’s Journey” as if this is just, you know, “all in a day’s work”—hyuk hyuk. The magnitude of the quest could not be any greater, but I just don’t find myself inspired by it.

Again, I really wanted to like this game after enjoying Divine Divinity (granted, for me it was nothing more significant than a guilty pleasure), but I’m having trouble getting through this game. Unfortunately, I can’t say I recommend it.

TL;DR: Combat is unfair/overly difficult. Combat mechanics and other game features are unpolished. Story sucks.

reviewText: This is absolutely one of the worst games I have ever played. Okay, that is a bit of an exaggeration, but from the rave reviews I have seen you would think that this was some kind of masterpeice. I didn't know that this game was a kickstarter when I purchased it. Found out too late. the people who have rated this highly are over rating this pile of trash based on the fact that this is an indy title... or they are masochists. There are so many things that are so frustratingly wrong with this game, and my time is too valuable to waste on this any longer. Take my word for it. or don't, your choice. just let this review crawl around in the back of your mind before you purchase this time sucking boring waste of a game.

reviewText: I bought it after almost 1,5 years after release and it is still very buggy. Besides that buginess Its also overly complicated without a reason. This game reinvented a lot of bicycles and boy they are all clunky! Complexity over simlicity, chaos over order approach. After playing it about 10 hours I cant understand how its skill-ability-attribute system works. I'm getting points but have no idea where to invest them. I cant get used to a cumbersome interface (with controller at least). There is no single item pool to all characters, be ready to spend a lot of hours distributing and comparing stuff between team members. Movement on the battlefield is frustratingly imprecise, you always end up missing clicks and doing wrong actions. You move too slow outside of battle. There is no feel of structure and progression to game, you become instantly overwhelmed with countless things to do and learn after game starts. And this is all on top of very generic uninspired fantasy setting.\nThe one thing I regret about this game -  I played it over 2 hours and cant refund now.

reviewText:

And if you like to read a lot, resolve puzzle , have patience have a lots of strategy and like tabletop D&D or warhammer then you may like the game. personaly i like D&D but didn't like that game, when you will play you will know what i'm talking about.

here is my gameplay ...save game, get inside a place, talk to someone, loose on a rock paper scisor game, load the game, repeat until I win. go outside the village, save, run in an invisible mine(**and get killed), reload, repeat walking instead, save, meet orcs, get kill by orcs, reload, meet the same orc, get kill again, reload, return to village, save, talk to people hopping getting xp on completing a quest, reload because I loosed at rock paper scisor game again... try to find a proof, placing a foot inside a room and loose all dialogue with a main character because it was his room, reload, try again. take 5 minutes to kill a door because I can't unlock anything. knocking my head because the theft was in a whishing well. try to unlock things with the theft,try to pickpocket with theft... get the theft kill because he is no use, and killing a door *is easier. save, talk to a suspect, talk to the other suspect, read your log book because you don't know what to do, save retalk to a suspect, retalk to the other suspect, save, try to kill everybody *( in the village to have some fun), reload...

pros :  - fully voiced,
- nice graphics, animation
- good sounds,
- lots of contents... and random crap.
** doesn't crash
** load fast
**as stressful as playing chess.

con :  - heroes are slooooowwwww. (**expect to walk a lot without any action)

reviewText: Just like the original version, this is a game that has the potential to be great but suffers from a slew of severe UI/gameplay errors that completely ruin my ability to take it seriously.  Larian made so many wonderful improvements to the game for the enhanced edition, yet seemingly ignored consistent, severe complaints like sloppy controls and issues with units' idle animations playing during targeting, causing players to misclick and waste their turn.  For a game that prides itself on tactical

reviewText:
Didn't like the first version, the non-enhanced.. And didn't like the enhanced version either. I guess turn-based RPG's aren't my type of games. I bought the game back in 2014, and I thought it looked like Diablo or TorchLight, but the view is a troll and the game is not like any kind of hack'n slash game, i.e TorchLight or Diablo. Don't buy if you're an enemy of turnbased attacks, i.e, you attack a few times using Attack Points, AP and after that is done, enemy attacks using their AP, and then it goes back to you, so simply it's a turn-based game and that is not my type of game, and it was really boring these 15 minutes I tried to play without crying. 39,99€ I could have put into eating pizza instead went to a complete failed game to me.

If you buy it because the images looks like Diablo or TorchLight, just rethink and watch YouTube let's plays etc. Save the buck, don't get tricked!

However, I'm not saying the game looks bad. Graphics are pretty decent, story looks pretty okay, voices are alright and it's not the typical chinese copycat type of game. It's just, not my taste.

reviewText:
at first I had the hardest time in combat with this game and figuring out what to do.  But if you take your time, listen to the NPCs and figure out combinations for combat you will have a  much better time.  If you're on fire, use a rain spell or water ballon to put it out, but dont forget that makes you more susceptible to being stunned by lightning attacks or frozen.

my one biggest gripe in this game, is during battle when your target bobbles around when you're trying to click them to attack, sometimes you click to move instead.  This can be incredibly frusturating as it wastes that character's turn and can drag them through harmful effects.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Excellent game.  Plenty of glitches (blind actually does nothing) but a really good game even with them.  I played 70 hours or so co-op and beat it on tactition mode.  Honestly don't bother playing any other mode than tactition, I wish there was actually a more difficult mode - but its still tons of fun.

There are lots of puzzles in game that if you don't read the books lying around you won't know what to do.  (my favorite was a set of cardinal directions, but you had to notice the floor had a compass that didn't point north.)

The combats great, the puzzles are mostly fantastic. (there are 1 or 2 that are really lame) so if you like turn based tactical combat and a game that encourages you to bypass mechanics in clever ways if you happen to have the stats, scrolls, or spells for it this is a good game for you.

The crafting is really complicated and not clear at all.  Its the worst part of this game for sure.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Very well polished turn based RPG.

Here are some things I dont like (played on tactician mode)
- The first few hours of the game puts way too much emphasis on exploring the town of Cyseal, both for the murder investigation and robbing people. If you want enough supplies and skillbooks to go out exploring you are advised to rob every building in the town with Scoundrel invisiblity. It feels stupid, they could have put in some defenses aganist this exploit, but since you kinda have to do it to get enough gold its marketed as freedom of gameplay instead of cheesy busy-work.
- The repetitive NPC phrases is so depressing. How can this not have been fixed? Its been a joke with this game since the start and the fact that you still hear the same phrases EVERY 30 SECONDS is such a troll move by Larian.
- The spell book is too cluttered IMO, its not the worst crime since most of the spells have a least some use but it feels like such a chore to have spells/consumables/arrows/grenades to all think about. Some form of consolidation would have been better
- I dont like turn based games that allow you to cast spells before a fight. Its too tempting to exploit and I feel its a problem of game design that shouldnt be put on the player to deciede.

I havent really mentioned the reasons I like this game so much because you will see for yourself why its worth your time pretty quickly.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
this game is amazing! I'm about 200 hours in and still haven't beat it. I keep starting over looking for the perfect way and then I just change my mind and start again. Do I want to 2 brute warriors with healing mages? Do I want to go the standard Warrior, Thief, Archer, Mage combo? Do I want to run a Tank, Healer, Crafter, Mage? Do I want one mage to specialize in Fire and another specialize in curses? So many combos and party configs. The story is also perfect, the voice acting is perfect, the graphics are perfect. Only 3 things bug me.

1. Targeting: Your archer's turn is up, you target this nasty Ogre with a big club who wants to make mince meat of you. You click to shoot your trusty arrow at him and... OMG he swayed back and forth in his standard idle animation, you clicked the ground instead, your wimpy archer walks over to the Ogre and stands next to him. Oh and now your turn is over since you walked all that way, now it's the Ogres turn to smash the ♥♥♥♥ out of your archer with his club.... UGH!!!! It happens to often the targeting system is crap. talking to bunny rabbit or a tiny mouse, it's incredibly hard because you can't click on them. Did you want to move forward and attack the next foe in line? No, apparently your warrior wanted to waste his turn looting the dead skelton during a battle. I mean you clicked on the ground where that dead skeleton was, that must have been what you wanted to do. So during battle to act you have to be very patient and move your mouse to the exact spot, then see how the idle animation works, and time your click for when they are under it. You have to move your mouse ever so slowly to the spot and keep it there for 5 seconds to make sure it actually does what you say it will.

2. Hidden clicks. This kind of ties in with the targeting. But the graphics are perfect and hidden in these are some super hidden clicks that if you don't move your mouse to the exact spot you will miss important aspects of the game. For example: There is a room later on in the game you have to click 5 tiny buttons to get into this middle room and fight 6 demons. I moved my mouse meticulously over the entire terrain looking for these hidden buttons, but the only way I could continue was to look up online where it was and even when it told me I had trouble finding it. Early on the characters say stuff like I spotted something" but later on there are key places where you just drag your mouse all over the terrain inch by inch looking for secrets. This is not fun.

3. Two players max! You have to hack it to get 4 players working and it doesn't work the best. A 4 player group is pretty key in nearly every other game I've played. So we all played through the story mode 1st
date: and then went back and hacked our 4 player mode so we wouldn't miss anything and could enjoy the game together. But only being able to play with 1 friend really bummed me out. But if you like single player or just one friend at a time you won't notice this.\n\nOther than that though the game is perfect. The spells vary and work together amazingly. Dop oil on bad guys

reviewText: I highly recommend this game to any lover of RPG games.  Besides the story being fantastic, the voices are incredible, the crafting system challenging, the decisions on where to take your character (c;♥♥♥/professions) are so numerous that I had to go back and play it again with a totally different set of classes.  The combat's are challenging as well, but, the second time I went through this (actually, I am currently on my second run), I find the combats much quicker and easier to get through as I have not made the mistakes of taking certain skills to early that I made in the first run.  As you will see if you get this game, there are to many choices and not enough skill points to try them all in a single run.  Plus, i missed so much stuff the first time through that a few extra skill points in perception opened my eyes (literally) to so many hidden traps and mounds to find buried treasure.  Take you time and enjoy this game rather than running through it as fast as you can.  There are gems in this game that are awesome and you can miss if you rush through.  Enjoy!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is my first review ever on Steam.  Sorry to be that silent lurker sort, but I figured it was time I contributed to the community.  After all, I do waste way too much time playing games.

In all honesty; this is one of the best RPGs I have ever played.  And I have played way too many of them.

Leveling actually makes a difference.  The spells are cool and well done.  Voice acting is good throughout the game, which is really rare.  The use of 'the elements', for/against you is a sort of a new idea and well executed and I can't believe nobody else has really done it like this.

The story is kind of basic but it works well and gets the player involved enough.  I would have preferred some sort of more crazy unexpected twist in the plot.

It very re-playable, trying different types of characters and (for me) crafting more.

All in all this game is near perfect.  They have done a very good job.  In my estimation; as good as and in some ways even better than Balder’s Gate, which is difficult for me to admit.

reviewText: Plot and style make this game the reigning heir to Baldur's Gate. The plot is a little convoluted and the dialogue and narrative tend towards the dramatic, but I think that's intentional and it's easy to skip if that's not your bag. The turn-based combat system is awesome. The point-based character design system is great, too. The class element is really just RP window dressing--you can individualize characters all you want. The co-op is really solid. I've played 46 hours so far with my wife and we've enjoyed every minute.

reviewText:
Divinity: Origina Sin.... o boy that game is evil, very evil it will take you lots and lots of hours and then when you think that you are near completing entire game you will realised that you only just chewed on the top of it!
This game with Pillars of Eterninty and Fallout 4 are top 3 best RPG`s I played this 2015. Game has nice colorful graphic very comfortable to eye, intresting elemental system (you don`t want to be standing in water when your friend is casting lightning spell on enemy who is also in that water). Ah yes coop system, probably one of best options in game you can play entire game with a friend in co-op mode (you can even play it in split screen mode if you have two controlers, screen only splits when one player becomes too distant from another player) but entire game is fun played solo but is ten times more fun if you play it with a friend (just be careful that you play it with a friend who actualy likes this kind of RPG games and are not expecting classic Diablo hack`n`slash) game is turn based in combat but in general is real time. Combat is still turn based and is done really well!
All in all I have no bad stuff to tell about Divinity Original Sin game is really fun and is also having really nice humor in it (not too much of it but still has fun parts, like a shell who asks you to throw her back in sea). Also I forgot to mention often you enter in discusion`s with your partner around decisions you make and then you enter in rock, paper, scisors  argument (though it still pays up to have some points in charm)
Final verdict is just get the game it pays up every penny!!!

reviewText:
NETFLIX Score- ***1/2

I haven't played long, but what I can tell you is that I've had to start over twice because of the classes I picked. If you don't have a healer, you are screwed, no ifs, ands, or buts about it. To be more specific you need to have a very specific type of healer, either a Hydrosophist or Man-At-Arms, anything else just wont cut it. I wont include any spoilers, but lets just say if you want to play a mage, you will need to take Hydrosophist, and if you want to play a fighter, well, you guessed it. Rogue? Well they're punching bags and probably will be the reason why you carry resurrection scrolls.

There are certain builds that just outclass everything else, dual wielding wands is an example. A lot of people put one point in dual wield and then the rest in wands, simply because it gives their main hand a bonus, but any more than one point in dual wield doesn't seem to be worth it. Another thing a lot of people do is make one magic character with all the magic schools, why? Because they can have a cacaphony of spells that means they'll always be able to maximize their APs. For me this kind of stuff gets boring fast, but maybe you'll like it.

I don't hate the game, but it's not as good as the hype makes it out to be. It's not Neverwinter Nights 3, it's not even Baldur's Gate 3, though it seems to try to be. In the end, I could've downloaded Baldur's Gate on my tablet and been just as happy. I got it on sale so I wont complain to much.

edit- I fluctuate between liking and hating this game. Even on easy the fights can be annoying and the fact you can't rest makes it so tedious at times. On more than one occassion I've had ot quit because I didn't have the time to wait for my party to heal up, since you have to manually cast spells then wait for the timer on the spell and wash and repeat. It literally took me 10 minutes to heal up my party. IF YOU DON'T HAVE A LOT OF TIME TO PLAY, THIS IS NOT THE GAME FOR YOU!!!
