reviewText:
This game is an excellent game. I mean I love how they did a total Voice over.

This game can be hard at first. Just ask around and eventually you will find what you are looking for.

I haven't played long but I already like it. I mean it could be better if they put Quest Markers. Alot of people complaining that it is to difficult. It really isn't you just have to think instead of just doing whatever.

I love the quest system and how it doesn't just tell you what you have to do and then complete it. It makes a log of what you have talked about or found out and what you should do to complete it it is interesting at the very least.

I rate this game 10/10.

Strongly reccomend for Paper and book Dungeons and Dragons fans.

reviewText: I enjoyed Divinity : Original Sin -vanilla version a lot, it was like a really good classic rpg on steroids. This enhanced edition is like that roided up game on steroids. reviewText: One of the best and most engaging true RPGs I've played in some time. Beneath the surface of the deceptively basic UI, there's a robust and flexible RPG system that can accomodate a variety of class archetypes and playstyles, albeit with a learning curve for some. Veteran RP Gamers may recognize the influence of the likes of Ultima VII in the (mouse and keyboard) UI and story, and LARPers might appreciate the conversation conflict resolution mechanic. This is the first game I've played in a long time that I can honestly recommend to anyone who enjoys RPG games of ANY kind.

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin is the modern-day comeback of the old-school, isometric RPG.

Complete freedom in character creation, non-combat stats that can contribute to your advancement in the story, and open-ended ways to complete quests. Even the crafting is open-ended, and you can combine seemingly random things together to create new items.

The Enhanced Edition makes the previous version obsolete. It is now fully voiced, has controller support, and cleans up the UI.

Overall, this game is a must-play for anyone who is into this kind of RPG.

7.5/10 Good" to "Very good""

reviewText:
Shoutout to the devs for giving their hard work on making this game a blast!
Bought the game 2 days before EE released (was not aware of the upcoming EE version when I bought it).

-Before EE-

After playing the previous version for severals hours, I'll say I had tons of fun with my friend. Like, running around looking for clues and emptying each room we cross into to get some golds for repairs ;), hard tuff combats which we had to devise this and that strategy to go through a horde of enemies. And lastly, the Freedom that was offered to this game. It was that good.

-After EE-

Once we (my friend and I) had set foot into EE (after a long hour creating our own class and stats), we had noticed the difference already. There was the voice acting which greatly enhance the immersion in the game, the skills added like Dual Wielding and Wands which is a great addition and needed for a rogue like me to backstab dem uglies, a few items like grenades and also notice a slight changes in the enemy strategy in a good way.

Amazed on how the devs put their time and effort into creating Enhanced Edition. Just want to say thank you so much for giving me a Well Polished and a GREAT game.

Totally Recommend this game.

reviewText:
Strong contender for my 2015 game of the year.  Enhanced edition worked out a lot of the kinks in the original game and it warranted a second playthrough.

The good:
* really satisfying combat
* loads of customization options
* lots of freedom
* nice graphics

The bad:
* story is passable at best (to be fair, it doesn't take itself too seriously)
* multi-classing only makes sense if you're intelligence based
* the game is hardest at the beginning and gets progressively easier
* some hitches and crashes

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10

Let me start by saying this game is not for everyone but it is good. The dialog and combat has an old school rpg feel that works for me. The combat reminds me a lot of dragon age: origins but with more of a tabletop (dungeons & dragons, pathfinder etc.) ruleset spliced into it. The dialog and interaction has a similar vibe although I would say this game wants you to explore more and does not hold any hands.

The pacing of the game is decent although one of the very first quests related to a murder has a very specific way about how you complete it and I did not like that. It's almost as if you have to discover how the game wants you to play. It can be rewarding but honestly it's easy to miss key game mechanics such as trap doors, wall switches etc. so early on in the game when you don't know what you're doing. Once I made it past that though I really started enjoying the core game.

Good combat, vast skill & magic system mixed in with the occassional important decision do make this very enjoyable.

reviewText:
Divinity the enhanced version is a solid turn based RPG.  Basing my viewpoint in contrast to past experiences with Baldur's Gate, Ice wind Vale, Neverwinter etc

The enhanced version is vastly superior to the original game in both function and stability

As a turn based RPG:
- innovative and immersive environmental impact of spells
- some measure of chess like turn based decision making
- compelling story, early game being stronger than end game
- some very interesting skill/class combinations, especially when combined with ennvironmental interaction possibilities
- overly easy to exploit, I'll not outline them here but self restraint once you figure them out is essential to enjoyment
- inventory management is horrid
- crafting system is fun yet horrid in design.  It actually became less usable with the enhanced edition
- graphics are pleasant but not ground breaking
- voice acting:  I turned off the sound, that pretty much covers it

This game was crowd funded at its start, the enhanced version refined many of those rough edges but beware you will still nick your self on the occasional bur.

If you are looking for a fun turn based RPG its definately one of the better ones of the last 10 years.

reviewText:
In this day of DLC-happy games, (unfinished in my eyes),  it's refreshing to see a game so complete, the details so well thoughtout.  This game is made and executed the way games like the Baldur's Gate series and the Elder Scrolls series are with an open world, a solid storyline and plenty of side quests to complete along the way.  I'm playing the single-player game in Adventuring mode which is the easiest one.  Some pluses I especially like:

1.  My two main characters affect each other through the choices they make which add or subtract to their abilities and to those of the rest of their team.
2.  Rift travel.   These are portals that are activated when approached.  Once activated you can step into any portal and travel to any other you've activated.  (There are more features but it would borderline on a spoiler to talk about it.)
3.  Teleportation:  You acquire 2 teleporter pyramids through a quest.  They are linked to each other.  You drop one somewhere you would like to return to, go on about your business, click on the pyramid in your pack and your team is transported back to the one you dropped.
4.  Lots and lots, and lots, and lots, and lots of armor, weapons and items to choose from.
5.  A great crafting/recipe system that allows you to make useful things without the grinding!  You discover the Recipes by placing items in the slots on your Experiment page or acquire a recipe book that teaches it to you when you read the book. (The crafting system includes cooking, blacksmithing, potion-making, tailoring and spell-making and others, all on one character).
6.  Dynamic and well-thoughtout dialogue.  (example:  My main character had purchased very expensive armor for her fighter.  After he put it on he commented how expensive it was and thanked her for it.)  It's little details like that that let you know how much the developers loved what they were making.
7.  You are not tied to the skill-set you chose for your character at character creation.  (example: My Wayfarer has her archery skills but now also has the ability to use wands and staves, as well as decent rogue skills.)
8.  Lots of companions to chose from to complete your 4-person team anyway you like, (single-player).  Some you can rent"
recommended: others you meet along the way and invite them to join.  You can tell a team member to take a hike so you can switch him out for someone else and then put him back on the team when you need him again.  He is sent to a warm and fuzzy "rest area" with the other "Island of Misfit Toys" you've temporarily retired. You can adventure alone or with 2
hoursPlayed: 3 or 4 companions.\n9. Using tools for crafting

For all new players there is a cave/dungeon you are given a choice to enter to before you reach the first town.  It's a very clever and useful way to introduce you to the dynamics of the game and some of the trickier traps you will come across later on. Obvious things like water-beats-fire but it shows you a possible way to do it you may not have thought of

reviewText:
Its a stupendous RPG that is literally everything I love about the genre! Gorgeous art and scenery, intricate story with frequent breaks for goofy jokes, and a soundtrack that I wish was playing all the time in real life!
Don't forget the combat! A deep, turn based combat system that frequently gets chaotic and kills all my characters because I made the slightest of errors! Most of the time I'm grinning like an idiot as I load my save game.
It has an environmental hazard system that makes perfect sense, for a fantasy world. Fire makes you burn for some damage every turn, but water spells put out the fire and make the floor wet and electric spells become area of effect in wet areas, but freeze spells make the floor slippery and everybody moving on ice can fall and lose a turn! There's also poison and oil, and most of them interact for mayhem!
Yeah, I'm having fun!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
oh boy, oh boy, where shall I start?
The amazing atmosphere? Or the great combat? The stellar voice acting or the outstanding sound design?
Divinity: Original Sin is a RPG that surely delivers as advertised.

Pros:
- great graphics and settings, there's some gorgeous backgrounds and all powers look neat
- sound! absolutely outstanding.
- great voice acting all over the game. not every dialogue is voiced, but those that are do entertain
- round based combat system. terrain is of importance, so is line of sight and the ground (which can be manipulated)
- classes. the ones I have played all feel satisfying and relevant
- all female party, ftw!
- story is not great, but serves the game well
- few but memorable encounters
- nicely scaled to give more experienced tacticians a run for their money
- love the soundtrack
- You can talk to animals!!!
- micromanagement

Cons:
- sometimes wonky controls with the gamepad
- camera can be a bit of a pain
- if you are, as I am, a completionist, then this game will take time. very, very slow indeed (this is half a con, at best)

Verdict:

Divinity: Original Sin is, in its Enhanced Edition, a wonderful treat for any RPG fan, with a keen eye for immersion and its setting.
Be aware that this is more oriented towards the pen & paper crowd, seeing many options to avoid conflict entirely and offering many an approach towards solving the issues at hand.
They ain't kidding when they say 'over 100 hours of gameplay. I'm 40 hours in and entered the second area. it's not big as much as it is challenging and vastly entertaining.

I got it on a sale
date: but I would gladly pay the full price for this gem of a game"

While it seems like the game can be fun and rewarding, I just don't have the time or patience to walk around a town trying to solve a murder for 9 hours (because Im STILL not done) before I do any combat.\n\nEdit: After restarting my game and looking up a few guides, the beginning became substantially more bearable. If you can stomach through the starter city (which actually can be pretty fun if you know where to look), youll be rewarded with the deepest and most interesting rpg I've played in years. Solid 9/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is one of those games I feel myself to be in a good condition to review. I may not have completed it perfectly, as my friend and I did not quite have the patience for that. I got around 70% of the achievements and downed the final boss after over 100 hours of play. I can see it being very possible to do it quicker, but playing it slowly and enjoying it is definitely worthwhile with this game. There are probably better qualified reviewers still, but at least I would make a baseline qualification as an amateur. That aside, this game incorporates some of the greatest ideas in the genre of top-down, party-based RPGs. Here is a list, some of them sound dry and factual, but also contain experience and opinion:

1. It has a free-roaming co-op mode where you can separate and join as you please
2. You can write notes on the maps
3. The log book keeps a good track of the quests, which there are many
4. It has a competent levelling system where you have to make tough choices about how to level your character
5. There are five rarities of random loot to keep the rewards fresh for replays.
6. There is a reason to keep and use scrolls. They get around cooldowns and the spells limited to 1/battle
7. It has great non-combat encounters which involve diplomatic choices and interesting puzzles.
8. It balances between high magic an low magic in the setting by having a lot of magic, but few actual spellcasters
9. It has a good turn-based combat system with a calculation of AP for all actions that is balanced.

reviewText:
Contrary to popular opinion, I like the original version better and have close to 300 hours in it and multiple playthroughs.

The Enhanced Edition IS more user friendly, as far as skill-checks and such are concerned and it's nice that it's fully voiced but the voice acting is atrociously bad. I don't know where they found these people but they certainly aren't the same ones that did the meager voice acting in the original edition, which was superbly done.

At any rate, this is an amazing game.... truly a work of art. It is very tedious and slow though, and if you don't like these old-schoolish RPGs you'd probably be better off to steer clear of this one. If you're just plain unfamiliar with them then you should probably ask some questions in the forums, read some reviews and watch lots of gameplay videos before you buy it. This isn't like Dragon Age or Skyrim. It's a whole different type of game and it isn't for everybody.

Character customisation does not in any way hinder you of your play style. It is rare that I find games that will allow the creation of a character type that will adjust. I made a tanky character, that deals a ♥♥♥♥ ton of damage, AND heals allies.

The companions in the game you can actually stand, and it actually makes me like them... with the exception of the know it all mage.

reviewText: Speant about 194 hours in the classic original sin. Enhanced Edition delivers in every way the classic did and more. Voice acting is on point at least for the main story so far. Some towns folk can be annoying, and I can't say im the biggest fan of my characters screaming out their abilities like they are from the DBZ universe. But I can overlook this as they tweaked the game in so many other great ways. First and most noteable for me was the optimization they preformed on this version vs. the classic. classic would run for me between 30-60 fps mostly around 45 depending on where i was in the game. The Enchanced edition runs at ultra with 80+ FPS at all times, I havent seen a dip below 60. If you like CRPGs this is the one to get.

Me and my freind played through the game swimmingly, untill we got to the door of the source temple. we didnt have all the inherit stones so we gathered 14 and thought this would be enough. ofc we didnt get through, and after some googling we found out that its the homestead portals that triggers it.
Problem is, zixzax is just standing there, telling us to jump into the portal and see whats inside. we have all the portals in the homstead except two. The last one we unlocked was either the trading emporium or the armory. either way we are stuck.

I just can't grasp how such a huge gamebreaking bugg is still left unattended to. There are apperantly loads of people having trouble with this, and it leaves me with a taste of disgust towards a game that i would outherwise love to death.

reviewText:
I was afraid to try out this EE after playing (edit: trying to play) the director's cut of WL2 (see my review for that).
I feared bugs, not-so-good controller support and such.
Instead, Larian has done an amazing job in taking the masterpiece that Original Sin was and pushing it to the next level.

What I love so far:
- it's FREE for everyone who owns D:OS. Nice!
- playing with a controller feels as good as with k+m, if not better
- UI has massively improved, everything is more coherent, really easy to manage with controller
- performance has improved too: I had to keep settings to medium-highish before, and still game wasn't so fluid. Now I can run it on Ultra on the same machine and it runs super smooth... not bad!
- every line is voice acted, and well acted I'd say!
- dual wielding! yess!

What I don't like so far:
- some minor translation errors in the Italian localisation (nothing gamebreaking, but reading that Dai a" instead of "go to" or something like this is disturbing)
- not able to zoom (or I didn't find how to) during character creation

In the end
date: I wouldn't see a reason not to upgrade to EE and have a fresh start (old saves aren't compatible) if you already own D:OS.\nIf you don't
recommended: just get it now and see for yourself"

reviewText:
This game is great! There's a ton of good things to say about it that I don't know where to start.

One thing that surprised me about the game is that it's hilarious. One of my favorite parts was reading the tomb stones in the grave yard haha it's great.

I'm new to these types of games where there isn't a quest tracker or anything like that so you need to do the reading and listen carefully to the people and quest logs or else you wont know what to do. Even still i've been somewhat following a walkthrough to help me with the quest as I get lost and don't know what to do.

That being said I'm sure if you're use to these types of games or have played it before then you probably won't have any issues.

The story is great and well voice acted. I'm finding myself very interested in the characters and story so that helps me want to come back and play more.

The combat is fantastic and makes you think of ways of winning as in using different tactics and different advantages to help you win. you are usually outnumbered and the fights are not easy to win. especially if you're new. But that's not to say it's not impossible. it's just a very well balance challenging game.

all in all i recommend this game to anyone who has played these types of games before or if you're intrested and wanna try it please try it. that's what I did and i freaking love this game! GET PUMPED

reviewText:
This game is challenging in all the right ways.  It makes you think tactically, plan out your fighting style, and allows you to customize every aspect of your interactions with others. I have only played the enhanced version where they added voice acting for every single character, and I have to say this is one of the most addicting and underrated games I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

Good:
- Makes you think tactically, there is room for error, but not enough to get too comfortable
- Perfectly balanced, it is easy to make a fantastic character, but even with all the right skills and equipment you will rarely just roll over the AI
- The story is incredibly in-depth and there are numerous sidequests that arent just running around delivering stuff
- Length.  I have put 67 hours into this game so far and there are still dozens of quests I need to complete
- Replayability. You have so many options on who you can be and how you can play that any new playthrough will be faster but not any less fun
- Co-op. With the joint use of two minds, the quests and puzzles are easy to parcel out between two people and you both get the expereience for it, so it moves faster.  It also helps to have both people controlling two characters so you never  forget anything you need for any of your characters
- Full controller support. I find the controller easier, but the mouse and keyboard is not hard to use
- This game is absolutely hilarious.  The background banter, conversations, books, and even quests are often funny
- Works well between linux and PC, I have not run into any compatibility issues or glitches


Bad:
- For those who like an easy run-through in games or cheats, this game will not boost your ego.  It can be merciless and you will cry in frustration
- The descriptions of some of the quests are lacking somewhat, so you really need to read/listen to what people are saying
- You may receive quests early on that you can't resolve until later in the game, which sometimes gets confusing

Overall:
This is a fantastic game that doesn't get enough attention, it is one of the best RPGs ever made.  You could do every quest and still enjoy another playthrough. I was hesitant to buy this game knowing so little about it, but I have never had any reason to regret it.  This is a must-play for any gamer. Every quest you finish is rewarding, but with experience and personal enjoyment.

10/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
TL:DR A CRPG style RPG that has some great turn based tactical combat but its weak story lets it down and leads to a pretty boring lategame. I've marked it not recommended because it wasnt for me but dont take that as me saying its a bad game, but more of a mixed review. Some people will find this to be an enjoyable game but it wasnt for me.

Full Version:

This game follows two Source Hunters sent to investigate a murder in Cyseal but uncover a more sinister and dangerous plot. Its a top down CRPG but with a really enjoyable turn based combat that incorparates environmental hazards like fire and ice that gives the combat a tactical edge and it's really enjoyable and the games strongest point.

However the story is pretty weak and I never felt overly invested in it to the point where even the enjoyable combat wasnt enough to keep my interest. Its a shame really as the first 10-15 hours I really enjoyed the game. The Cyseal section is probably the games strongest section but once I left there the new areas never really gave me as much enjoyment or interest. This game wasnt really enjoyable for me but I wouldnt say its a bad game and some people may enjoy it where i didnt.

Good points:
- the turn based combat is great and elements play a big part. You can freeze enemies or stun them with electricity or set them on fire. Learning to utilize these effects is important. The environmental hazard like toxic clouds or ice for example can be used to turn the tide of a fight. These elements add a tactical layer to combat where each move has to be carefully considered.
-the games colourful environments look great particularly the forested and coastal section
-the inclusion of waypoints that allow fast travel from anywhere provided you're not in combat is a plus as it saves a lot of time from having to back track or run everywhere

Bad points:
-while the story starts well with you investigating a suspicious murder it turns into a dull heroes saving the world from destruction" plot and makes the later game quite dull. The later quests arent particularly interesting either and the quest log can feel a bit muddled at times.
-the dialogue is also quite weak and there are few divergent conversations. A lot of it just seemed like dull filler
-the inventory is a bit hit and miss. When equipping characters equipment can be picked from a pool of items carried by all the characters but this doesnt happen when crafting where the character doing the crafting has to be carrying the necessary items.
-the "rock
recommended: scissiors" minigame you play against the AI to settle arguments or to talk your way past enemies feels too random and annoying. They should have tried for a more enjoyable mechanic that takes better account of your level and skills like Charm."

reviewText:
This is my first review ever on Steam.  Sorry to be that silent lurker sort, but I figured it was time I contributed to the community.  After all, I do waste way too much time playing games.

In all honesty; this is one of the best RPGs I have ever played.  And I have played way too many of them.

Leveling actually makes a difference.  The spells are cool and well done.  Voice acting is good throughout the game, which is really rare.  The use of 'the elements', for/against you is a sort of a new idea and well executed and I can't believe nobody else has really done it like this.

The story is kind of basic but it works well and gets the player involved enough.  I would have preferred some sort of more crazy unexpected twist in the plot.

It very re-playable, trying different types of characters and (for me) crafting more.

All in all this game is near perfect.  They have done a very good job.  In my estimation; as good as and in some ways even better than Balder’s Gate, which is difficult for me to admit.

reviewText:
Enhanced Edition is amazing. I disliked the original version, but the new release is really good.

This game is fun and challenging if you do a blind play-through. Its less hardcore than Pillar's of Eternity and Baldur's Gate without being too mainstream casual like most RPGs these days. reviewText:
The original Original Sin is good but had a lot of problems, the Enhanced Edition is better, but still suffer from a lot of problems.
-The new crafting system is very good,
-Controller support is awesome.
-The battle system is simply amazing, really, one of the best Turn Based you'll find.

Of course, the game still suffer from the problems of the original:
-Terrible inventory management: Your characters spend almost all the time together, why not a shared inventory? You have to manage FOUR  inventories at once.
-Conversation is made for two people playing, not one.
-Very few armor and weapons models. 2015 and the only thing that changes are stats and names, the armors look always the same, you just get better stats and powers.

With that being said, still a good game, specially if you like the combat. Not the best thing that will come this year, but is worth a play.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Perhaps one of the most addicting games I've ever played. This game basically took the best aspects of its predecessor, Divine Divinity, and made them even better. If you like lengthy (100+ hours) RPGs with lots of side quests and things to discover off the beaten path, you'll like this game. If you have an appreciation for games that spare no expense when it comes to graphics, music, effects, etc., you'll love this game. If you get nostalgic thinking about old-school, D&D-style RPGs, this game will be a welcome blast from the past (but with much better graphics and killer music). All in all, I think this game will appeal to true RPG-players, given how much effort the writers invested into the storyline - I found the quests to be very well-written, with an array of moral dilemmas, and your character's choices actually having more than one possible consequence. The turn-based combat requires a bit of strategy, especially if you're playing on a higher difficulty, but for those of you who fear that getting away from the hack-and-slash gameplay will take away from the excitment, I promise you this will not be the case. This game also has its share of humour, so if you want to get the best of its witticisms, do take the time to read the tombstones :)

reviewText:
Divinity: Original Sin
It starts off like every other game. You are stranded on a beach and monsters are out to get you. The quests start very early and can be be overwhelming, for fans of to turn play games it is a must. anyone who likes the old crpg games like planescape torment and baldurs gate will find this game an amazingly done rpg. Its length is amazing and the add ons from the publisher give me an erection.

never done multiplayer but apperently its amazing

rpg factors are some of the best

------the story

the story is pretty bad. but... but... but... gameplay is clearly the best in combat turn based rpgs.

it is tons of fun and you will appreciate the mistakes you make when you die.

actually when i die i understand what went wrong and can adjust my technjiques to suit the gameplay.

then i die again.  gameplay 13/10 strategy is the key even if you are a beginner

story  6/10 unoriginal and repeat. but thats what all these games are so i change it to 7/10

thanks for thinking my review sucks balls!!

regards,

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I have ever played. The game is actually challenging, it harkens back to the old RPGs of yore. You will frequently lose fights and you have to figure out which way to go based on which enemies won't curb stomp you. There's no grinding -- better than that, there's nothing to grind. The environment can be manipulated in many ways to turn a fight in your favor; the direction and tactics of the fights you take give the fights a very dynamic quality.

The storyline is deep and engaging; it forks in different ways and it feels like your decisions have weight. It doesn't rely on stale fantasy RPG cliches. The environment is well-crafted with a lot of good set pieces and interesting stuff scattered around. The map isn't even that big but a ton of stuff is crammed into it, making use of every space. The only slightly annoying thing is that some of the voice actors are bad and some of the lines get really repetitive (merchants in Cyseal advertising cheese, fish, and greens).

10/10 GOTY

reviewText:
Can pick up and play whenever you want!
Good story line and can fast skip if not into reading it.
Items and Customisation are good you can build your party any way you want..... However you really need good fire potential either Wizard or atleast a counter to poison and fire meaning you need water spells to remove burning and fire to remove poison haveing a healer is a must.... you pick up full party very early but can modify in base by recruiting.
there are good walkthrough guides online should you get stuck as there is a lot that you have to spend ages figuring out.
All in all a well rounded RPG and good for the Hardcore tactician or the casual run through player.

reviewText:
Warning, minor spoilers!!




Me and my freind played through the game swimmingly, untill we got to the door of the source temple. we didnt have all the inherit stones so we gathered 14 and thought this would be enough. ofc we didnt get through, and after some googling we found out that its the homestead portals that triggers it.
Problem is, zixzax is just standing there, telling us to jump into the portal and see whats inside. we have all the portals in the homstead except two. The last one we unlocked was either the trading emporium or the armory. either way we are stuck.

I just can't grasp how such a huge gamebreaking bugg is still left unattended to. There are apperantly loads of people having trouble with this, and it leaves me with a taste of disgust towards a game that i would outherwise love to death.

reviewText:
With almost 30 hours in the divinity games, (Original Sin) I would have to say that the Enhanced Edition really made me want to actually play the game more, now I have about 19 hours in RDOS, NOT Enhanced. But that was mainly me trying to figure out how to play the game, and creating a multitude of characters to find which one I wanted to play as, now settling on a shadowblade in the Enhanced Edition.

-The journal is still a bit hard to understand coming from a more linear" background of (insert rpg... Fable? yeah we'll go with Fable) standard questing systems.

-I like the 360 camera
date: people may not assume it is THAT big of an update to the game but in reality it really opens but parts of the maps and areas you were previously intangible.\n\n-I honestly wish they would have put more time into the actual customization of the characters features
recommended: however this isn't too big a deal as the game is more based around class customization and combat to really worry about the actual look of a character
hoursPlayed: so long as they have a beard... because who can play an rpg without one?\n\n-The new repairing/identifying inventory system honestly should have been in the Original game
voteText: it was practically a Sin not to have it
helpfulPercent: having someone in your party who is particularly skilled with lore should be able to automatically identify things for you
votesHelpful: but the standard version did not have this feature.\n\n-Controller Support
votesTotal: now I am a huge fan of keyboard and mouse in games where other plebs use controllers
votesFunny: ie. CSGO
commentsCount: COD
column16: Deus EX: HR... To name a few. But the controller in this game is so great.\n\nAll in all
column17: I did skip over a couple new features however
column18: I will say that whilst playing RDOS - Standard
column19: I did think the game felt a little unfinished and most of the things added should have been in the standard game when it was released
column20: and even though this is literally a "new" game that I got for free
column21: (I got both of them for free really / all the older ones that won't run) the game is still great and if you haven't played it yet
column22: I can only say good things.\n\nEXCEPT!!!! IF YOU ARE NOT A FAN OF WALKING A LOT / READING A LOT / ACTUALLY ENJOYING A STORY THEN WHY WOULD YOU PLAY THIS GAME?"

reviewText:
By far one of the best RPG's I have ever played in my entire life! There is no game out there that comes this to close to providing you an RPG experience as interessting and intricate as D&D, while still being so streamlined.

D:OS rewards the player for thinking out of the box; some situations are better solved stealthily, some using charisma and reason, others might go for the hacky-slashy approach (which can work) or maybe the entire combat phase can be skipped if you picked up the key in a crate behind the bookcase which location you read about in a note on a dead NPC.. The ability to take different routes to complete quests (albeit they sometimes provide a different outcome) is something I haven't sene done before. This isn't your simple choose A), B) or C) kinda story. It goes way beyond that..

Combat being turn-based allows for a lot more strategy than you would expect, saving energy on one turn to do a lot on a second after repositioning might turn the entire battle around. Play to your strengths, try to determine your enemies' weakness (movement, resistances, position..), combo spells with your party for devastating damage/CC...

I tried teleporting barrels of oil around, these apparently break from fall damage and covered my friend and a dozen mobs in oil. Both he and I concluded that, him being surrounded, that my mage could only do one thing to help him.. by setting everything and everyone on fire. So much glorious fire. Like seriousily, you have no idea, how much fire there was. Mobs died, left ooze behind, this caught flame, more explosions, more stuff on fire. My friend died. It was a good day.

Another great feuture is the fact that D:OS has two main protagonists, and you play as both of these; so if you have a friend who also owns the game, you can complete the story with the two of you, each controlling one protagonist and one companion. (4 total) The fact that your characters have internal discussions and may or may not agree with one another provides another layer of extreme awesomeness. I will NEVER forgive me friend for forcing me to kill a certain character, even though we had a long in-game discussion (read: rock, paper, scissors) to determine said person's faith. But I wouldn't t reload for all the paintings in Cyseal. Stick to your decisions and breathe the wonderful world of Divinity!

10/10 70h played, only halfway through the game, can't get enough of it!

Pro-tip:
If it looks like you can use it for some kind of crafting, keep it, materials do not respawn. Vendors restock everytime you level up, but this makes things in this game sort of finite. My buddy and I converted an abbandoned building in Cyseal to be our homebase. This place has several crafting stations" and storage where we drop by every so often.
And don't underestimate the power of non-combat-related stats!
"
